subdebate.1.para: Senator MARTIN-I present the following petition from 1 7 1 citizens of Australia:

To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the establishment of an Australian Government Insurance Office will:
1 . Lead to the nationalization of the Insurance Industry.
2. Divert a substantial flow of funds from the private to the public sector.
3. Depress the private sector still further and create unemployment both within the insurance industry and elsewhere.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate rejects completely the Australian Government Insurance Office Bill 1975.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
Petition received and read.
Senator MARTIN- I present the following petition from 1 69 citizens of Australia:
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
( 1 ) That Parliament should reject the Bill currently before it to establish an Australian Government Insurance Office.

(2) That while there is a need to establish in Australia a Natural Disaster Fund to provide compensation for property damage and other losses resulting from disasters such as earthquakes, floods and cyclones, such a Fund can be established, as in other countries, using the medium of the existing private enterprise insurance offices.
(3) That a plan for such a Fund was submitted to the Treasury in October 1974.

(4) That no reasons for the establishment of an Australian Government Insurance Office (other than the desire to provide non-commercial disaster insurance and Australian Government competition with private enterprise) have been given by the Government.

(5) That there is already intense competition between the existing 43 life assurance offices and between over 260 general insurance companies now operating in Australia, and that further competition from a Government Office would only be harmful.
(6) That the insurance industry is already faced with
(a) the effects of inflation,
(b) increased taxation on life assurance offices,
(c) the effects of recent natural disasters,

(d) other legislative measures already in train or in prospect by the Government, e.g. the National Compensation Bill, a National Superannuation Plan and improved Commonwealth Public Service Superannuation.

(7) That as taxpayers your petitioners are greatly concerned at the huge costs (far more than the $2 million initial capital and loan funds which it is proposed will be allocated ) of establishing an Australian Government Insurance Office.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will reject the Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
Petition received.
Senator MARTIN-I present the following petition from 22 citizens of Australia:

To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully refer to the Bill concerning the establishment of an Australian Government Insurance Office:

We are not necessarily against the formation of such an organisation. We do, however, feel that the Bill could be rushed through Parliament without sufficient deliberation. Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Bill be referred to a Senate Select Committee or Public Enquiry Committee. In this way submissions from interested parties can be called for. Recommendations from this Committee would then reflect the true wishes of the Australian electorate.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
Petition received and read. The Clerk- The following petitions have been lodged for presentation:

talk.start.para: My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the inquiry into the alleged theft of letters from the office of the former Treasurer, Dr J. F. Cairns, begun? Will the findings of that inquiry be made public? If the Minister cannot give a detailed answer now, will he give a detailed answer to those questions no later than tomorrow morning?

Prime Minister indicated last week that as a result of certain events concerning the department for which Dr J. F. Cairns had been responsible the Prime Minister would hold an inquiry into the matters which had been raised. I think, for the record, I should read the letter which the Prime Minister addressed to the Secretary of the Treasury, Sir Frederick Wheeler, on 6 June this year. The Prime Minister wrote:

quote.para: Dear Sir Frederick,

You will be aware of the statement made in the House of Representatives yesterday by the then Treasurer, Dr Cairns, concerning the handling of papers in his Office, in the Treasury and in the Attorney-General's Department, dealing with loan raisings.

Naturally I take a serious view of what Dr Cairns has said and I therefore require from you a full report insofar as your Department is concerned, including signed statements from any individual members of the staff who have dealt with this matter in a material way.
The report and accompanying statement should be produced to me early next week.

answer.para: The letter was signed by the Prime Minister. As he has indicated, it is quite clear that he wants this matter properly investigated. For that reason he has decided to set in train an inquiry.

When the result of that inquiry is eventually presented to him, he will consider the report. If the report contained discrepancies or matters which he felt required further investigation he would- and I would give an undertaking on his behalf- appoint an independent inquiry if he thought that was necessary. It will be a matter of judgment based on the nature of the report and the material contained in it. I can assure the Senate that the Prime Minister will act in a most responsible way in respect of the report when it is presented. If discrepancies should appear he will certainly have an independent inquiry held.

talk.start.para: Has the Minister for Agriculture seen recent figures concerning requests by Tasmanian dairy farmers for assistance under the Dairy Industry Adjustment Scheme? Do the figures support some Opposition Party claims that the scheme is unattractive to Tasmanian dairymen?

The Dairy Industry Adjustment scheme which was introduced by this Government in 1973 in fact has had an excellent response from all the States, but in particular from Tasmania. There have been no fewer than 126 applications approved to the end of April and I understand that the initial figures for May would suggest a continuing interest by Tasmanian dairymen. The total amount which has been approved for assistance to dairymen themselves is very close to $700,000. In addition to that, approvals of approximately $250,000 have been made available for factory assistance and the restructuring process. I believe that the success of the scheme is unquestioned. The form of assistance now is in direct contrast to the form of assistance that was operating in the industry previously. I am sure that, on all the evidence available so far, this scheme will stop the drift of dairymen out of the industry which has been reaching serious proportions, not in the last 2 years but as a continuing process over the last 10 years.

My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: Is the Government engaged in any inquiry or does it intend to have any inquiry as to how many letters of credentials and/or authority have been given by Ministers in this Government to various persons in relation to overseas loans? To whom have they been given; what was the nature of the letters or authorities, and what Ministers have in fact given such authorities?

I do not know on what grounds Senator Durack asks the question, because it is directed at the Government as a whole. I have just indicated, and the Prime Minister himself indicated last week, that in respect of the matters that were the subject of some detailed discussion in the House of Representatives last week, such an inquiry will in fact be held and the information relating to that matter will be sought and placed before the Prime Minister. It is, I believe, quite wrong of Senator Durack- I will not say mischievous- but I do not know why he sees the need for such an inquiry to be extended across the whole range of government. I am sure that if the Prime Minister considered such an inquiry necessary he would act accordingly. But at the present time the Government is committed to ensuring that all the details and the facts relating to the matters that I have just dealt with in my first answer here this morning will be properly investigated.

My question is addressed to the Minister for Labor and Immigration. It relates to the decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission implementing wage indexation and to the further review of that decision in July of this year. I ask the Minister: What attitude will the Australian Government be taking in submissions to the Commission in the hearing in July relating to indexation?

Before deciding on what attitude the Government will take in the national wage case hearing in July it will be necessary to see what happens in the industrial relations arena in the meantime. The Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission made the important point in its decision of 30 April this year that:

quote.para: If the conditions we have set down for indexation are violated by even a small section of industry, whether in the award or non-award area, it would put at risk the future of indexation for all.

answer.para: The Government supports the continuation of wage indexation, provided that the conditions set down by the Commission in its decision of 30 April are complied with or substantially complied with. The Government welcomed that decision as a sensible and courageous attempt to introduce in this country a system of wage fixation combining social equity and economic responsibility. I believe that the decision to accept wage indexation in principle and to set conditions to be met if it is to operate on a continuing basis has the support of the overwhelming majority of employees and the greater part of the trade union movement. The Government has already indicated its support for the indexation decision in the national wage case by intervening in the metal industry case before Mr Justice Moore to support the principles set down in that decision and to submit that the claims in the metal industry should be assessed in terms of the principles of that decision. We shall continue to take action whenever necessary and appropriate to support the principles set down in the decision.

talk.start.para: My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Will the Government table all files relating to arrangements which have been made with private individuals or institutions since January 1 972 to assist in loan raisings?

As I indicated in answer to the first question I had this morning, upon receipt of the report which the Prime Minister has initiated, he will then decide what further action he should take, if that is necessary. I do not believe that there is anything further that I should add or need to add.

I direct a question to the new Minister for Social Security, and I welcome him to that assignment. Does the Minister visualise a future external development of Medibank when Australians who have an appendix or similar operation in distant places like Copenhagen or Belgrade will find that, due to reciprocal agreements with European nations, an international coverage will remove them from the extremely tough negotiations they now have to indulge in when they are dealing with hospital and medical benefit funds?

I must confess that I am sorry I can no longer say this is a matter I will refer to my colleague the Minister for Social Security, and I can assure everybody present that this question was not asked by previous arrangement. I should certainly hope that the sort of thing Senator Mulvihill envisages can be accomplished. It must be extremely awkward having problems with one's appendix when one is in Copenhagen or Belgrade and not only having to go through all the inconvenience of that but then having to confront the hospital and medical funds as well. I will inquire further into the proposal that Senator Mulvihill has put forward. I know that he has always been very interested in the portability of pensions, so I take it that he is also interested in the portability of Medibank. That is a matter which I will certainly be examining.

My question is directed to the Minister for the Media. Is it- correct that radio stations 4KQ Brisbane and 4IP Ipswich have made technical changes which substantially affect their coverage areas? If so, what explanation is forthcoming as to why no public hearings were held?

I answer the question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for the Media, but the matters to which the honourable senator refers occurred during the time when I was the Minister for the Media. In about February 1974 I announced that arrangements could be made for the restructuring of broadcasting frequencies and that, with the stations going into directional aerial arrangements, more power could be given to broadcasting stations and, by a readjustment of the band, more broadcasting stations could be available to the Australian public. It was as a result of that decision in, I think, February 1974 that 4IP and 4KQ made representations to the Broadcasting Control Board to shift their mast into Moreton Bay, to operate from joint mas ting facilities and to operate at increased power. I understand that the Chairman of the Broadcasting Control Board went to Brisbane and had discussions with representatives of all the commercial broadcasting stations, and that after those discussions the Board agreed to the proposal that was submitted by 4IP and 4KQ.

I direct my question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I ask: Firstly, since the Australian Legal Aid Office was opened in Launceston on 16 December 1974, how many persons have sought advice from the staff of the office? Secondly, how many persons have been referred to private legal practitioners whose fees have been or will be paid by the Australian Government? Thirdly, what is the total staff of the office at present, and is it proposed to appoint additional staff?

The honourable senator gave me some advance notice that he was desirous of obtaining this information. The answer to the first part of the question is 1 146 persons. This figure does not include advice given by letter and court appearances on behalf of clients. The answer to the second part of the question is 204 persons. The answer to the third part of the question is that the total staff of the office at present is four. There are 2 lawyers and 2 clerks employed in the office and it is not proposed to appoint additional staff at the present time.

I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Will the Minister table a list showing details of all free overseas airline tickets received as gifts by Ministers who are at present members of Parliament or who may have resigned from Parliament? Will the Minister list the airlines which gave free trips to Ministers, and include in the list details of free tickets given to members of Ministers 'families?

I must confess that I do not even understand what the question is about. The honourable senator has asked for details of free trips given to Ministers and members of their families. I think that the honourable senator should place the question on the notice paper. We will see whether we can understand it then.

Has the attention of the Postmaster-General been drawn to an article which appeared on page 2 of this morning's Australian' which, under the heading 'Post Office gets tax records, says subscriber', asserts that the Australian Post Office has access to Taxation Office records? Can the Minister say whether the assertion is correct?

Yes, I have read the article. I suggest that whoever gave the information to the person concerned was wrongly advised. The assertion is not correct In the article it is claimed that telephone subscribers are paying the higher business rentals because of information supplied by the Taxation Office. The Post Office never seeks nor obtains any information from the Taxation Office. Honourable senators will know that there are 2 rates- one for business rentals and the other for residential rentals. Where there is any doubt as to the classification of a subscriber the subscriber is asked about the use of his telephone and, in some cases, he is asked to make a declaration as to the telephone's use. The Post Office does not rely on receiving any information from the Taxation Office.

My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind him of the information he earlier gave to the Senate- that the inquiry directed by the Prime Minister was an inquiry into the specific matters alleged last week by Dr Cairns in regard to his files. I ask the Minister Is he able to assure the Senate that the only authorities issued on a commission basis to investigate the availability of loan moneys overseas were the authorities given by the Minister for Minerals and Energy to Mr Khemlani and the authorities given by Dr Cairns to Mr Harris? Is he able to say positively that no other authorities were issued?

As far as I am aware, the only 2 Ministers concerned in that particular matter of overseas loan moneys were the 2 Ministers who have been named by Senator Greenwood. I believe that over the past several weeks there has been adequate disclosure of that fact in respect of those overseas borrowings. I am not aware of any other grounds that would warrant any further consideration being extended into other areas.
Were other authorities issued?
I am not able to say whether there were or not. If there were, I will obtain that information if I can and give it to the honourable senator.

I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Following last week's events- that is the ruthless crushing by the Canberra heavies of the National Country Party of Australia of the attempted deviance from the Party's mono lot hic Canberra line by State branches of the National Country Party in Western Australia and Tasmania, which indicates that the Liberal Party and the National Country Party have repudiated the doctrine of partial State autonomy which they once espoused- have the Liberal and National Country Party governments of New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia told him that they will cease trying to sabotage the full introduction of Medibank, as they have been doing under a spurious States rights banner?

No,oddly enough they have not told me that. I have been expecting that they would at any time because I noticed the intervention which Senator Walsh, with his Per.cipience, also chanced upon- the event which took place in Western Australia whereby the Federal body of the National Country Party by its intervention was able to overwhelm the opinions of apparently the majority of members of the State branch of the Party regarding their participation in the coalition government. But it would seem that as yet the message which is inherent in that event, namely that there ought to be national solidarity, has not penetrated the minds of Mr Bjelke-Petersen and other prominent figures within the Opposition parties. The only redeeming feature one can see about this, at least insofar as solidarity between the States is concerned, is that Mr Lewis, the Premier of New South Wales, has not taken the lead of Mr Bjelke-Petersen and Mr Hamer in supporting the claim by the doctors for an increase in costs grossly in excess of that which was recommended by the independent tribunal which inquired into that matter. That is an example of the way the divisions, the sharp divisions, between the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Lewis, and Mr Hamer are of benefit to the people as a whole.

Is the Minister for Labor and Immigration aware of reports of the difficulties being experienced by the United States of America in making suitable arrangements for the future welfare of Vietnamese refugees of whom some 30 000 refugees still remain on the Island of Guam, living under unsatisfactory conditions? Did the Prime Minister undertake at one time that Australia would take its fair share in the settling of Vietnamese refugees in Australia? In the light of present difficulties, will the Minister now vary the Government's present inhumane restrictions on the admittance of such refugees, speedily increase the inflow of such refugees into Australia and give guarantees of continuing residence to Vietnamese students in Australia and to their families?

Perhaps it would be appropriate if I gave the honourable senator the benefit of a resume of what the Australian Government has done with regard to those who were unfortunate enough to be displaced in South Vietnam as a result of the conflict so enthusiastically supported for so many years by the other side of politics in this country.
Who started the contest?
Is it suggested that the Labor Government started the contest? I think we can ignore that interjection.
Oh, come on.

If the Opposition is interested to know, I can give it a lot of information on the matter. There are 3 distinct aspects of the recent Vietnam situation as far as migration to Australia is concerned. Firstly, there were applications for persons in South Vietnam immediately prior to the change of government there. Secondly, there were the so-called Vietnamese orphan flights. Thirdly, there was the refugee situation following the change of government. Up to the time the Australian Embassy was evacuated on 24 April this year, nominations covering 3667 persons had been received by the Department in Australia. Of these the following were approved: Wives, dependent children and aged parents of Australian residents; wives and dependent children of students for temporary entry only; and those who met normal occupational requirements for migration to Australia. In addition there were some special cases approved at Prime Ministerial and ministerial level. In total 380 of these 3667 persons were approved, most immediately before the embassy was evacuated. How many of these 380 have succeeded in coming to Australia is unknown, but it is a small number. Heavy nominations continued and the final total was 5400.

continue.para: There have been 2 Vietnamese orphan nights. The first arrived in Sydney on 5 April with 208 children. The second arrived in Melbourne on 1 8 April with 78 children. All children were approved by the then South Vietnamese authorities for movement to Australia for the purpose of adoption. They are under the guardianship of the Minister for Social Security by virtue of the Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act. The State and Territorial child welfare authorities are his delegates. Where children were already 'linked' to Australian families they were sent to the State or Territory concerned, regardless of whether the family had been approved by the child welfare authorities. Whether the children were then placed with the family concerned was then solely the responsibility of the State or Territorial child welfare authorities. Of 261 children transferred to the States' care some are still in hospital- most, 115, went to South Australia. The numbers going to other States and territories were New South Wales, 62; Victoria, 50; Australian Capital Territory, 13; Queensland, 8; Western Australia, 7; Tasmania 5; and Northern Territory, one.

Estimates of the total number of persons who left South Vietnam immediately before and after the change of government vary. Most went directly or indirectly to American territory. Guam has had a steady refugee population of around 50 000, despite substantial movements towards the United States. Quite large groups have already been located in Hong Kong, Singapore, Thailand and Korea. Two Australian migration officers were sent to Guam to locate approved cases and to approve any others which met the criteria outlined in what I have just mentioned. A total of 64 persons were brought to Australia from Guam on a Royal Australian Air Force Hercules. Three Australian officers, including the two who were in Guam, are currently processing cases in Hong Kong refugee camps. At present more than 170 have been approved and arrangements are being made to bring them to Australia by Qantas charter. The initiative still rests with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and no Australian migration officers have been sent to Korea and Thailand to interview Vietnamese refugees there. I suggest that in the light of this information it is very hard for the Opposition to sustain the thesis it has so regularly plugged that the Australian Government has been indifferent or has dragged its feet in giving attention to the refugee problem.

talk.start.para: Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I appreciate what the Minister has told me, but what I want to know and what the question was about is whether there is any change in the policy that has been adopted in the light of the present difficulties.

There has been no change since I became Minister responsible for this situation. I think the honourable senator will recognise that I have not had adequate time to inform myself of all aspects of the problems that suddenly have been thrust upon me. I shall take it upon myself to inquire and to let the honourable senator know the answer to that aspect of his question.

Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware that there has been a chronic unemployment rate of 4 million people in the United States since the end of World War II, despite a succession of conservative governments? Has the Minister noted that current reports from America indicate that that number has now doubled and 8.5 million Americans are out of work, the highest number since 1941, the year America entered the war and the last year of the 1 930s depression? Do not these figures indicate the apparently more healthy economy in Australia where the unemployment rate is not chronic, permanent or high?

The state of unemployment in the United States is consistent with that of all countries in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development of which Australia is a member. It indicates the common problems which are being faced by all members of the Organisation. It is true that the United

answer.para: States is probably suffering more severe economic problems than we are in this country, lt is correct that the rate of unemployment in the United States is twice as high as it is in Australia. It is important to realise also that the anticipated deficit for 1975-76 in the United States will be not less than $70,000m which makes it just slightly higher proportionally than we anticipate in this country. It also should be borne in mind that even though there has been a reduction in the proportion of profits going to the private sector in this country in the last 12 months, there has been a higher reduction in the United States.

It was the Australian Government which realised the need for increased expenditure by this Government to lift Australia out of the recession which was ensnaring all OECD countries. The United States Government did exactly the same thing. The only difference was that it followed Australia; it was later in doing so. America has exactly the same problems as have all other OECD countries. This is not something which is peculiar to Australia; it is peculiar to a whole range of countries. In fact, Australia has weathered the situation a lot better than most members of the OECD, including America.

talk.start.para: My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Do members of Parliament forfeit the right to their electorate offices immediately after they resign from Parliament or after they cease to be Ministers? I refer the Minister to reports in today's newspapers that the Australian Labor Party has set up temporary campaign headquarters for the Bass by-election in the office of the retiring member, Mr Barnard. I ask: Who is paying the rent for the use of this office for the period following the resignation of Mr Barnard? Will the Minister assure the Senate that the rental will be paid by the Australian Labor Party and not borne by the people of Australia?
I can answer that question. I have taken over the office previously occupied by Mr Barnard, as from yesterday morning.

talker.role: Minister for Science and Consumer Affairs
talker.name: CAMERON, Donald Newton
Senator DONALD CAMERON

talk.start.para: My question to the Postmaster-General relates to the Australian Post Office testing of a system which provides for telephone calls to an unattended police station to be automatically switched to the radio in a duty officer's patrol car. Can the Minister say whether the experimental period of this system has been completed? If so, how successful have the tests been?

South Australian Police Force and the Post Office have been experimenting with this new system for about 6 months, particularly in the area of Victor Harbour which is not a good area for radio communications. I have been advised by my Department that the tests which have been carried out have proved very satisfactory. It looks as though the system can be adopted generally. Presently Post Office officials and South Australian police are negotiating to see to what extent the system might be applied generally throughout the State.

My question to the Minister for Repatriation and Compensation relates to the Repatriation Department's practice in all States of paying State institutions, such as nursing homes, mental hospitals and some regional public hospitals where there are no repatriation facilities, the cost associated with the medical care of veterans. I ask: Is it a fact that the Department owes such institutions in Tasmania $80,000 and that this amount is increasing? What is the reason for this amount being outstanding? When are the arrears likely to be paid?

I have to confess that I was not aware that there were any arrears. I would say in passing that it does not seem to me that $80,000 is a very large sum considering the number of people who are probably using the facilities and the cost of such facilities. Nonetheless I think that if delay in payment dragged on for any length of time it would be a matter of some seriousness. I undertake to find out from my Department whether there is any undue delay in Tasmania or the other States and, if there is, how it occurred and what can be done to remedy it as soon as possible.

I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the abortive and somewhat unorthodox attempt by the Government to borrow petrodollars from Arabian sources. Is it a fact that the former Treasurer, Dr Cairns, called at Hong Kong on his way back from China to examine the possibility of arranging a $4,000m loan from the Arabs? Can the Minister say whether talks with a Chinese agent on that occasion were not continued because of advice from the Australian High Commission that the person concerned had been convicted on various charges?

I am not in a position to say what talks Dr Cairns had in Hong Kong or with whom he had discussions. As I said earlier in question time today, the Government has given a proper account of matters involving negotiations for overseas loans. It has been stated on many occasions that it is traditional for a government not to disclose confidential information concerning overseas fund raising. That practice was not introduced by this Government but has been continued from past governments over the years. With regard to further detailed information on this matter, I can only state that the Prime Minister has initiated an inquiry and will consider the contents of the report when he receives it.

I address a question to the Minister for Labor and Immigration. I refer to media reports that the Minister advocates a general wage pause as a major weapon in the fight against inflation. Can the Minister tell the Senate in what form such a wage pause is to be achieved? For what duration is it to be applied? How would it be enforced?

The term wage pause' can be variously interpreted. I certainly was not suggesting anything in the nature of a wage freeze- which of course I assume would be strenuously opposed by the honourable senators opposite, otherwise we undoubtedly would have heard something from them condemning the recent action of the Australian Medical Association in going for a 12.5 per cent increase in doctors' fees. So the expression 'wage pause', as it is suggested by the honourable senator, is not to be interpreted to mean a wage freeze.
Is not a pause a stop?

No. Let me state quite clearly my attitude to unionists' claims. I believe that in no circumstances should their standard of living be allowed to drop because of rises in prices of goods. This is what we set out to achieve in our espousal of a program of indexation which has been introduced on a temporary experimental basis by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I believe that if wage increases occur this year in proportions far greater than the rise in the price of commodities, they will have a catastrophic effect on the economy. For that reason I believe that unionists should confine their demands for wage increases, at least during this year, to figures which will cover the loss in purchasing power of their wages, and that they should postpone a request for a greater share of the products of society at least until we have pegged back the rate of inflation. It is in that sense that I use the term 'wage pause'.
That is not a pause; that is a climb.

I would suggest to the honourable senator who asked me the question, if he interprets wage pause to mean a wage freeze, that he should convey that propaganda to the doctors of Australia whom I have not heard him even criticise.

My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I preface it by reminding the Minister that the parallel take-off and landing system practised by Australia's two major airlines seriously disadvantages people living in provincial cities and country areas. Will the Minister request his colleague, the Minister for Transport, to undertake a study during the parliamentary recess in order to ascertain the possibility of breaking the stranglehold by Ansett Airlines of Australia on the Australian airline industry and, if possible, to give passengers outside capital cities a reasonable choice of airlines with rationalised take-off and landing times?

I am aware that the Minister has had negotiations with the airlines on this matter, as did the former Minister for Civil Aviation, Senator Cotton, to see to what extent this practice could be altered. I am not aware of the current position. The Minister for Transport is overseas for a couple of weeks but I will take the matter up with his Department and with the Minister, as soon as he returns to Australia.

I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: Did the Treasury or the Attorney-General's Department advise the Government against the use of private individuals or private companies to assist in overseas loan raising? Were warnings received on this method of overseas loan raising from any other institutions, such as the Bank of England?

I cannot provide that information. I am not aware of what precisely has taken place between the Treasury and the Attorney-General's Department and I believe that in view of the remarks I made earlier no comments should be made at this stage.

Can the Minister for Repatriation and Compensation explain how the proposed Australian Government Insurance Corporation, if it entered the reinsurance field, could benefit Australian insurance companies and the Australian economy? Is there any real need to have an Australian company operating in this field?

I take this opportunity of answering not only the question which has just been asked by Senator Poyser but also more fully a very perceptive question which was asked by Senator Laucke last week in the Senate, the answer to which tended to get lost in the thrust and parry of the repartee associated with some other matters which were raised by way of interjection. I think it is necessary to say first of all that what is meant by reinsurance is the taking by an insurer or re insurer of all or part of the risk which has been entered into by another insurance office. The existence of re insurers enables insurers to issue policies exceeding the amounts which they would otherwise be able to afford to write. Without making the whole matter sound too vulgar, it is a bit like a bookmaker engaging in the operations which we well know bookmakers engage in with other bookmakers when a rather substantial bet has been placed with them.
Laying off.

It is referred to as laying off, as I am advised by Senator Douglas McClelland, who is more familiar with these matters than I. Apart from providing this sort of assistance, reinsurance also provides insurance offices with protection against the sort of catastrophe which can sometimes strike them, as was the case in the Darwin cyclone, whereby damage which has occurred can be met by a variety of offices rather than by the one or two offices that happened to be engaging in the insurance business in the area affected. Re insurers also spread their risks by further re insuring some of their business against catastrophe. The reinsurance business is one of the most complex aspects of a very complex industry, and it is very largely operated internationally. Because all of the reinsurance companies in Australia are foreign owned and are either foreign companies or the Australian incorporated subsidiaries of foreign companies, there is a large flow of funds out of Australia. Admittedly, this has not been the case over the last couple of years, when as a result of the various unfortunate episodes that have occurred here, of which the Darwin cyclone was the most recent, a loss has been sustained by re insurers. Taken not over the last couple of years but over the last ten or twenty years, generally speaking, reinsurance has proven to be a profitable undertaking.

continue.para: If and when the Australian Government Insurance Corporation enters the field of reinsurance it will be able to retain some of this business in Australia. Not only will it be retained in Australia but it will be transacted by an Australian owned reinsurance enterprise. Reinsurance is undertaken only by very large overseas companies because very large potential losses are involved in reinsurance. Whether the Australian Government Insurance Corporation goes into this field will depend on its success as a commercial venture. It may be recollected that last week Senator Laucke asked me how, with such small funds as those made available initially, the Corporation can go into the reinsurance business. The answer to that question which was asked by Senator Laucke and which was in addition to Senator Poyser's question is that this will depend on how successful the Australian Government Insurance Corporation is.

What we are doing is making it clear that one of the powers of the Board of the Australian Government Insurance Corporation will be the power to engage in reinsurance activities. We ope that when the Corporation is successful it will engage in reinsurance, which in the long run will be of considera ble benefit to the Australian people, but writing reinsurance business is certainly not something which could be done ab into because obviously the necessary funds would not be available until such time as the other commercial activities of the Australian Government Insurance Corporation had proven to be widely supported and successful.

talk.start.para: I ask the Minister for Labor and Immigration: How far have the guidelines laid down by the Prime Minister prevented South Vietnamese refugees from entering Australia on humanitarian grounds? I will convey the honourable senator's question to the Prime Minister who, I think it will be agreed on all sides of politics, has never failed to show the utmost humanitarian spirit.

My question is addressed to the Minister for Repatriation and Compensation and Minister for Social Security. Have insulting messages been sent from the Melbourne office of his Department when replying to people who have applied for unemployment benefits? An example of the comments alleged to have been made is: 'Don't try it again, bludger'. If these allegations are correct, what action has the Minister taken in the matter?

This is a matter which concerns my capacity as Minister for Social Security. If I may say so, I feel as if I could probably get a job with Wirth's Circus as at the moment I have 3 Permanent Heads. The information which I have has been provided by officers of the Department of Social Security. It is to the effect that 4 instances have been discovered of outgoing correspondence from the Melbourne office to social security beneficiaries in Victoria having delightful little inscriptions such as 'Don': try it again, bludger'.
Order!
I am not using the word 'bludger' myself, Mr President; I am quoting.
It is an unparliamentary word.

I realise that the word is unparliamentary. One can imagine the distress it would cause the recipients of such correspondence if it even distresses members of Parliament. Form SU1 1, of whose existence I have to confess I was hitherto unaware but which has recently of necessity come to my attention, is a card that requests people in receipt of unemployment benefit to notify the Department of any change in circumstances. In some instances these forms have been returned by beneficiaries in the mistaken belief that it was necessary to return them even though no change in circumstances had occurred. Such comments as 'found new job' have been inserted on these forms, which has resulted in the unemployment benefit being terminated.

continue.para: Action has been taken by officers of the Department of Social Security to peruse the outgoing mail and to intercept the blank SU11 forms which have been returned. Arrangements have been made for the Australia Police to commence investigations immediately in an attempt to identify the person or persons responsible for this. This is a very serious matter because the receipt of social security benefits by unemployed people is something that is necessary for them. It is certainly a most disgraceful situation if some employee of the Department is taking it upon himself to deprive these people of their social security benefits without any justification by giving misleading information and by writing insulting inscriptions on the mail that is delivered to them. I trust that the malefactor will be apprehended.

talk.start.para: My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, refers to the subject matter of the first question asked of him this morning in relation to which he made a statement on behalf of the Prime Minister. I ask: Does the Government consider that the relationship that exists between a Minister and the head of his department means that responsibility is indivisible and that confidence and communication must be exchanged without reservation? Did that relationship exist between the former Treasurer and his Permanent Head? If so, why did the Prime Minister write the letter of 6 June in the terms disclosed to the Senate this morning? Did the Prime Minister write in similar terms to any other departmental head?

As to the very last part of the question, I do not know whether the Prime Minister has written to any other departmental head. As to the general substance of the question, I am quite sure that if any problems exist between any Minister of the present Government and his Permanent Head it would not be a breaking of new ground as that is something which has obtained, I would say, all through the years of Australian politics and which probably will obtain in the future.

Can the Minister representing the Minister for Defence give the

question.para: Senate some indication of the resignation, re engagement and recruitment figures in the armed Services at this time? Are these figures considered satisfactory by the Department of Defence?

talk.start.para: The last figures that I have show that the total strength of the Services has increased by 250 persons. Recruitment has been exceedingly good. The later figures show that recruitments totalled 6 1 3 in April compared with 408 at the same time last year. The number of officer resignations has dropped. The number of male officers resigning and leaving the Services was 39 in April and of these 27 were officers who were eligible for a pension and who in effect retired early. Officer resignations for the 4-month period ended April 1975 totalled 178, a fall of 43 per cent. In addition, re-engagement figures are very high. I address my question to the Minister for Labor and Immigration. Will the Minister agree that none of the 250 000 people who are unemployed, together with those precariously employed by the Regional Employment Development scheme, plus the many small businesses that are on the verge of bankruptcy in Australia would share the opinion of the Prime Minister that Australians are better off now than ever before?

I welcome the contribution which the honourable senator has just made to the forthcoming campaign in Bass, but I think that a question like his deserves most careful consideration which I propose to give to it. One arm of the question which has just been put to me reveals the new-found concern of honourable senators opposite for the plight of small businessmen. As I pointed out in answer to, I think, Senator Marriott last week, the plight of the small businessman engaged the belated attention of the Liberal-Country Party coalition around the year 1968. So steamed up was the coalition about the plight of the small businessman that it initiated an inquiry into his plight. It was a leisurely inquiry and a report found its way in due course on to the shelves of the Liberal - Country Party coalition about the year 1970. But by December 1972 when this Government came to office no action had been taken in respect of that report and we still do not know what that report contained.

answer.para: By contrast this Government took speedy action to set up small business bureaux as a pilot scheme, in Perth and Sydney. At the bureaux advice can be given to small businessmen. We hope that the advice will enable them to improve their operations. A study of the plight of small businessmen over the years would convince the honourable senator, and indeed all honourable senators, that at all times a high proportion of small businesses do go bankrupt. That proves nothing more, in my view, than that a large number of people who undertake business are ill-equipped to undertake business at all.

As to the others in the community for whom the honourable senator's heart bleeds, I think it has to be agreed that, in the unforeseen economic circumstances in which we find ourselves today and which are due largely to forces beyond our control, the Government has moved speedily to alleviate the lot of those who do feel the chill economic winds which are, of course, but temporary. The various schemes that we have undertaken, such as the Regional Employment Development scheme and various schemes under the structural adjustment program, are doing everything which it is possible for a government to do to alleviate the plight of those who are not at work at the present time. In addition, the Government has undertaken a whole series of remedial actions which I feel confident will soon get the economy back on an even keel.

talk.start.para: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Media. I refer to a question asked of the Minister by Senator McLaren last Thursday in relation to the number of repeats of television programs on Australian television stations. Is it a fact that television channels participate in an auction or ballot type system for the purchase of overseas series and feature films, thereby creating a most unreal price for these products? If that is so, would it not be one of the contributing factors in the high rate of repeats, to enable the channels at least to get value for their money? If the answer to both those questions is in the affirmative, will the Minister advise what action can be taken by either his Department or the Broadcasting Control Board to bring a more realistic price level to these products, thereby eliminating the necessity for innumerable repeats being foisted on the Australian public?

When I first became Minister for the Media, there had been in practice an operation whereby television stations in Australia would purchase programs from abroad on a packaging arrangement. In other words, if one station wanted to purchase a program it would have to purchase with that program a number of other programs. In the early life of my Department we conducted negotiations with the stations and they agreed that they would not engage in that sort of activity, and I assume that that sort of activity is no longer in existence. However, the matter is now one for my colleague, the Minister for the Media. I think I should refer the matter to him because it no longer falls within my jurisdiction.

I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Urban and Regional Development. I have received inquiries from local government authorities in South Australia who have expressed concern at a recent, news item, the source of which is attributed to the Minister for Urban and Regional Development, which indicated that local government would be that tier of government to be singled out particularly in respect of cuts in governmental expenditure or funding next year. Is the concern expressed by local government authorities in fact justified? Will the Minister clarify the position?

If the report is correct, essentially it is a matter of government policy in framing the Budget and therefore not a matter which should be raised at question time. I know of no intention to make cuts specifically in local government expenditure in the Budget context next financial year. If I can ascertain any information, firstly, as to whether the Minister for Urban and Regional Development made any such statement and, secondly, as regards his authority for making the statement, I shall supply it to the honourable senator, but I know of nothing which can help the honourable senator.
I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Defence whether he will table this week the manifest for all VIP flights up to the latest date possible.
Senator Withers raised this question last week. Arrangements will be made to table them either tomorrow or the next day.

I direct a question to the Minister for Social Security. Why is the Government abolishing the Social Welfare Commission? Is it to stifle criticism of the inconsistent welfare programs being developed by the

question.para: Government which give little or no priority to the relief of poverty- criticism which has been ably supported by the Social Welfare Commission? Will the Government permit the Public Service Board to put the Social Welfare Commission out of operation by refusing the Commission staff, or will the Commission be allowed to carry on until the Government delivers the legislative coup de grace during the Budget session?

talk.start.para: Senator Chaney is obviously referring to a statement which was made last week by the Prime Minister to the effect that the Social Welfare Commission in its present form would be abolished and would take the form in future of a bureau within one or other of the social welfare departments. I should have thought that the Opposition would welcome this because, as I understood it, one of the Opposition's complaints about the Labor Government was that it had too many commissions.
This is a very good one.

The Opposition does not object to this one; it likes the Social Welfare Commission. Certainly any actions which are taken by the Public Service Board, as I think Senator Chaney would know, are taken by the Board independently of what the Government does. I am not in a position to direct the Public Service Board on what it does. In fact, one of the problems that I seem to have had since I have been a Minister is taking directions from the Public Service Board rather than vice versa. All I can say is that it is proposed that there should be a more rational organisation of the whole of the social welfare system of Australia. I would say that there has been- I would think, indeed I would hope, that members of the Opposition would agree with me- unnecessary duplication of a great many functions in the whole social welfare field. It will be one of my purposes to try to eliminate this duplication. Certainly if Senator Chaney is suggesting that some vindictive action has been taken, that the Government has not done enough about poverty, or if he is arguing that insufficient has been done about the Regional Employment Development scheme, or the National Employment and Training scheme, I would be interested to debate the matter with him. If he is suggesting that in some way we have not been assisting Professor Henderson's inquiry into poverty, I would be very interested to debate this matter also with Senator Chaney and find out the propositions he is putting forward.

continue.para: I do not think that any government has done more to eliminate poverty within Australia than this Government has done. But in any event, there will need to be full discussion concerning the future of the Social Welfare Commission and the functions which are presently performed by the Commission. It was established by legislation. If it is ultimately to be abolished, it will have to be abolished by legislation. I would hope that this is a matter which will be dealt with in a co-operative non-partisan manner. The Commission was established by this Government and I trust that the Opposition will not try to make some party political capital out of administrative arrangements, the purpose of which is to bring about rationalisation, the elimination of duplication and the consequent saving of the Australian people's money.

talk.start.para: Mr President, earlier this morning Senator Mulvihill asked me a question about what I suppose could be described as the portability of Medibank benefits. His question related to the position of somebody who might be taken ill in a foreign country. The objective of the Government is to see that when Medibank is fully operating and all of the States have adopted the hospital benefit branch as well as the medical benefit branch of the Medibank service, arrangements will be entered into with those countries which have national health services to see that they are made reciprocal. Unfortunately it will be necessary for all the States to have entered into the hospital benefit arrangements, otherwise we would find the anomaly that somebody from South Australia, for example, would be able to go to Denmark or Austria or Britain and receive hospital benefits, but not be able to get them if he went to Victoria, Western Australia or any State which had not adopted the hospital side of Medibank. Certainly this is our intention, and there is no doubt that if all the countries with national health services do work co-operatively in this way it will be of great benefit to many people, both people visiting this country and people from Australia who are visiting other countries.

debateinfo.title: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK BILL 1975

debate.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Bishop) read a first time.

talk.start.para: I move:

speech.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Honourable senators will recall the recent enactment of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act and the States Grants (Nature Conservation) Act. These historic Acts represented the first firm evidence by an Australian Government of a co-ordinated approach to the protection and management of" this nation's natural resources. More recently, my colleagues, the Minister for Urban and Regional Development and the Minister for Environment have introduced a Bill to establish an Australian Heritage Commission. This Bill builds on these foundations. As honourable senators will know, the Government introduced a series of amendments in the other place which were the result of discussions between the Minister for Environment and Opposition representatives. Additionally, an amendment was moved by the Opposition which was accepted by the Government. The Bill which comes forward to the Senate, therefore, reflects the bi-partisan support that this Bill has.

The Great Barrier Reef, a vast collection of islands and coral reefs, extends along some 1900 kilometres of the Australian Coast. This nationally and internationally important marine ecosystem encompasses many unique forms of sea life, and is the largest and most complex expanse of living coral reefs in the world- quite possibly the largest which has ever existed. It is an area of unique beauty and of irreplaceable scientific value. Most simply, the Reef is a significant part of the world's heritage- a priceless heirloom which we must safeguard for future generations. No previous Australian Government has demonstrated the conviction necessary to act on this obvious truth. Marine ecosystems, especially the rich inshore parts, are vital to the survival of many species, including man. They are the breeding grounds and nurseries of species upon which the world's commercial fisheries depend and of many other species vital to the complex food webs of the marine environment. To ensure that marine ecosystems generally are protected in a comprehensive manner, I will be introducing a Marine Environment Protection Bill in the Budget session of the Parliament.

Only recently has the park concept been applied to the oceans, but already it has achieved world-wide acceptance as an important conservation priority. This is due partly to the realisation that man is increasingly turning to the sea to solve food shortage problems and because of concern that he is over-using the seas as a cesspool for the toxic wastes resulting from his ever increasing activities. The creation of viable marine parks is not without problems. Even so, many marine national parks have been created throughout the world. Highly industrialised Japan, one of the most populated parts of the world, for instance, had reserved 23 marine park areas by 1974. Undoubtedly the future declaration of marine parks and reserves will be difficult for most countries. Those with highly developed technologies will be torn between the desire physically to exploit the sea's resources and the demands of conservationists and re creationists for areas to be reserved. Less developed countries, particularly the small island areas, also will be torn between the desire for commercial exploitation of their offshore areas and the traditional dependence of their people on marine resources for subsistence. While the Australian Government cannot stand apart from such conflicts of interest, it has decided that protection of our unique Barrier Reef is of paramount importance to Australia and the world.

This Bill proposes the establishment of a Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority which will examine the entire Barrier Reef region, determine which sections of the region should be proclaimed as part of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park, and decide appropriate uses for its various sections. It has been prepared after extensive consultations with departments and organisations concerned with all aspects of the Reef. Once the legislation is passed the Government will be able to declare and protect zones of the Reef as national parks or nature reserves, which will then be managed by the National Parks and Wildlife Service. Other zones will be set aside for tourist development, shipping, fishing, and other appropriate uses. However, conservation and protection of the Great Barrier Reef will be the paramount aim of the Authority in all zones of" the Marine Park. The Bill specifically excludes operations for the recovery of minerals within the declared Marine Park areas except by or with the approval of the Authority for the purpose of research and investigations relevant to the establishment, care and development of the Marine Park or for scientific research.
I am sure this Bill will receive the support of all Australians who are concerned that our magnificent natural heritage should be preserved. I commend the Bill to the House.
