subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 5 June on motion by Senator Wheeldon:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: On the last day of sitting I was talking about this very significant Health Insurance Bill which is before the Senate today. It is designed to enable patients of optometrists and those people who go to ophthalmologists for refractive treatment to be afforded a benefit under the National Health legislation. Since that time, of course, Senator Wheeldon has been elevated- I think that would be the term- to a position of responsibility in the social security area. No doubt he is looking forward to the headaches that this responsibility will create for him and if he has any as the no pic symptoms that may be attributed to refractive causes I would be available for him for a consultation. But I do not think the problems will be refractive; I think he is going to have problems that are far more difficult to deal with than that. I believe that no health scheme is complete or can be considered to be universal until all areas in the field of health care are recognised.
Quite right.

I am glad to see the Minister for Social Security (Senator Wheeldon) acknowledging that statement. As I said last week, it has been a long time since the optometrists started their campaign to get recognition for their patients. At last their desires have been brought to fruition. But, as I started to say earlier. This Bill has opened the door for the inclusion in the health scheme of all other professions working in the field of health care. I refer particularly to preventive dentistry. I recognise that when the Gorton Government was administering this country we did take a step in the direction of dental care by introducing a benefit for special oral surgery. I think that preventive dentistry is a must as far as the Government health scheme is concerned. Perhaps physiotherapy, chiropody and, ultimately, chiropractic treatment, when it attracts some sort of recognition throughout Australia, might be included in the health scheme.
I think you will find some problems there which do not apply to optometry.

I should think so. Nevertheless, I mention that in passing because 1 know some chiropractors do have the regard of the medical profession. In the private area, the profession of hearing consultants also has been neglected. I believe that hearing aid consultants ought to accept the challenge to provide a technical course of study for their students who wish to pursue that career. They ought to aim to be included in the health legislation of the various States in a similar way to optometrists. From time to time orthotist have been mentioned. The orth optic profession is not registered in each State, and orthotist are required to work under the supervision of an ophthalmologist or an optometrist. The position has been described in a paper by the New South Wales Crown Solicitor. It refers to the New South Wales Act and mentions the penalties. 1 will read the whole section. Section 24 (2) of the New South Wales Act prohibits persons other than registered optometrists from -
Which Act was that?

New South Wales Optometrists Act. I will give the Minister specific details later so that he will have a chance to study them. It prohibits persons other than registered optometrists from practising or pretending to practise optometry. However, certain savings are affected by section 24 (3), which provides:

continue.para: Subsection (2 ) of this section shall not be construed to-
I will not read (a) and (b) -
(c) prevent a person from carrying out orth optic treatment under or upon the prescription, direction or reference of a legally qualified medical practitioner or registered optometrist.
That subsection clearly defines the role of. orthotist as work under the supervision of an optometrist or an ophthalmologist.

talk.start.para: Do you think orthotist should be able to practise independently?

My attitude- I think it would represent the attitude of our Party- is that certain benefits ought to apply to orth optics, similar to benefits for physiotherapy. We believe that sustained physiotherapy treatment as a result of an accident, cerebral thrombosis or similar condition ought to be recognised under the Act and that patients in that category ought to be provided with some extra benefit at this time. I think I could say that our Party would support the idea of extending the benefits to cover protracted orth optic treatment due to some trauma affecting the eye muscles which requires persistent eye exercises.

I do not want to prolong the debate, but how can we tie in this treatment if orthotist are not able to practise independently but must practise under the supervision of an optometrist or ophthalmologist?
Orthoptists are independent in terms of their ability to charge and maintain their practice. They operate only on referral.

That is the way we would like to see it. The Government may be presented with that problem and I draw it to the Minister's attention. I would like to say how much 1 have appreciated the assistance given to me by members of the Opposition's Health and Social Security Committee. I mention my colleagues Senator Baume, Senator Sheil, Senator Guilfoyle, Senator Drake-Brockman, Senator Marriott and Senator Townley, all of whom have participated in the formulation of our ideas and our attitude to this Bill. They have all heartily supported the inclusion of optometric benefits in the health scheme.

continue.para: The Opposition is concerned, of course, as no doubt the Government will be, that this provision should not be over utilised. I demonstrated in my speech last Thursday night, that the optometric profession also is concerned to see that practitioners do not over utilise this benefit. The Liberal-National Country Party Opposition will be watching this very closely to ensure that the practitioners concerned continue to act responsibly in the interests of the patient and in the interests of the taxpayer who will have to foot the bill. If there is any abuse of this scheme we are determined to have a look at it and to rectify it when we return to government.

talk.start.para: That will be a long time.

I was going to suggest at the next general election, Mr Minister. By the same token, if there appears to be any weaknesses in the measure that we are discussing we shall be anxious to rectify them when we are in government soon. If there are any anomalies in the short term before the next election, I shall be pressing the Minister for Social Security, and, knowing how co-operative he is, I believe that he will recognise anything that I point out as being an anomaly and will do something to rectify if. In conclusion, I thank the President of the Australian Optometric al Association, Mr Ley, his vice-president, Mr Layland, his executive director, Mr Damien Smith and Mr Malcolm Miller and Mr Charles Wright of South Australia, as well as members of the Royal College of Ophthalmologists who have been very helpful to me in my consideration of the Bill before the Senate. I look forward to the continued cooperation between the professions of ophthalmology and optometry in the interests of their patients to ensure that the patients in Australia will get the best possible eye care in the future.

It is with pleasure that I follow our optometric al colleague opposite in supporting the Health Insurance BUI 1975. It is also with pleasure that I note that the new Minister for Social Security, Senator Wheeldon, is handling this Bill now in his own right rather than on behalf of anyone else. This Bill, as Senator Jessop has told us, amends the Health Insurance Act 1973 and includes under the health insurance scheme benefits for patients of optometrists. This, as is known, has been a policy of the Labor Party for some time and covers a gap which existed in the health insurance scheme which worried many patients and which caused great confusion among the patients who, at times, went to optometrists and at times went to ophthalmologists. I think it is perfectly justified because, as Senator

speech.para: Jessop has told us, refraction and the correction of sight difficulties is an important part of health care in this country.

The relationship between the medical profession and the optometric al profession in this country has not been a very happy one at times, particularly at the official level. I, with others, have for many years been disturbed at this lack of harmony. I remember some years ago being at a meeting of the Australian Medical Association when an attempt was made to have medical practitioners ostracise or ignore the presence of optometrists and refer all their patients to ophthalmologists at all times for all purposes. I believe that this policy was always an impractical one and it was particularly noted to be impractical by us who practised medicine in country or non-metropolitan areas. The ophthalmologists, the medical specialists- there are some 500 of them, I believe- like other medical specialists in this country have tended to congregate in the large metropolitan areas and to have been in very short supply in non-metropolitan areas and in small country towns, whereas the optometrists, of whom there are 1,000 or more, have been spread more evenly throughout the country. It has been very difficult at times for doctors practising in rural areas to have patients' refractions done and patients' visual defects corrected by ophthalmologists, who frequently live a long way away.

Therefore, from the point of view of economics for the patient and convenience for the patient, doctors in rural areas have tended to cooperate very much with optometrists and to send patients to optometrists for ordinary corrective services. Of course, this has been possible because the members of the optometric al profession generally have shown themselves to be efficient, to be ethical in their behaviour and to be concerned about advances and further education in their own profession. Since the early part of this century they have been accepted as professionals, and careful professionals at that, by the patients and by the population of this country, and they are continuing to be accepted in that way. I believe that the optometric al profession has been very careful to maintain its high standards of ethics and practice in the community, and I must say that its actions in dealing with the public, the media and the various political parties and departmental officers in this community have been very different from the actions of some members of my own profession. The members of the optometric al profession have not used the histrionics and the hypocrisy that we have seen sometimes from members- I must say that I think it is a minority of members- of my own profession. For instance, optometrists have accepted the concept of an independent fee fixing tribunal for the purposes of this Bill, and they have accepted the need to provide care for pensioners without burdening the pensioners with great costs on top of what is provided in this Bill.

Concern has been expressed by many people in the community, as well as by Senator Jessop, that the provisions of this Bill should not be abused, that over-use of the provisions for extra consultations each year for certain conditions should not be abused. I know that some ophthalmologists and others were rather concerned that the Bill should be more restrictive in this regard and that there should be introduced regulations which would restrict more carefully the number of consultations allowed. However, I believe that the behaviour of optometrists in the past and the guarantees that they have given to the Government for the future will mean that they will not abuse the provisions of this Bill. But I warn optometrists that I will join with Senator Jessop in condemning them if they do so. However, they have shown themselves to be responsible people and to be concerned about the patient and the reputation in the community of their profession.

Senator Jessopmentioned that this Bill may be the start for widening the scope of health insurance in this country to include other professional groups, and I daresay that over the years, as people come to realise that this country can afford, and that the people deserve, to have universal health care in the fullest meaning of that phrase, some of these other professions will be included. Honourable senators on both sides of the chamber have been concerned that some patients, particularly those with cleft palates, should have the benefit of ort hod ont al treatment which is essential to their care. We have been working hard to have this benefit introduced, and we hope that a satisfactory arrangement for its introduction soon will be brought into the Parliament. I believe that the difficulty with chiropractors always has been and always will remain not so much that the medical profession is opposed to chiropractic but that chiropractors cannot agree among themselves on who is a chiropractor and who is not. Almost every attempt in this country, including one in Tasmania and to a lesser extent one in Western Australia, to register chiropractors has tended to fall down because chiropractors argue among themselves and will not set up professional standards which everyone can apply. I hope that the new inquiry by the Australian Government into the chiropractic profession will bring chiropractors together and help to sort out these problems so that chiropractors can arrive at a proper scientific basis for their profession and open up the methods of their profession to scientific scrutiny. Until we can see that their results are what they and some of their patients claim them to be I feel sure that no one in this community can contemplate the registration of chiropractors and the payment of health benefits to chiropractors.

talk.start.para: Some of their patients are doctors, are they not?

I accept that. 1 accept that some of their methods are probably very good, just as some of our methods are good and perhaps some are not so good, but until there is a proper analysis of their methods we will not get anywhere. I am pleased to see this Bill go through the Parliament. I am sure that members of the Australian Optometric al Association are even more pleased to see this Bill go through. They have been haunting the portals of this Parliament for the last 3 weeks waiting for this Bill to come up in the Senate and for it to be debated. I am sure they have had an interesting time. I am sure they have been well entertained. Unfortunately the Bill did not quite go through the Senate on Thursday night but I am assured by Senator Jessop, Senator Baume and by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Wheeldon) that the BDI will go through the Senate today. I commend the Government for bringing in this Bill. I commend the Opposition for not opposing it. I certainly do not oppose it. I welcome it as a fulfilment of another policy of this Government and of this Party. It will be welcomed, I am sure, by all patients of optometrists, ophthalmologists and doctors everywhere.

The Senate is debating the Health Insurance Bill 1975 which aims to give health insurance benefits to patients of optometrists. The Bill in fact concerns all the helping professions the medical profession, the paramedical profession and all the groups which make up what we now call the helping professions. The Bill represents a major departure in health insurance practice in a couple of ways. For that reason it is worth examining the Bill, what it proposes and also having a look at what the optometric al profession has agreed to.

speech.para: It is a major new step in the provision of benefits and we have indicated that the Opposition will support the measure. I support the remarks of Senator Jessop who set out in some detail the training and professional status of optometrists. I do not intend to traverse that ground again. We are discussing patients and whether people who need professional help are going to get it and whether they are going to get help of good quality and competence. I accept the competence of optometrists in their own area of practice and the role they have to play. I see no reason why their patients should not receive benefits under the health insurance scheme.

The policy which the Australian Labor Party is implementing in this Bill is different from the policy proposed by the Opposition in only a couple of ways, but it is worth mentioning what these are. For a start, the Opposition was aware that the practices of ophthalmic surgeons and optometrists overlapped particularly in the area of" refraction and it had been proposed by the Opposition that benefits should be paid to patients of optometrists for these services where overlapping existed. So the wording of our policy was that benefits be paid to patients of optometrists for those non-medical refractive services normally rendered by optometrists. The Government has elected to extend the provision of benefits more widely and it has brought in the further question of overlapping where the practice of optometrists, for example, will overlap that of orthoptists. I will come back and mention that briefly later. Secondly, the Opposition proposes that there should be some limit on the number of services rendered annually and again the Government has elected not to follow that proposal. But most importantly there was nothing in the Opposition's policy to indicate that the arrangement would bind the profession. There was nothing to indicate that we were to have, had the Opposition policy come in, a participating profession.

The Government's proposals, on the other hand, have broken entirely new ground because for the first time we have a profession which has elected to participate as a profession and, as a profession, to accept the concept of bulk billing. This is a major departure. The optometrists have decided that they as a group will embark on a road which other professions have viewed with considerable reserve and concern. Benefits are to be paid only to patients of participating optometrists. These matters are set out in clause 8 of the Bill which refers to the common form of undertaking which is to be drawn up after consultation with the Australian Optometric al Association. The common form of undertaking is to include, among other things, the kinds of services and assurances by optometrists that the fees they charge will not exceed the appropriate fees specified. The common form of undertaking also contains an assurance by optometrists that when asked they will give to eligible pensioners or members of low income groups, or dependants of such persons, the right of assignment of benefits. So in the common form of undertaking we have an agreement that it will be a participating profession and an agreement that there will be an assignment of benefits- that is to say bulk billing of the Government in respect of patients by the optometrists who take part. There is an interesting part of clause 8 which says:

quote.para: The Minister may, at any time, after consultation with the Australian Optometric al Association, vary the common form of undertaking.

speech.para: I would like the Minister for Social Security (Senator Wheeldon) to assure us that should there be disagreement with the Australian Optometric al Association he would not proceed to vary the common form of undertaking because, as I read the Bill, particularly the words of clause 8 (3), the Minister is under no obligation to heed the views of the Australian Optometric al Association at any time should he wish to vary the common form of undertaking. He may care to give me assurances on this matter. I am sure he has been following it and can answer me in regard to that point.

The medical profession has been particularly concerned, as a profession and as a participating group, about the implication of assignment of benefits. The medical profession, unlike most other professions, has had experience of participating schemes. Its experience in the pensioner medical service and the repatriation service have led it to have some reservations about the procedures adopted by governments for the updating of benefits and of the use of tribunals by governments. We are seeing an experimental situation whereby a profession is setting out to do something it has never done before. It is placing considerable trust in the Government and in the new Minister for Social Security. It is trusting that he and the Government will play fair in regularly updating benefits and ensuring that the kinds of complaints which followed the activities of tribunals under the pensioner medical and repatriation services will not be repeated with regard to the practice of optometrists and the provision of optometric al benefits. It is reasonable to draw upon the experience of the past in this kind of scheme in suggesting that problems could lie ahead.

I want to refer again to the question of orthotist and remind the Senate that there are 174 orthotist in Australia, mostly in private practice. Most of them operate independently, to answer the Minister's question earlier, although they act only on referral. Many of them have their services -

talk.start.para: That really is what I meant by my interjection.

Yes, they are independent in that sense. Some of them are situated in close proximity to ophthalmic surgeons or optometrists but they still operate independently. Their concern is that there is a new situation of overlap. A patient who receives orth optic services from an optometrist now will be eligible for a rebate whereas the same patient seeing an orth opt i st will not attract any rebate for equivalent care and equivalent services. In Australia we have quite a good number of orthotist per head of population- more than in the United Kingdom in fact- and there is quite a role for them to fulfil. It was estimated in Cardiff in the United Kingdom as a result of a survey that, for example, about 7 per cent of children under the age of 5 years have muscle abnormalities requiring orth optic care. I simply remind the Minister that orthotist in the 2 & years training they do, spend about 1750 hours learning orth optics alone while their optometric al colleagues, who are also trained in orth optics, spend about 150 hours training in that same field of practice. I am not suggesting in anyway that there is anything wrong with orth optics being practised by optometrists. I am simply saying that the orthotist are a well qualified group.
They are not registered, though.
Senator Jessop draws attention to the fact that they are not registered. A register is kept by the Australian College of Ophthalmologists of people whom it recognises as orthoptists
Senator Jessop's point is valid. We have a particular problem with people who are not registered under law, do we not? That problem does not arise with optometrists.

Minister, I should like to see you take the initiative and seek to do something about this situation. Otherwise we may have a situation in which a very valuable profession may find itself in a non-viable position.
But would you not agree that as it stands at the moment, with the registration being in the hands of the States, the Federal

interjection.para: Government is in a very difficult position in trying to pay benefits to people who have no registration, who have no legal recognition in the way that optometrists have?

talk.start.para: I accept that. I point out to the Minister that a register is kept by the Australian College of Ophthalmologists. I think it should be relatively simple to have the States look at the question of extending registration to orthoptists. We will want to see a regular and fair review of benefits under the scheme to be introduced by this Bill. We hope also that the optometrists will confine the bulk of their services to non-medical refractive services, the kind of thing which they do so well and for which 1 for one have sought their help in the past when I have needed new spectacles. I remind the Senate that the optometrists themselves were involved in a survey which established the relative frequency of first, second and third visits. Figures are available suggesting that 35 per cent of optometrists' patients require a second visit and 9 per cent of their patients require a third visit. There are figures available which will be used as a yardstick against which to measure future utilisation of optometric al services. In taking part in this survey, perhaps optometrists have created a rod for their own backs. If third and subsequent visits come to exceed 9 per cent of total visits, the baseline figure, by any significant amount it would be reasonable to ask the question: Why? I hope the optometrists will exert the kind of close control of their own activities which will avoid any of these questions arising in the future.

continue.para: Referring to figures which the optometrists have produced, they have indicated that a small percentage- perhaps three per cent or four per cent- of patients going to them have significant pathology. I am aware, for example, that most optometrists if they see patients with pathology refer them immediately for medical care. But since the consequences of delay in referral can be so catastrophic in matters affecting vision, I hope that the optometrists will continue to display the same high standard of ethical conduct and rapid referral to which we are accustomed. I hope that there will be regular evaluation of the use of services by optometrists. I hope that we will have made available to us the number of services rendered by optometrists each year, the cost and the breakdown of first, second, and third visits- particularly third and subsequent visits- so that we can see the amount of utilisation and what is happening to the cost of these services in the community.

I repeat that this is not just a Bill concerning optometric al benefits; it is our first experiment in which one profession has elected as a group to become participating, to lose its right to charge independent fees and to accept completely the bulk billing principle. The profession is getting what it asked for. It is getting from the Government what it agreed to accept. We support the Bill on that basis. But it is still unlike what we would have offered. We would not have demanded that the profession be a totally participating group or that it utilise the bulk billing mechanism on a compulsory basis if members wished to be in the scheme. We have yet to determine whether this road down which the optometrists have decided to walk is as rocky as other professions fear it is. They have a view that it is a primrose path. Only time will tell whether this is correct. We have yet to determine the true costs and benefits of this scheme. We will watch annual reports closely. We support the Bill. We are in favour of the benefits which will come to the patients of optometrists. I finish by making the brief observation that all too often we talk about optometrists and assume that the benefits flowing to them are necessarily in the best interests of patients in the same way as we sometimes worry about how much the doctors get and assume that that might be in the best interests of their patients. Whether the patients will be better off may be a completely different matter. It is a situation which we will watch independently and closely.

talk.start.para: This Health Insurance Bill has been discussed at length and without any dissent, and it is not necessary for me to go further into the aspects of the discussion. I rise mainly to further sow the seed for the expansion of the national health scheme. At the outset I congratulate the Minister for Repatriation and Compensation (Senator Wheeldon) on his second reading speech which was most explanatory. It was in line with the philosophy of the Medibank legislation. This legislation is designed to provide an important system of health benefits. The proposal was discussed with the Australian Medical Association and the Australian College of Ophthalmologists. The interests of all parties were well protected. I think that is a state of affairs for which we should be very grateful to the Minister. He has been able to introduce this legislation after it was originally thought some pitfalls were in the offing. He is to be congratulated on that happy state of affairs.

speech.para: I think the Government and the Australian Optometric al Association are also to be complimented for the part that they have both played in putting their cases. As a result of that, unanimity has been reached between all members of that section of the profession which I think will stand the Australian public in very good stead. The more comprehensive a national health scheme can be, the better for the community. This is a most commendable Bill. As I see it, the main aspect of the Bill is that the Government recognises the special arrangements which will be made in relation to persons living in isolated areas.

I said that I rose in this debate mainly in connection with the expansion of the national health scheme. It is necessary that any national health scheme should be all-embracing. When Senator Jessop was speaking the Minister made a statement in connection with chiropractors. He suggested that there could be some difficulty in that field. For a national health scheme to be a national health scheme it is incumbent on Government to see that people are protected against every ill. It is an impossibility for people to determine the illness with which they might be inflicted. It is an impossibility for people to determine in what type of accident they might be involved and what the result of that accident will be. So when the Government says that it is necessary to have a national health scheme include medical, hospital and now optical aspects, it is also necessary for that Government to ensure that the Bill is all-embracing. I can speak with some conviction as one who owes much to the profession of the chiropractor.

As we have advanced a further stage by admitting optometry to the national health scheme I would like to see an advance to yet a further stage whereby dentistry, chiropractic and other professional occupations in the health field are included to make it an overall Bill. A fundamental of any national scheme is that it should apply to all concerned and the fundamental of this national health scheme is that it should create equality and equity as between all members of the community. Some members have to see a medical man, others have to see a dentist, an optician or a chiropractor and others have to be inmates of hospitals. This scheme has been dubbed as a national health scheme and it is necessary therefore to maintain an equality between people who by way of general taxation pay for the national health scheme to ensure that they are covered in respect of any malady with which they may be inflicted. It is a wrong state of affairs that a person can consult a medical practitioner and get relief from the national health scheme and cannot receive similar consideration when requiring specialist attention of a chiropractor, not being able to get that benefit under the national health scheme. If there is one aspect of this matter that should apply definitely, it is that full equity should apply in all forms of taxation and in all forms of rating. It is definitely wrong that in our community today people who require the services of a professional chiropractor are not covered under the national health scheme and it is just as bad for people not to be able to claim as a taxation deduction fees paid to a chiropractor.

Equity is everything. The law of equity is the greatest law we have, but it is not applying in this instance. While congratulating the Minister for having brought in this further extension of the national health scheme I would appeal to him to have a very close look at further extending the scheme so that we may have a health scheme which is truly national. I congratulate the Minister on the part that he has played in introducing this Bill. I thank him for the way in which he presented it and I look forward to having him look at the possibility, as I know he will, of further extending the Bill so that there may be that equality applying to all members of the community which is desired in a national- I stress the word 'national'- health bill.

talk.start.para: in reply- I thank all honourable senators who have taken part in this debate and I appreciate the support which has been given to the Bill by members of the Opposition. I think it is appropriate first of all to make some comment on the remarks that were made by Senator Bunton. I certainly share with him the desire that a national health service should be a fully comprehensive national health service. This means naturally that if people require treatment other than that which is given by medical practitioners or optometrists the scheme could well be extended to include many other fields. However, chiropractors- and there are some other people who fall into the same sort of category as chiropractors, that is to say, osteopaths and naturopaths- are in a somewhat different position from that of optometrists. Whatever arguments there may have been about optometrists from members of the medical profession, there could not be any argument that optometry is a rigidly scientific discipline following the established empirical methods handed down through the years which are known as scientific method.

speech.para: One of the difficulties of practices such as those of chiropractors, osteopaths and naturopaths, as I understand it, is that the assumptions on which they base their practices are not those that could be described, in the strict sense of the word, as scientific, but there are certain premises which they bring to their fields which it would be difficult to refute or confirm. They are not, in the strict sense of the word again, scientific disciplines. That is not to say that they, particularly chiropractors, have not obviously brought about tangible benefits to certain people who have received their services. I think it is quite well known that a number of medical practitioners do on occasions refer their patients to such people as chiropractors for attention. The difficulty- and this also applies to orthotist- is that they are not legally registered except in Western Australia where there is a Chiropractors Registration Board, but even in that State there are difficulties owing to the fact that there are now, apparently, 2 associations both claiming to represent chiropractors, each disclaiming the validity of the other's qualifications. At present the Department of Health is engaged in a study of chiropractic and I know that Senator Bunton and other honourable senators will be interested to learn what the Department of Health concludes about this subject, but until that is done I certainly would not be in a position to give any undertaking.

I have noted for a long time the interest which Senator Jessop has taken in this question. We all know that he is an optometrist by profession and, if I may say so, he and I on occasions have formed something of a united front on the part of optometrists against some of our colleagues on both sides of the chamber. We are pleased that the Australian Optometric al Association has come to this agreement with the Australian Government. Certainly optometry is one of the most important paramedical fields of activity and a great many Australians already take advantage of the facilities that are provided by optometrists. Doubtless there are many more who could be making more use of optometrists than is being made at present. One of the purposes of a national health scheme and of introducing this Bill which is now before the Senate is to see that people who in the past felt themselves precluded for financial reasons from consulting optometrists are able to do so.

It is very gratifying that the Australian Optometric al Association has taken such a reasonable attitude and has been able to come to agreement with the Government on the question of bulk billing. One thing which I would like to say about optometrists is that from my studies of their qualifications, which I confess I have only made over the past year, I think it has been most unfair that they have not been given greater recognition in the past. There have been exchanges in the Press between Associate Professor Hollows, the Chairman of the Department of Ophthalmology at the School of Surgery in the University of New South Wales who, I think it is fair to say, has had some quite derogatory things to say about optometrists, and Professor Lederer, to whom Senator Jessop referred, who is head of the School of Optometry at the University of New South Wales.

One instance in one university, which was drawn to my attention, which struck me as a most anomalous situation, occurred because of the ethics of ophthalmologists, that an ophthalmologist should not give lectures to students of optometry. Because they do not give lectures to potential optometrists, some ophthalmologists have been saying that optometrists are not properly qualified because they have not received any teaching from ophthalmologists. Yet we find at the same time that within the department of ophthalmology in the same university, optometrists are lecturing to students of ophthalmology. This is a most ridiculous situation and an example of a rather unfortunate sort of a closed shop approach to learned professions. If this Bill does nothing else, if it can do something to remedy this sort of situation I think it will be of great advantage, because optometrists are very highly qualified. One of our audience today, for example, holds the degree of Doctor of Philosophy in optometry, and certainly someone who holds those qualifications from one of the leading Australian universities cannot be regarded as being other than a man very eminent in his profession.

I do not wish to prolong the matter unduly, but some questions have been asked of me by Senator Jessop to which I would like to refer. The first question to which I would come is a question he asked me with regard to the specifications of optometrists ' premises. Proposed new section 23a (2) (b) in clause 8 of the Bill, which deals with this matter, does not mean that the Minister can determine the plan of consulting rooms and facilities that should be provided by participating optometrists. The Minister would not want to do this in relation to the premises of optometrists or medical practitioners. In fact, the relevant clause does not mean that he can do that. As was pointed out in the second reading speech, regard will be had in the common form of undertaking to the fact that a participating optometrist may be a person or a company employing optometrists. In such cases the participating optometrist providing optometric al services at a number of practice locations may wish to enter into an undertaking in respect of only some of those locations. The locations to be covered by the undertaking will be specified in the undertaking, and the specification will merely list the addresses of each place of practice to be covered by the undertaking. This is very largely for the convenience of the optometrist himself and I think it has no significance other than that.

Senator Jessopdrew attention to the statement that provision should be made for other low income groups. He wished to know what was actually meant by that. It was said, when the Government's proposals were first introduced, that in the case of people benefiting from the pensioner medical service low income earners and similar people covered by the present subsidised health benefits arrangements we plan to enter into arrangements with optometrists under which consultations are provided free of charge to the patient. I think that Senator Jessop quite properly asked the question, because under the Health Insurance Act there is no specific provision for low income persons similar to the subsidised health benefits provisions of the National Health Act. Eligible pensioners, that is people who are eligible to receive the pensioner medical service, and their dependants are the only group for which special arrangements are envisaged to enable medical services to be provided at no direct cost to the pensioner.

Because of problems of identifying eligibility and other low income groups solely for the purposes of the optometric al consultations benefits, and because of possible anomalies if some persons are entitled to optometric al but not medical services free of charge, this question was deferred. It was considered that the most appropriate course would be to provide under the common form of undertaking for free optometric al consultations for eligible pensioners and dependants as defined in the National Health Act and for any other low income groups subsequently agreed to between the Australian Optometric al Association and the Australian Government. So nothing will be inflicted on optometrists. In due course, once the scheme is operating, we will doubtless have consultations which may be initiated by us and which may be initiated by optometrists at which we can arrive at some mutually satisfactory definition.

The Australian Optometric al Association has agreed in principle with the requirement that participating optometrists accept the assigned benefits in full payment for most services to eligible pensioners and dependants and to any other agreed low income groups. The undertaking to be signed by optometrists will make reference to this. However, at the commencement of the benefit arrangements and until agreement is reached on any other low income groups, eligible pensioners and dependants will be the only persons entitled to optometric al consultations at no direct cost to themselves. It is hoped, of course, that participating optometrists will also choose to direct bill for other patients.

Another matter which was raised by Senator Jessop was the special arrangements provided for isolated areas- those areas in which there is no optometrist in practice. Clause 18 of the Bill seeks to insert a new section 129A, which would empower the Minister to make special arrangements. The provision flows from the present practice in Australia whereby a number of optometrists, who have been referred to as 'visiting optometrists', visit outlying areas periodically. Higher charges necessarily have been made to offset the additional costs involved, and this of course is one of the many burdens that people living in isolated areas have to suffer. Because of the requirement under the benefit proposal that the fees charged by participating optometrists be no higher than the negotiated schedule fees it is considered necessary that special arrangements be made to ensure the continued provision of such services on a satisfactory basis without higher charges to the persons living in isolated areas.

Because of the wide variations in the existing arrangement and the need for more detailed information in relation to individual visiting optometrists, the clause provides in broad terms for the Minister for Social Security to make special arrangements as necessary in relation to the provision of such services. It is considered that the most suitable approach would be along the lines of payments outside of the benefit arrangements to participating optometrists approved for the purposes of these arrangements that are designed to reimburse all or an agreed proportion of the reasonable expenses applicable to rural visits. Per capita payments appear to be impracticable at this stage, but it is envisaged that arrangements will be made to ensure that the payments are reasonably related to the number of patients seen.

We propose that any participating optometrist who seeks to obtain payments under the special arrangement will need to apply to the Department and provide details of his practice in this regard over the past 12 months or 2 years. Information would be needed, for example, in relation to such matters as the costs incurred, the overhead expenses and so on. Consideration will then be given to the particular arrangements to apply in those cases, which will be periodically reviewed by the Department. Payment of the appropriate amounts will be made by the Health Insurance Commission. Obviously those arrangements will have to be made in consultation with the Australian Optometric al Association, as the representative of the optometrists, because it would be very difficult to lay down a hard and fast rule. In fact it would be very difficult indeed to define what is an isolated area because there may be some areas that are not strictly speaking isolated but that do not have a resident optometrist. Problems could well arise in that respect. That matter also will have to be looked into.

As far as the reviewing of fees for optometric al consultations is concerned, it was said by me in my second reading speech that the Optometric al Services Committees of Inquiry and the Optometric al Services Review Tribunals are to have similar roles and are to be established and function similarly to the Medical Services Committees of Inquiry and the Medical Services Review Tribunals already authorised by the Health Insurance Act. In relation to the review of the fees charged by participating optometrists, the Bill provides for benefits for services by optometrists who enter into undertakings with the Australian Government, one of the terms of which is that the consultation fees charged will not exceed those included in Schedule 1 of the Health Insurance Act. It is envisaged that the fees will be reviewed annually with the next review taking effect from 1 January 1976.

I come now to a matter which was raised by Senator Baume, that is, the question of the orthotist. At present orthotist are not registered under any of the laws of the country, although the practice is for them to be registered with, I think it is, the Australian Orth optic Board. Certainly the introduction of a new benefit such as this does impinge upon other areas of activity. The fact is that there are some 135 orthotist practising in Australia, according to my information, and a substantial majority of them are either employed on a salaried basis or in fact sponsored by ophthalmologists. I am not overlooking the problem that is involved here. I can see that there is a problem. But I agree with Senator Jessop, that until such time as we do have a legal registration of orthotist it is going to be very difficult to overcome some of the problems that are involved in the payment of benefits to them. But certainly I would be happy to receive any suggestions from anyone as to how these difficulties- if there are indeed difficulties can be overcome because I recognise the anomaly that is involved in some benefits being paid to some people and not being paid to others.

I do not wish to speak any longer on this measure. I hope that I have answered- I have endeavoured to do so- the questions that honourable senators have put to me during the debate. I would be most anxious to hear from them, from the Australian Optometric al Association and from any other interested person any criticisms that they may have of the operation of this aspect of the national health scheme or any suggestions that they can make for its improvement.

I appreciate that the Liberal Party has been concerned about this matter and has had various proposals as to how these benefits should be introduced. But if I might just introduce one partisan note in concluding my remarks, despite the attention which the Liberal Party has given to this matter it is in fact the Australian Labor Party Government which has brought about the introduction of the benefits. We did not just talk about the matter; we did not just study the matter; we have in fact introduced benefits for optometric al treatment within the national health scheme. I take it that the people of Australia will be aware of the role that we have played in this.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

I am sorry but I thought that I had dealt with all the points raised by Senator Baume. In fact the Minister does have power to vary the agreement and to vary the undertaking. I can give the assurance that no such steps would be taken without the fullest consultation with the Australian Optometric al Association. The Bill does make this provision which I think is necessary. It is certainly not something that we would be doing without co-operation with the Australian Optometric al Association.
