talk.start.para: The Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill 1975 has come to us from the other place. I am not sure of its track record but I think it has been before us on a number of occasions. You will remember, Mr President, that the matter with which the Bill is concerned is a matter upon which there was a division of opinion in the Joint Committee on Constitutional Review. On that occasion there was a recommendation that such a Bill be introduced. I rise simply to remind the Senate of a most formidable dissent from the recommendation on that occasion which is manifested in the record of my vote. But this really is not a matter in relation to which I have been entrusted with any responsibility on this occasion. Senator Withers who has carriage of this matter has now joined the Senate. I have said all that is important for me to say, that is, that it is a thoroughly wrong proposition that the Senate should be submerged in House of Representatives elections. We should stand on our own merits, and I hope that the Senate will support the attitude it has taken previously.

I thank Senator Wright for filling in for me and I apologise to you, Mr President, and to the Senate for not being here at the appointed time. The Opposition will oppose the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill 1975. The Bill falls into a pattern of attacks on the Senate which has typified this Government. Only 12 months ago the people rejected this proposal out of hand and I put to the Senate that the people have already had their say. They expressed their opinion on 1 8 May, I think it was, last year. Because of the hatred of the Senate by the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam), the people are again to be asked to give their opinion. I put to the Senate that this is a waste of the Parliament's time; it is a waste of the Senate's time; it is a waste of the electors' time, and it is a waste of the electors' money. We oppose this legislation because we do not believe that this wastage should occur for the second time in 12 months. We oppose this legislation because it is another attempt by the Prime Minister to destroy the Senate.

speech.para: If the referendum which the legislation proposes were passed by some freak mischance, it would effectively destroy the capacity of the Senate to act as it now does. It would be the first step towards placing all power in the hands of the House of Representatives and therefore in the hands of the Prime Minister for the time being. It would destroy the Parliament as we have known the Parliament since 1900. It is the Senate, and at present the Senate alone, which stands between the complete arbitrary power which is being sought by this Government and the individual rights and liberties of the Australian people. This Bill is an attempt to destroy the only effective watchdog, the only effective check, on the abuse of power in this country. What the Government is seeking is to bind the Constitution, and thereby to bind the Senate, to 2 terms of the House of Representatives.

Yet strangely enough the Government places no limit on the duration of the term of the House of Representatives. Conceivably, a government could go back to the people time and time again, forcing election after election, until it won control of the Senate. It could keep doing so until it destroyed the watch-dog and turned it into a rubber stamp stacked with its own unquestioning supporters. That is what the Prime Minister wants. He wants a Senate that does his bidding without question. Mr President, I put it to you and to my colleagues that he will go to any lengths to achieve it. Since this Government came to power it has been carrying on an unceasing campaign against the Senate. I think one is entitled to ask why. I answer that it is because this chamber has insisted upon its right- a right provided for it in the Constitution- to review the Government's legislation and avoid unnecessary and unfair legislation being foisted upon the people.

Whilst the Government rants and raves about obstruction, the fact is that the Senate has never used its power capriciously. Its opposition to Government legislation comes about because the legislation is either bad- because it hurts the people- or because it is a bid to keep the Government in power, which would equally hurt the people. There is not one Bill that the Senate has held up that would provide any real benefits to the people of Australia, but there have been plenty of Bills which would have disadvantaged them. In fact, far from obstructing, the Senate has helped. One need only recall when the Government tried to rush its trade practices laws through the Parliament, and the Senate, quite rightly, asked and insisted that the law be deferred pending review. What happened? The Government came back with more than 100 amendments to its own legislation. The Senate 's action allowed the Government time to discover the inequities it was about to put on the statute book. That is only one example of how the Senate has used its power responsibly. There are plenty of others.

The Prime Minister objects to the Senate having a 6-year term. The fact is that half the Senate must face the people every 3 years. Its membership is constantly up-dated. It is often more in touch with community thinking than is the House of Representatives. For example, there will be an election for half of the Senate some time within the next 12 months. The Senators who take their places here on 1 July 1976 will be more responsive to the needs of the people, more aware of the attitudes of the community, more anxious to ensure that the people's wishes are carried out and more charged with a mandate, if there is such a thing, than are the members of the House of Representatives elected on 18 May 1974. To that Mr Whitlam wishes to put an end. He wants to tie the Senate to the House of Representatives. He wants to make sure that its membership mirrors that of the Lower House. He wants to deny the people their right to express their opinion of the Government at frequent intervals. He wants a rubber stamp, a lame duck and a tame dog. In fact, he just wants to get his own way.

There is a simple way for Mr Whitlam to get the situation he wants without holding a referendum if he thinks it is so important that the elections for both Houses should be held on the same day. He could bring the House of Representatives back into step with the Senate. When the next half Senate election is due, he could take out the House of Representatives and put the fate of his Government on the line. But why does he not do that?

talk.start.para: Your leader said that the Senate should have 2 terms of 3 years.

I am not denying anything that my leader said. What I am saying is that this is an option open to the Prime Minister. 1 ask: Why does not he do that? The Opposition would not mind because we would like the

continue.para: Government to go to the polls. Mr Whitlam could do what he himself claims he wants to do, that is, let the House of Representatives serve a full 3-year term, and by that I mean a full 3-year term. But Mr Whitlam does not really want that. He wants the right to call an election when he wants it. He wants to go to the people when the climate is favourable. That is the real reason for this referendum. The Prime Minister fears serving a full 3-year term, because at the end of 3 years the Government would be as unpopular as it is now, and the Prime Minister knows it. He wants the right to go to the people after producing a popular but irresponsible Budget. He wants to con the people, make himself out to be Father Christmas and then have an election when the polls say the people like him. He wants to keep the timing in his own hands. If this referendum were carried the Prime Minister would be given that absolute right. This is another way of rigging the electoral system in Labor's favour.

The present system ensures that for Senate elections at least a part of the Parliament must face the electorate at a fixed time, and that means that governments have to be doing a good job or they pay the price. The people are given a proper chance to express their will. Prime Ministers are in part denied the opportunity to put themselves at risk in the most favourable circumstances. The people were alert to all these dangers last May. They are still aware of them. They rejected the Prime Minister's first attempt to interfere with the proper running of the Parliament and the proper method of electing its members. They will do so again. We will oppose this Bill and will vote against it. We will oppose the referendum when it is put to the people and we are certain that the people will vote against it. We are quite certain that the people of Australia have a far greater affection for the Senate, as it is constituted at the moment, than do our opponents opposite. In no circumstances will the electors of Australia see their sole watchdog taken away from them so that this Government can exercise its arbitrary, centralist, socialist power from Canberra.

talk.start.para: It is rather fitting that Senator Withers should have finished his address with one of those stereotyped cliches of which the Opposition is so fond- a reference to arbitrary, centralist, socialist powers- when he is ostensibly putting a case against a proposition which has nothing to do with centralism, socialism or the exercise of arbitrary power. The Bill is quite explicitly designed to ensure that if the Opposition in the

speech.para: Senate repeats its unprecedented and irresponsible action of May 1974 and rejects a money Bill which enables the Government to continue in power the Opposition also will have to face the electors and answer for the decision it made, as indeed the Opposition answered for its decision of May 1974- greatly, I may add, to the cost of those Opposition senators who had rejected Supply.

Senator Withers,understandably, did not really speak about the Bill at all because he does not have a valid argument to put against it. He attempted to put a case to justify the existence of the Senate. Be that as it may, that case has nothing to do with the piece of legislation which is before the chamber. He also alleged that the Senate has never abused its power. Obviously the people rejected that opinion in May of last year. The real crux of the Opposition's objection to this piece of legislation is the same as the Opposition 's objection to every electoral reform which has been put before this Senate since I became a member of it. The Opposition does not trust the people. It does not want to give the people an opportunity to elect a government or a parliament under any fair electoral system. It insists that the electoral laws be rigged in favour of its component parties and that that system be retained forever mainly of course through electoral gerrymandering to ensure that the votes of Australians have a grossly unequal value in a way that advantages the Opposition parties and in this case to retain for the Senate the right to force a government in the House of Representatives to an election through rejecting a Supply Bill without submitting the senators who forced that election to the judgment of the electors themselves. I see that Senator Bonner is amused. I daresay that Senator Bonner would be afraid to face the electors again, and in particular might be afraid to run for another pre-selection ballot in Queensland, as I understand that at least one member of the Opposition Parties from Queensland has made a significant move, for the very basest of reasons, to displace Senator Bonner from the very favourable position he occupied on the ticket.

talk.start.para: You tell us.

If the honorable senator does not know about the influence of the League of Rights on the National Country Party in Queensland- or whatever it is calling itself these days- and how the views of the League of Rights on the question of racism have been distilled through the National Country Party, he has not learnt very much in a lifetime of residence in Queensland.
Order! I ask Senator Walsh to return to the Bill.
I accept your ruling, Mr Acting Deputy President. I also accept that this is a very sensitive subject for all Queenslanders.
Order! I ask the honourable senator not to reflect on a ruling, and that is what I sense in that statement. The honourable senator will proceed with the debate.

I have not very much more to say. We are, of course, all aware of what will happen to this Bill. We are also aware, I think, that the Government can ultimately proceed to hold a referendum whether or not the Opposition accepts this Bill. I want to make 2 points: When Electoral Bills were being debated in February this year Senator Scott referred to what he considered to be a conspiracy on the part of the Whitlam Government to present to the Senate for the second time a number of Bills, the object being- according to Senator Scott- to acquire a very long list of Bills which could be used as a justification for a double dissolution. Senator Scott went on to say- I am afraid that I have not been able to locate the relevant quotation in Hansard -
How do you know he said it?

I remember it very clearly. If I have deviated substantially from what Senator Scott said, I will be very happy to withdraw it later on. What Senator Scott said is that the Government is conspiring to acquire a long list of double dissolution Bills upon which it could call an election, submit those Bills to a Joint Sitting of the Houses and thereby, according to Senator Scott, change the whole political fabric of Australia in a way which was never intended. It is pleasing to note that Senator Scott took it for granted that if there should be another double dissolution it would be followed by a Joint Sitting, following a Labor victory. It is perhaps even more enlightening to discern the underlying political morality behind that statement. What Senator Scott was really saying was that it would be totally unacceptable for a Joint Sitting of the Parliament to enact a number of Bills following an election, the subject of which was those very Bills which a Joint Sitting would enact. Senator Scott could not have put more plainly the central fact that the Opposition does not trust the people in any fair election, will not under any circumstances tolerate a fair election and will not accept the judgment of the people once it has been given.

It is a strange irony of fate that a Western Australian Australian Labor Party senator, seeking to make a pre-selection speech for next week, puts it on the line that the test should be that we should trust the judgment of the people.

I rise to order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Carrick has made a reflection against a senator. This is something which, by interjection, other senators claimed that Senator Walsh did. I ask that it be withdrawn.
What?
The reflection against a member of this Senate. If Senator Carrick wants it that way, he will get it that way.
Order! I cannot uphold the objection. I call Senator Carrick.
Senator Walsh, a Labor senator from Western Australia, invites -
I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I asked for a ruling. A reflection was made against a member of this House and I asked for it to be withdrawn.
What was the reflection?

By intervention, Senator Carrick made Senator Walsh move from the subject of his remarks and inferred that Senator Walsh had made a reflection against another senator. They were Senator Carrick 's own remarks. This has happened again and I ask you to rule in the way you did earlier in this debate, Mr Acting Deputy President.

I regret that I cannot uphold the point of order. In doing so I want to say that I asked Senator Walsh to come back to the Bill because he was quite extensively debating matters not related to the Bill. Senator Carrick has just started his remarks. He has mentioned Senator Walsh in terms of some matter of selection and, as he travels along, I shall see how far he goes from the Bill. If he moves away from the subject of the Bill to any extent I certainly shall call him to order. I call Senator Carrick.

Senator Walsh, a Labor senator from Western Australia, made the point that it is a correct principle to accept the judgment of the people. What an irony of fate that he chooses this Bill to illustrate that point because exactly 13 months ago the people of Australianowhere more strongly than in Western Australiasaid they would not have a bar of this Bill. The only people who are not accepting the judgment of the people of Australia are members of the Labor Party, including Senator Walsh. So, indeed: Physician, cure thyself.

continue.para: Let us remind ourselves of what this Bill is about. It is a Bill which seeks to resubmit to the people of Australia a proposition which they rejected resoundingly 12 months ago. That is quite clear. It is a Bill which seeks to make it compulsory forever afterwards that the House of Representatives and the Senate elections be held on the one day. Any senator coming from one of the small States who ties himself basically to this device is, indeed, in dereliction of his duty to the States. That applies to Senator McAuliffe, who is attempting to interject, and to Queensland. The simple situation is that the Australian Constitution was formed on the basis that the less populous States- Tasmania, Western Australia, South Australia in particular, and Queenslandwould only come into a Commonwealth if there were a Senate and if the constitution of that Senate were as provided in the Australian Constitution. Any senator who gets up and seeks to destroy the quality of the Senate in this way ought to be defeated in his own State.

I want to remind honourable senators what is proposed. Incidentally, the only argument that is used for the proposal is that it will save money and save time. I suggest that to save money we ought to put it on a simple basis: Two overseas journeys by the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam) equals the cost of one separate Senate election. This is the situation: It is good enough for the Prime Minister to spend his time as a peripatetic Prime Minister overseas -

talk.start.para: I rise to order. I suggest that the same ruling you made in respect of Senator Walsh should be made now in respect of Senator Carrick as he has departed entirely from the Bill before the House.
Senator Carrick, I ask you to keep within the confines of the Bill.

I will. I understand that the Minister for Agriculture (Senator Wriedt) repeatedly referred in argument to the cost of a Senate election being relevant. I was talking about the cost of an election and equating it to the cost of 2 overseas trips of the Prime Minister, and that is totally relevant. The only reason a point of order was taken was that what I was saying hurt. The Constitution is worth looking at.

continue.para: When it was written 4 sections were highly pertinent. I refer, firstly, to part II, section 7, which states:

quote.para: The senators shall be chosen for a term of 6 years . . .

continue.para: There is no question of 'or part thereof, it is for 6 years. Section 28 states:

quote.para: Every House of Representatives shall continue for 3 years from the first meeting of the House, and no longer, but may be sooner dissolved by the Governor-General.

continue.para: The first point is that the Constitution fixes a period of 6 years for the Senate and 3 years or less for the House of Representatives. Section 12 of the Constitution states:

quote.para: The Governor of any State may cause writs to be issued for elections of senators for the State.

continue.para: Section 32 states:

quote.para: The Governor-General in Council may cause writs to be issued for general elections of members of the House of Representatives.

continue.para: The Constitution sees the Senate as a States house. It says that there must be a series of 6 elections for the Senate, the writs for which are issued by the Governor of each State. Therefore the Senate should be considered quite separately from the House of Representatives.

As Senator Walsh saw fit to criticise our arguments, I remind him that the lesser populated States, notably Tasmania, Western Australia, South Australia and Queensland, have an absolutely de vested interest in this situation. All the Labor senators, including Senator Walsh, subscribe to a Party platform which seeks to abolish the Senate. If the Senate were abolished Senator Walsh's State of Western Australia would be almost unprotected in the other place. New South Wales and Victoria between them could command 79 of the 127 votes in the House of Representatives. Western Australia would be swamped. Tasmania, which has only 5 seats in the House of Representatives, would be swamped in every way. It gets a rough enough time now. What would it get if it had no recourse to the Senate? In the Senate the small States have equality with the large States. The proposition that we are considering comes from a government which seeks to abolish the Senate. What irony! A government which wants to abolish the Senate now puts in the Senate ministers with five of the major portfolios. If the Government has contempt for the Senate and wants to abolish the Senate, why do we find the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Minister for Social Security, the Minister for Labor and Immigration, the Minister for Agriculture and the Special Minister of State here? That is something that we might have explained in future.

This Bill is introduced for the reasons that my leader states. The aim is to deny to the people of Australia a mid-term election. If this Bill were law today there would not be an election for half the Senate during the next year.

talk.start.para: It would be a good thing, too.

Senator Steele Hall from South Australia interjects that it would be a good thing too. Those who have an understanding of American politics know that the people of America have come to regard the holding of mid-term elections in America as a basic way of registering an opinion of their government, whether by way of recall or review. The one chance that the people of Australia will have to register their view on the Whitlam Government at this moment will occur between now and 30 June next year when they will have the opportunity to vote at an election for half the Senate, unless some other event of major importance supervenes.

continue.para: The aim of the Government's proposal is to destroy that opportunity; the aim is always to twin the two together so that the Senate becomes a mirror image of the House of Representatives. I wonder if those honourable senators who interjected would want the Senate to be a mirror image of the House of Representatives? If it were so, if it were always so, and the Senate were simply a reflection, then of course there might be an argument for the claim that the Senate would be redundant. The one way in which there can be a Senate which is independent and which reflects more readily the views of the people than the House of Representatives does at times is to have from time to time a staggering of the elections. That is what is happening now. The Senate, by having a half Senate election in the course of the next eight to ten months will be more contemporary in its outlook and more contemporary in registering the vote of the people than will be the House of Representatives. After all, it should be understood that the Senate is elected by compulsory, general, universal franchise of the people in exactly the same way as the House of Representatives and therefore gets a mandate of its own. It gets a particular mandate; it gets a special mandate from the smaller or less populous States. The people of those States can speak out on that occasion and assert themselves.

This is indeed what the Government is now seeking to stop. This Bill seeks simply to ensure that in the future the Senate will not be allowed to be other than a rubber stamp. That having once before been put to the people of Australia, the people of Australia said: 'We do not want the Senate to be a rubber stamp. We want the Constitution to carry on as it has before. We want the right of the Senate to have separate elections midterm elections, if that be- to persist. We do not want a compulsory twinning. We want the Senate to have an independence of its own, to have a character of its own and not to be destroyed'. This is what this debate is about. It is utterly pertinent that this debate should occur in this atmosphere- an atmosphere where the importance of the small States is very much before the Australian public, as it is today. In common with my Leader, I reject this legislation.

talk.start.para: At least the Opposition Parties are consistent in their view on electoral matters, and that is to oppose all electoral alterations and changes which are suggested and which they have not made themselves. Whether or not merit exists for the proposals, they are to be opposed. One is not of course to take the Opposition's argument seriously. If one did take it seriously one would become very exasperated trying to find any logic in the disjointed opposition which is put to this and other proposals. I notice however that the spokesmen for the Opposition are generally very smart with little phrases. In relation to another Bill- a redistribution Bill- but particularly to the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill, there are 3 phrases which have come through. They are: 'mirror image', 'map makers' and 'compulsory twinning'. I suppose all of those phrases sound very erudite, very learned, but their use is only a fancy cover-up for a lack of logic and a lack of principle.

Senator Withersnever fails to repeat his performance, and never disappoints if one is expecting to find the lowest of all approaches to the electoral question. He simply approaches the question by asking: 'Who's gonna win?' That is all that worries Senator Withers. He does not worry about any principle; he does not worry about the principle of where the Australian people stand on this matter. He just confuses the issue and asks: 'Who's gonna win?' The only thing one must get from the other end of the microphone on the amplifier side is that Senator Withers does not think that he is going to win under the change. This is about the only logic that comes out of his continued opposition to the fairest of all proposals- because it is the fairest of all proposals that the Houses should be in phase in elections.
Did the people reject it?

I am pleased that Senator Baume has interjected on the side of instability in Australian politics. The people did reject this matter at the election caused last year by the Opposition when they cut right across what Senator Carrick said about having Senate elections every 6 years. Senator Carrick voted against 6-year Senate elections as the pragmatic method of forcing aU senators to stand for election last year, regardless of their 6-year term. So I do not know why Senator Carrick argued for a 6-year term; he voted against it. I make those comments by way of answer to Senator Baume 's interjection.

continue.para: The situation has changed dramatically since the election last year. Following the election the then Leader of the Opposition said, as honourable senators know very well, that he did not lose the election, he just did not get the numbers. From then on, week after weary week, he threatened Australia with yet another election. There could not have been a more unstable political situation than that which existed in Australia following the double dissolution last year. The public of Australia got thoroughly fed up with the instability in Australian politics. If ever there was a lesson for Senator Baume it existed in the removal of his former Leader on the very basis that he constantly threatened instability in Australian politics. The Australian public does not want instability; it does not want elections every 18 months. If the people were asked to vote again, on issues shorn of the deception which the Liberal and National Country Parties used to support their opposition to this matter last year, they would vote yes. I do not think they Will vote yes, because I think the Liberal and National Country Parties would use the same sorts of arguments again, although they will find it more difficult next time. They will not be able to cloud their opposition by a general opposition to 3 other proposals, as the issues were so clouded and generally amalgamated last year. It will be a simple question, and I should like to think that those on our side of poetics who do oppose this Bill would use honest answers, but I do not expect they will.

No doubt there are scripts remaining in a drawer in the office of some member of the media somewhere in Australia which would show the deception used last year by the Opposition in opposing the proposal, and I challenge honourable senators opposite to produce those scripts and say that they were not deceptions. They were. Senator Withers used them again today when he said that putting the elections in phase is part of an act to destroy the Senate, a part of the Prime Minister's attempt to get at the Senate, that it is wrong, after the example of the instability to which I have referred, to put the question again. The Liberal Party certainly acted in the face of a leader who would not give stability to its politics, and I suggest that the Australian public also might want to take action which will establish stability in Australian politics. There has been a very real result from the new stability that has emerged, on which the new Leader of the Opposition (Mr Malcolm Fraser) should be congratulated. He said that he will not defeat the Government by defeating the Budget, and that is a promise he made again on the weekend. So the Government knows from that public promise given by the Leader of the Opposition that its Budget will not be defeated.

talk.start.para: It has got to govern.

It has got to govern, as Senator Missen says, and it is governing better since last week. It has removed two of the greatest obstacles to sensible and decent government in Australia. They were the 2 Ministers who were replaced- the former Treasurer, who would not help govern Australia by guiding the various departments in a proper financial and managerial sense, and a Minister who would not support, actively and properly, wage indexation in Australia. The Government was able to move effectively against those Ministers simply because it knows it has a tenure of office. For an Opposition to say to a government at any time of crisis that it is going to force an election every 1 8 months is a crime against Australia.
I think we ought to object to that, Senator.

Senator Georges can object as much as he likes and I will have it out with him here or on the hustings or wherever he chooses. If honourable senators do not know now where I stand let me tell them that I am going to vote for the Bill. I thought they would have understood that from the remarks I have so far made. I can only make this plea in voting for this Bill, that the Opposition Parties will use honest arguments in the electorate in the case they prepare against the Bill and against the referendum and not the sort of arguments which they use here and which have been put forward today by Senator Withers and Senator Carrick.

Senator Hall made a plea, as I understood him, for honesty in argument and for responsibility in government. I am surprised that he should have used those arguments and announced that he will support this Bill because it is quite clear that if responsibility in government is at issue, it is the Government which is lacking in responsibility. This measure was before the people of Australia in 1 974 and the people of Australia resoundingly defeated it by a majority of approximately 250 000 votes, yet Senator Hall apparently regards that decision as of such little consequence that he feels a contrary view can be advanced and urged as the responsible course. That is not denying to him his right to put the point of view which he espouses, but I do not suggest it is a proper attitude to condemn those whose attitudes have been endorsed by the people and those who are still maintaining those attitudes. What are the arguments which have been advanced by the Government to bring forward this Bill once again? The Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam)- I imagine that he is the best exponent of what the Government's reasons are- said when he introduced this Bill for the first time in February this year:

quote.para: This Bill proposes to alter the Constitution to ensure that Senate elections are always held at the same time as elections for the House of Representatives . . . The proposal is clearly one that has great appeal to the electorate. My Government is of the view that it is of such importance and merit that it should again be put to the people.

speech.para: What is its importance? He does not state. What is its merit? He does not state it. As for it having great appeal to the people of Australia, the facts are against him. For a referendum to be carried in this country the Constitution requires that a majority of the people should support it and that a majority of States should support it. At the last election, as I have said, this proposal was overwhelmingly defeated and a deficit of some 250 000 votes is not some small margin. There was only one State in which people supported the measure and that was in New South Wales. In Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania, Western Australia and Queensland the proposal was defeated and in the last 3 mentioned States it was overwhelmingly defeated. In those circumstances how is it that the Government believes that an argument which was so devoid of merit to the Australian people is likely to prevail on a second occasion? On what justification does Senator Hall claim to be a democrat in the way in which he condemns the Opposition Parties for our apparent paucity of argument and inconsistency of argument when he ignores the fact that the Opposition's viewpoint was clearly supported by the people of Australia? I suggest that what Senator Withers said- he was supported by Senator Carrick- is an argument which clearly has merit and in terms of past results electoral backing behind it.

There is another aspect of this which is the prime reason why I rose to speak, that is, the way in which this Bill seeks to undermine the bicameral system and to weaken the power of the Senate. I refer again to what the Prime Minister said when he introduced this Bill. He said:

The intention of the men who drafted our Constitution and the expectation of those who voted for it was that every 3 years there should be an election for the House of Representatives and half the Senate.

He does not give any authority for that. He does not refer to any of the convention debates and he does not explain how it is that suddenly in 1975 he can divine an intention which is not to be found in any of the prior writings. In fact there is no such intention in the Constitution. The Senate is to be composed of members elected for a 6-year term and half the senators are to retire every 3 years. That is a fixed rule. That certainly is what the framers of the Constitution intended. They did not have any such intention with regard to the House of Representatives. In the case of the House of Representatives, all they said was that there must be an election every 3 years, but they left it on the basis that it could occur much more frequently because the Westminster system gives to the Governor-General a power to dissolve the lower House on the advice of the Prime Minister of the day. That is a practice which has grown up and has been acknowledged over the years in this country. There is no basic proposition of the character which the Prime Minister enunciated.

We in the Senate have maintained a view that the Senate should have the independence which the constitutional provisions currently give to it and which this Bill, if carried into law in the way it is framed, would deny. The Senate is an integral part of the bicameral system which the Liberal and Country Parties support. A bicameral system is supported because it enables a second chamber to review, to amend and, if appropriate, to reject legislation of the first House. It is a brake on hasty action and it is a second judgment on legislation. For these functions to be properly performed the second chamber should not be a duplicate or a rubber stamp of the first chamber. The acceptability of this approach is assisted by other things which we find in the Constitution; for example, direct election by the people on as representative a basis as the first chamber. This is secured in the case of the Senate by proportional representation on a Statewide electorate. The fact is that the Senate is as democratically elected as is the House of
Representatives and it has, subject to the Constitution, the same rights as the democratically elected lower House.

Another aspect is that there is an ability in the Senate to reject or amend Bills without being required to submit to an election unless, of course, the particular circumstances arise in which, after a 3 months lapse, the Senate reaffirms its amendment or rejection and a double dissolution occurs, as specifically provided for by the Constitution. Another aspect is that the fixed 6-year term of senators, contrasted with the term not exceeding 3 years for members of the House of Representatives, will last as long as the House itself is not dissolved. The fixed 6-year term is the distinguishing characteristic of senators and it is that fixed term which gives them the ability to exercise the functions which the Constitution gives to them without regard to the considerations which from time to time can affect the members of the House of Representatives. If these general conditions did not exist, the ability of the Senate to be an effective second chamber and more than a duplicate or rubber stamp of the House of Representatives would be seriously impaired.

Another point which can be made is that a Senate election for half the Senate every time the House of Representatives went to an election would mean that the Senate result would be likely to reflect the voting result for the House of Representatives. This may be a desirable result because it may offer the hope that the Government will not be frustrated by perpetual opposition in the second chamber. I think that is the basic reason the Government is putting this proposal forward. The Government is putting it forward because it wants to avoid, if it can, the prospect that an upper House, in its own judgment, will frustrate the legislation which the lower House has put forward. I stress that point because I think that for the greater part of the period of the Liberal-Country Party Government, certainly the last seven or eight years of such Government, it did not have a majority in the upper House, yet that Government learned to live with the fact that there was a second chamber which did not always agree with what the lower House was providing.

Nevertheless, the Government of the country was not frustrated. The Government of the country is not currently being frustrated. The Prime Minister cannot in one breath say that this has been a most productive autumn session of the Parliament and at the same time justify his condemnation of the Senate as a frustrating upper House. He cannot have it both ways. The fact is, as Senator Withers said, that no legislation which confers benefit on the people of Australia has been rejected by the Senate. The continuity of the Senate means that if a change of government in the lower House occurs the effects of that change will not be too drastic and in any event can be tempered by a Senate effectively reviewing legislation while the electorate decides whether the change is to be endorsed for a longer period.

In 1931 when, as a result of Senate action, there was a House of Representatives election, the change of Government resulting from the 1929 election was not endorsed. In 1951 the change made in 1949 was endorsed, and following the 1974 election I suggest that the people are biding their time. They endorsed the Labor Government in power in the lower House but denied to the Labor Government a majority in the upper House. It seems to me that a fair interpretation of that electoral verdict is that people are still biding their time as to whether they will give the Labor Party a complete mandate or take away the mandate which they gave it in 1972. But this breathing period can be and ought to be regarded as being a safeguard for the better working of representative democracy. But possibly the real question is whether it should be mandatory that every time there is a House of Representatives election there should be an election of half the Senate. The function of the House of Representatives as the House of government and the function of the Senate as a House of review surely indicate that it should not be mandatory.

Why should a desire for a mandate, for any one of the many reasons which may prompt it, leading to a dissolution of the House of government also involve a dissolution of the House of review? The terms for senators could be reduced to less than 18 months by penal dissolutions of the House of Representatives emanating entirely from internal differences within the House of Representatives. One can instance the events which occurred- it seems an awfully long time ago- in 1929 within 7 months of the coming together of the House of Representatives. It is unnecessary, it is expensive and it is a weakening of the Senate's independence and therefore a weakening of the efficacy of the bicameral system to require in all circumstances that every time there is a dissolution of the House of Representatives, notwithstanding the reasons which have prompted it, half the Senate should be elected too.

The present position which in political terms leads to the pressure for simultaneous elections arises from the fact that Senate elections are held at times different from election times of the House of Representatives. If it is desired to bring these together, we repeat, there is no need for a constitutional amendment. It is acknowledged that within the next 12 months, between 1 July and 30 June next year there must be an election for half the Senate under the terms of the Constitution. If the Prime Minister is only concerned to bring the House of Representatives and the Senate elections into line- without there being a constitutional mandatory provision that it should happen on every occasion into the distant future- he has a ready-made opportunity of which he can avail himself. At any time within the next 12 months when he holds the half Senate election he can hold an election for the House of Representatives. One might go further. He can hold a double dissolution election and the result which he seeks to obtain can be secured in that way.

Why Senator Hall- and I conclude on the aspect on which I started- regards that as an unsatisfactory solution or as in some way an undesirable course to follow, I am at a loss to understand. But I certainly feel that the argument against what the Government has proposed is an argument which has received the overwhelming endorsement of the people. That, for no other reason, ought to justify the stand which the Opposition is expressing today. No reason has been advanced- except unsubstantiated and detailed assertions that this is a matter of importance and of merit- to explain why within 12 months after the people have given their verdict, the matter is being brought forward again. The Government ought to explain not only to the Parliament but also to the people of Australia why this is being done. The Opposition will be consistent in its rejection.

talk.start.para: in reply- The arguments in relation to this Constitutional Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill have been canvassed quite extensively in the Parliament over the past few months, and I do not wish to go over again the points which have been raised in the general debate. It would be much better if we were to crystallise the points which have been raised during this afternoon's debate and try to analyse why the Opposition is opposing this legislation. There seem to be 2 points on which it bases its opposition. Essentially, we are told that this is a move to create centralised control in Canberra. We have arguments about the abolition of the

speech.para: Senate. This is completely irrelevant in this debate. This Bill has nothing to do with the abolition of the Senate. These are the sorts of red herrings which are drawn across the argument for the sake of confusing anyone who is listening. It seems that not too many people listen to the Senate, anyway. In fact, I look at the public gallery on this day and I find about a dozen people sitting there. If this were the House of Representatives, the gallery would be full. It seems that the average Australian does not care very much what happens in the Senate.

talk.start.para: There are four -

I did not interrupt Senator Greenwood when he was speaking. I know the honourable senator does not like it when someone argues against him, but he might extend me the courtesy of listening to what I have to say. It is said that if we were to pass this legislation the bureaucrats would rise up, centralised control would emanate from Canberra for the purpose of creating a rubber stamp, and we would be living under some form of dictatorship from the House of Representatives. But is it not a fact that for over 50 years since Federation, with the exception of 1 929, that is exactly the system which has operated? I do not think anyone would suggest that for the first 50 years of the existence of this country we lived under a dictatorship simply because the elections for the Senate and the House of Representatives were held coincidentally. Would anyone put up that contention? I am sure that if they tried to do so there is not an Australian who would believe them. Right up to 1953 it was the accepted routine and procedure that elections would be held concurrently. That is what this legislation is trying to do.

continue.para: The other point is that there should be elections for the Senate in between general elections in order to gauge more accurately the feeling of the people. How does Senator Greenwood reconcile that argument which has been advanced by the Opposition while he extols the virtue of the 6-year term which, under the Constitution, is mandatory for a senator? He cannot have it both ways. Is it not obvious that every 3 years a government ought to go to the people? Consistent with what the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Withers) has said, during this debate, reference has been made to the fact that a government ought to be allowed to exercise its mandate for that 3-year period. I think the majority of Australians want that, and that it was the point Senator Hall was trying to get across. The average Australian does not want instability in government. When a government is elected on a platform of a 3-year program it has a right to implement its policies.

The other argument is that this legislation was put to the Australian people only 12 months ago and was rejected and it should not be put up again. Twelve months ago the Australian people also rejected the Opposition by about the same number of votes. Are we to assume that the Opposition has now opted out of Australian politics and will not put itself forward at any election that may occur between now and 1977? Of course it is not opting out. I think the Government would even be prepared to withdraw the legislation if the Opposition were to give the undertaking that it was not prepared to put itself up for re-election. I am not putting that as a serious proposition, but I am drawing an analogy with the fallacious argument that is advanced that because the referendum was put to the people 12 months ago therefore it should not be put again.

The Government was asked to give one example of legislation that has been rejected by the Senate and which would have been of any value to the Australian people. I will give one example- the legislation concerning the National Investment Fund. That was one of the most forward-looking and beneficial pieces of legislation that this country has seen for a long time. It was designed to ensure the formation of capital in this country by Australians to assist the development of Australian industry. That legislation was rejected by the Liberal-Country Party Opposition. These sorts of things will continue while the Opposition adopts its present position.

Does not any political Party, whether it be the Labor Party, the Liberal Party or the National Country Party, go to an election with a specific purpose of winning a majority not only in the House of Representatives but also in the Senate? Is that a crime? The objective of any political Party when it goes to the people is to obtain that majority. Yet that is the very argument which, we are told, condemns this legislation. It is a contradiction. The whole purpose of this Bill is to bring the elections together so that the Aus.tralian people will not have to suffer successive elections which serve no good purpose either for themselves or for the Parliament. It is true that $2m is not a fortune but nevertheless that amount of money is being spent where it is unnecessary to spend it. This legislation would be good for Australia. It would take us back to the situation that obtained for over 50 years. The Australian people would want it that way and if common sense were to prevail in the Senate today that is the way they would have it.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 17 April on motion by Senator Wriedt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: This Bill which seeks to create the National Gallery is supported in principle by the Liberal and National Country Parties. It represents our on-going commitment to the arts which, in respect of a national gallery, began in August 1963. It will be recalled that in 1965, the then Prime Minister, Sir Robert Menzies, established the National Art Gallery Committee of Inquiry which was chaired by Sir Daryl Lindsay. The Committee reported in March 1966. The difficulty in siting the Gallery was one of the problems which needed to be overcome by the Committee. The Interim Council was appointed in 1968, and since them we have seen steady progress towards the creation of a national art gallery. During the 12 intervening years there has been a steady build-up in our national collection of works of art. I believe that the pursuit of excellence in visual arts at home and by our own artists living abroad has been an objective of governments during that time. For that reason we are pleased to support the Bill which creates the National Gallery. It is consistent with our own current policy on the arts in Australia. We believe in the development of an Australian cultural identity which is distinctive, but which reflects the full scope and intensity of international cultural influences and our own social and historical heritage.

speech.para: I am dealing with this Bill for the Opposition on behalf of the shadow Minister for community development, Senator Rae, who has had a great deal of interest in this Bill and has done a deal of consulting with art galleries throughout Australia and elsewhere to seek their views on the establishment which is provided for in this Bill. A Liberal-National Country Party government would provide a national stimulus to the development of the arts in all its forms. As a matter of policy, we would promote the pursuit of artistic excellence and freedom of expression in all forms of art. Equally, we would encourage the growing appreciation of the arts within the Australian community, because we believe that cultural expression and appreciation are important elements in the development of a vibrant and imaginative but cohesive society. We have an extensive policy with regard to the development of the arts in this country. Details of this policy have already been released. We see the pursuit of our objectives as vitally important and we believe that these objectives are supported in principle by the legislation which we are considering today. Our support for this legislation was given to establish the principle that practitioners of the arts must undertake the primary responsibility for artistic judgment in the disbursement of public funds for the promotion of the arts and that individual art forms, as far as possible, must be assessed and fostered in their own right and also that there must be full accountability to the Parliament for the expenditure of public funds on the arts. I believe that nothing less would be accepted by the Australian people.

One point on which Senator Rae found unanimity in the consultations which he undertook is that, if the National Gallery idea is an attempt to kill off in any way the galleries in the States and the regional centres of Australia instead of blending and making widely available all our resources and talents, then the arts will suffer, and for that the present Government will have to accept responsibility. It was of interest to us that the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam) in his second reading speech used these words:

Honourable members will be aware of my longstanding interest in a National Gallery and the Hansard record of my questions over many years stands testimony to my concern about the growth of our national collection of works of art.

We consider that in this area the Prime Minister has been somewhat inconsistent because apparently his interest has been confined to asking questions instead of to answering them. I had thought of seeking leave to incorporate in Hansard the Prime Minister's table of questions on the arts given to the right honourable member for Bruce (Mr Snedden) as set out in Hansard for the House of Representatives of 8 April, but I feel that my purpose would be served if I abbreviated the matter and simply said that the Prime Minister answered a question asked by the right honourable member for Bruce by giving a chronological record of 10 questions which he had asked since 1965 with regard to the development of the arts in this country and then went on to give further information that was requested. The most important part of the information he supplied related to Australian works of art as a percentage of acquisitions from 1969 to 1975. A table which I think is of significance shows that in 1969-70 89 per cent of our acquisitions were Australian works of art, in 1970-71 the figure was 90 per cent, in 1971-72 96 per cent, in 1972-73 82 per cent, in 1973-74 77 per cent and in 1974-75 68 per cent. These figures show that there are significant Australian works of art in the national collection, but they show some disparity between the years with a declining Australian content in the national collections, particularly in the years 1973-74 and 1974-75. The Prime Minster in his second reading speech said:

A novel feature of the Bill is that it provides for 2 statutory officers, the Director of the Australian National Gallery and the Secretary and Manager of the Gallery. The Director shall have overall responsibility to the Council for the running of the Gallery and its artistic direction, and the Secretary and Manager shall, under the Director, manage the day-to-day administration affairs of the Gallery and act as secretary to the Council.

The Prime Minister said also that this provision has been introduced to avoid the problems that have arisen so often elsewhere, where unlikely and unreasonable combinations of different expertise and experience have been demanded of the one person, usually with unfortunate results. We felt that it was necessary to pursue the Prime Minister's statement that there had been unfortunate results in the past, so we put a question to him on notice. The question and answer to it appeared in the Senate Hansard of 22 April 1975. Mr President, I seek leave to have the question and answer incorporated in Hansard.
The Presidents leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted. (The document read as follows)-

quote.para: Australian National Gallery: Statutory Offices (Question No. 506)
Senator Raeasked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice:

( 1 ) With reference to the Prime Minister's second reading speech on the National Gallery Bill 1975, in which the Prime Minister said 'This provision (of two statutory offices) has been introduced to avoid the problems which have arisen so often elsewhere, where unlikely and unreasonable combinations of different expertise and experience have been demanded of the one person, usually with unfortunate results', will he itemize the 'unfortunate results'.
(2) What are the names of all the public servants or office holders who have evidenced 'unlikely and unreasonable combinations' with 'unfortunate results' during the time of his Prime Ministership.

(3) In what particular positions within what departments or agencies do these persons now serve the Government and in what positions and for what periods within departments or agencies did they serve at the time of 'the problems'.

(4) Besides his view of the need for the provision of two statutory offices, what other steps have been and are being taken to overcome 'the problems' and by whom are these steps being taken and in what government departments or agencies.
Senator Wriedt-The Prime Minister has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question
(1) I was referring to the problems which have often arisen in galleries in some other countries and in some Australian States.

talk.start.para: The answer to the question was incomplete. It was to our way of thinking an inconsiderate reply from someone who had alleged that he had a long-standing interest in the establishment of a national gallery. So we asked a further question on notice. We received a reply to that question on 26 May. The answer to that question did not give any further information as to the Prime Minister's concern or the unsatisfactory results that had been experienced.

continue.para: There are some other comments that we want to make about an arts policy for Australia. We trust that this Bill, along with our endeavours in other areas of the arts, will stimulate creative minds in the pursuit of cultural excellence. That hope is held alongside an awareness of the fact that the function of such a gallery is largely symbolic. It seems to us that governments, past and present, in Australia have, by their secrecy in purchasing, contributed to a resistance by the people generally to the arts. If it is only possible to negotiate reasonable prices in secrecy, then what measurement do we have that this policy has been successful in terms of value and worthwhile results? We ask: Is it not time that the Government made the purchasing guidelines known to the people of Australia? We believe that would avoid some of the controversy and resentment which has been experienced in the more recent past when costly purchases of art have been undertaken on behalf of the people of Australia.

talk.start.para: Would it not be something like dealing with Budget secrets in some of these instances?

We accept that there is a need for secrecy in negotiations for the purchase of art and we understand that traditionally there is secrecy with regard to the prices that are actually paid. What we are suggesting is that the laying down of some guidelines with regard to the commissions that are given for the purchase of art on behalf of the galleries of this country would be one way in which the people would feel more fully informed about what the costs do represent when they are disclosed as public expenditure. I accept that negotiations of this kind are not dealt with publicly, but it is more in the way of what we are trying to achieve in the pursuit of excellence and balance in our collection and the effects of the public expenditure that this would need to command that has made me put forward the comment that I have made with regard to purchasing guidelines. The role of Government in Australia in the visual arts could have 3 functions. Firstly, it could have the function that was expressed by Bernard Smith in the Australian' newspaper in February of this year when he said: the National Gallery should embark upon creating a collection which is not polemic about taste but is poised to collect tested and enduring value in all areas of creative activity in the visual arts.

continue.para: That concept is something that would be important in the formulation of a national policy for the development of an art collection. I think there is time for us in this country to use that sort of approach in any future collection that we hope to establish. I think the second feature that could be taken into account is that we should take the collection to the people across Australia so that it is no longer locked up in the Prime Minister's Lodge or in Kirribilli House or in any other area where the people have a somewhat restricted opportunity to see these things.

Clauses 6 and 7 of the Bill deal with the functions and the powers of the Gallery. We welcome the fact that clause 6 (1) (b) provides that the Gallery shall exhibit or make available for exhibition by others, works of art from the national collection. Clause 7 (2) (b) provides that the Gallery shall have power to lend or hire out or otherwise deal with . . . works of art;

This approach to the matter is important having regard to the size of this country, the distances involved, and the fact that the national collection is truly something which belongs to the people and to which they should have as wide an access as possible.
The Prime Minister was asked the following question on notice by the right honourable member for Bruce (Mr Snedden):

What percentage of works of art owned by the Government which are intended to be exhibited in the National Art Gallery has been publicly displayed in Australia since they have been acquired by the Government.
On 5 December 1974 the Prime Minister stated, amongst other things, in his answer

Works of art from the Collection have, however, been included from time to time in exhibitions in State and regional galleries. They have also been displayed in official establishments in Australia such as Government House and The Lodge in Canberra, and Admiralty House and Kirribilli House in Sydney.

The display of these works of art in the official residences listed by the Prime Minister perhaps does not give the wide access to the collection that a gallery in the States or the regional centres would give. It is for this reason that I made my second point.

The third point I want to make is that the National Gallery should stimulate artists within Australia. There should also be much stimulation for the neighbourhood workshop movement as a means of creating the environment and facilities in which talent can thrive. This is very much part of our attitude towards community involvement in any of the creative expressions. We would see the visual arts as coming very much within our framework of community involvement and community development.

talk.start.para: The Government is already doing that sort of thing.

That is right. I think this is to be commended. It is very much part of the way in which the community can be enriched through the resources that are made available by government for the development of art collections and to encourage and stimulate the artists who live within this country further to develop their own talents. The approach that has been outlined in the Bill is one that essentially has our support. However, there are one or two matters to which we wish to refer and on which we seek some interpretation during the Committee stage of this Bill. But in general we welcome the Bill and the proposal which is covered by it. The Bill has the support of the Opposition Parties.

The purpose of this Bill is to establish the National Gallery of Australia in the Australian Capital Territory. I am personally disappointed that Senator Guilfoyle devoted so much of her speech to establishing the apparently new-found fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam) is not infallible when it comes to matters of the arts. But be that as it may, I think I share with her the essential views she has expressed relating to the purposes of this legislation. To establish a National Gallery in Canberra, the capital of Australia, is of course consistent with the notion of Canberra as the national capital. We already have in Canberra the national Parliament, the national War Memorial, the National Library, the Australian National University and shortly we will have the High Court. It is important that recognition of the significance of the arts in the life of Australia should be symbolised likewise by the establishment of the National Gallery in Canberra. As Senator Guilfoyle has pointed out, we have already 6 State galleries. Prior to 1 900 they were, of course, 6 colonial galleries. It has really taken us quite a long time as a nation to establish a National Gallery for Australia. In talking of those 6 State galleries, I share Senator Guilfoyle 's view that it would be most desirable if the Australian National Gallery worked very closely in co-operation with those 6 State galleries. I do not for a moment share her apprehension that in the 'Canberra-opus', which seems to be the latest successor to what used to be known by our opponents as the 'Red-opus', will fail to co-operate with those galleries and in some way will take them over.

speech.para: I think it is true to say that the establishment of the National Gallery is perhaps the most appropriate recognition of the importance of the arts in Australia and the aspirations of the Australian people to a national identity. The Gallery which is to be established is to be a body corporate and it will be presided over by a council. The functions of the Gallery are set out in clause 6 of the Bill. As we all know, already some of those functions are being performed under a very able director in Mr Jim Mollison who has acquired for Australia some very significant works of art. Although those purchases have been the subject of some criticism and some inquiry as to whether the right prices were paid and things of that kind, I think anybody who understands the field will recognise that significant steps have already been made in establishing a significant national collection.

The important point that I seek to make about the National Gallery is probably consistent with something which Senator Guilfoyle said. It is simply that by passing this legislation in the Parliament the function of the Parliament should not be seen to be at an end, but rather that we should be diligent to ensure the future activity of the Gallery not as a museum for the citizens of Canberra but as a living thing having relevance to the life of the Australian people as a whole. That, of course, involves co-operation with the State galleries. It involves travelling exhibitions and things of that kind. It involves the uses of new aspects of technology in spreading the work of the Gallery as far as possible. We can, of course, just go ahead and establish what would be another sort of national art museum in Canberra. That would be consistent with the concept of the Australian War Memorial which has been established in Canberra, but it would not be consistent with the best interests of the Australian people.

One can picture the National Gallery as a sterile institution which receives pilgrims in the form of tourists and school children and other people who pile out of their Holden cars and their Pioneer buses outside the Gallery, make a quick examination of its contents and then go away having chalked up another score in their travel itinerary. Honourable senators will probably have heard the story of the American tourist visiting the Louvre in Paris and saying to the attendant at the door: 'Quick, where is that goddamn Mona Lisa? I am double parked'. That sort of thing can, of course, happen in Canberra if the Gallery is confined to Canberra and is just a place which people visit as an institution. But the important thing, I think, is for the Gallery to use modern technology, the developments in cassette television which will shortly be upon us, and various developments of that kind to get across the message of the Gallery and to get out to the Australian people the full emphasis of what it means. I refer not only to those who may not have the opportunity of visiting Canberra but also to the sick, the aged and the impoverished who are just not able to make a visit to Canberra and inspect what might be a sort of national museum.

In this regard there comes to mind particularly someone in Victoria who now lies on his sickbed, one Bruce Edward Weather head, a well-known Victorian aesthete with a lifelong devotion to the pursuit of beauty in all its forms. He lies on his sick bed today in Victoria having collided with a tree in his car, no doubt while he was listening to Beethoven's Ninth Symphony. Like someone waiting for Godot, he waits for the national compensation scheme to arrive and help him with his problems. But a man like that, who is unable to visit a gallery of this kind because of ill health, can surely have the benefits which the Gallery should provide in the form of, as I said, cassette television productions from the Gallery which can be distributed widely throughout the community. Particularly with the advent of colour television, there is the prospect of the Gallery's works being brought into every home from time to time. I do not want to discuss the various sections of the community which could benefit in that way because if I do I suppose that I will sound as though I am conducting the Hospital Half Hour session, the happy Hammond show, or something of that kind. That is not my intention. But I am concerned to see that the Aus.tralian National Gallery does fulfil a living function in the life of the Australian community, that it is just not a sterile museum in Canberra, that it is a thing which can grasp the imagination of the Australian people by its own activity and by generating activity in the artistic field throughout the community, particularly through the galleries of the various States.

I make the comment in passing that we tend, even in 1975, to see works of art as having some degree of immortality. That is to say, one has a profound reverence for the works of the great masters and believes that when purchasing paintings, even in the 1970s, they should be regarded as permanent things which wil survive for as long as man can imagine and for the benefit of future generations in that form. That may not necessarily be so. Art is a very changing form and it may be that the artistic forms of the 1970s will be of a very transitory nature; that is to say, they may not be things which are bought to last. If that be so, I believe it is very important that all the facilities of the Gallery be brought to bear on the problems which I have raised, namely, dis simulating throughout the community the sorts of facilities and values which are enshrined in works of great art and which will be found in the National Gallery at Canberra when shortly, I hope, it is built. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

talker.role: Leader of the Government in the Senate
talker.name: WRIEDT, Ken
Senator WRIEDT

talk.start.para: Speaking very briefly, I thank both Senator Guilfoyle and Senator Button for their contributions. I am pleased that the Opposition is not opposing this legislation. The only matter which I feel I should comment on is the availability of art exhibitions around Australia and the fact that it is not intended, of course, that these great works of art will be available to only a very small section of the community. In fact, what the Government intends is to have 3 exhibitions on tour in Australia within a very short space of time so that we can ensure that people all over Australia will benefit from seeing these works of art. I understand that the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam) has approved of a major exhibition of selected works from the national collection to tour all States commencing with the Adelaide Festival in March 1976. So honourable senators can be assured that the works with which this legislation deals will be seen by as many Australians as possible, which is the intention. I am sure that Australia's cultural life will benefit to a very marked degree by the passage of this legislation.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: The Bill.

talk.start.para: I have some comments to make with regard to clause 5 and would be pleased to have a response to them. It will be seen from the Bill that clause 5(1) provides that the national collection shall be housed in the Australian Capital Territory and sub-clause (2) provides:

speech.para: Nothing in the section prevents the exhibition outside the Australian Capital Territory or outside Australia of works of art from the national collection.

It has been brought to our attention that the wording of this clause binds the Council to house all its collection in the Australian Capital Territory except for exhibiting elsewhere. This makes us feel that the clause exempts items which cannot be moved, such as Aboriginal rock paintings or other murals or sculptures which are incorporated into a landscape. It is conceivable that a nationally important acquisition might be tied to some other location by the wish or bequest of an artist or owner or because of religious views of the community concerned, including Aborigines. The Bill includes mechanisms to make possible any arrangement required and invites techniques to achieve practical or diplomatic objectives. We wonder whether clause 5 is limiting in the way that we would be excluding the ownership of collections which were required to be housed outside the Australian Capital Territory.

talk.start.para: I would think that what

speech.para: Senator Guilfoyleis saying is covered by subclause 2 which provides:
Nothing in the section prevents the exhibition outside the Australian Capital Territory or outside Australia of works of art from the national collection.

I would assume that Aboriginal works, for example, which obviously could not be moved to the Australian Capital Territory, would remain as a perpetual exhibition in their natural state. But quite apart from that, I feel that sub-clause (2) gives sufficient coverage of any such exhibition if it be deemed necessary for the exhibition to take place outside the Australian Capital Territory.

talk.start.para: I was making the point that sub-clause (2) provides that the collection shall be housed in the Australian Capital Territory. We were thinking of things that may be incorporated elsewhere as pieces of sculpture but bequeathed to the national collection. We are thinking also of people who make a gift and require that it be held in a place other than the Australian Capital Territory. What we are talking about is perhaps hypothetical, but we wonder whether there needs to be some qualification of the requirements for housing within the Australian Capital Territory.
Mr Temporary Chairman-
Do you intend directing your remarks to this point?
Yes.

I make the point to the Committee that we are dealing with clause 5. We will deal with the clauses seriatim, that is we will not be returning to a particular clause. We will be dealing with clauses in the order in which they appear in the Bill.

May I add to the argument which Senator Guilfoyle has raised. I think that on any natural interpretation of this clause the national collection is to be housed in the Australian Capital Territory. That seems to me a very firm and fixed statement. Sub-clause (2) merely allows the exhibition outside of works of art from the national collection. I would think that that might be unduly restrictive. It may be that the Government will not choose at this stage to amend the Bill which already has passed through the House of Representatives, but it seems to me a great pity that some amendment did not come forward. I think the clause might restrict the Government from acquiring works to be part of the national collection which ought to be kept in the Northern Territory. I do not think that, on any normal interpretation, clause 5 (2) does more than allow the works to be taken from the Australian Capital Territory for exhibition. I support the comments which Senator Guilfoyle has made.

I think it may be the wording of the clause that creates a problem. I would not defend completely the manner in which the clause is expressed. It does perhaps give rise to some doubt. I can only assure both Senator Missen and Senator Guilfoyle who have spoken on it that there is certainly no intention on the part of the Government to restrict the location of exhibitions outside the Australian Capital Territory. Perhaps that is not a satisfactory answer for either honourable senator. The only way in which we could overcome the problem would be for the clause to be deferred for the purpose of amending it and re-wording it, but I do not really feel that that is necessary. Clause 5 ( 1 ) is quite clear. It says:

speech.para: The national collection shall be housed in the Australian Capital Territory.
Notwithstanding sub-clause (1), sub-clause (2) says:
Nothing in this section prevents the exhibition outside the Australian Capital Territory ... of works of art from the national collection.

The intention of the draftsmen was obviously to permit works of art to be exhibited outside the Australian Capital Territory but at the same time not entirely to restrict those exhibitions to be located within the Australian Capital Territory. I agree that it could be argued either way but I am assured that it was not the intention of the legislation to do that. I can do no more than give that explanation as to what appears to be an arguable point.

talk.start.para: The Opposition accepts the comments of the Minister for Agriculture (Senator Wriedt) with regard to the intent of the Bill but would like consideration to be given to the wording of the clause. We did not wish to move a formal amendment because we did not wish to impede the Bill as the other House is not in session at the present time. For this reason we raise it as a point that could require clarification. We would welcome discussion by the Minister with regard to the wording or we would accept a re-wording of the clause that would allow the National Gallery to accept as part of the national collection offers which may not be able to be housed in the Australian Capital Territory. We do not think that sub-clause (2) covers the point that we have been making with regard to the requirements that may be imposed upon location of offers for the national collection. We accept that the Aus.tralian national collection may at this stage in our history not be the best collection of all works of art in the world but we would like to think that it is the best collection of Australian works of art. For those reasons we would want to think that the National Gallery could accept bequests that may have attached to them some requirements which would tie those contributions of art to other locations.
