We would like to feel that the point we have been making has the consideration of the Government.

I can say only that I would be quite happy to discuss this matter with the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam). If we seek to amend the clause now we will hold up the legislation. It is very difficult to know what to do. All I can suggest is that I will discuss it with him. If it is possible to clarify the intention of the wording of the clause I shall do so, but I could not give an undertaking beyond that.

The Opposition will accept that undertaking. I would now like to refer to clause 9. We see this as interesting because clause 9(1) says that the Council may resolve that the work of art be disposed of by sale, gift or destruction. We find of interest the word 'destruction' and wondered what explanation there would be that would require the inclusion of the word 'destruction' in such a Bill. We think there would need to be a very good reason why it should be necessary to destroy works of art and we would be interested to have the explanation as to why that word had been included.
It is to cater for a gentleman called Lallo Toth. I think that is his name.

That may be the case but I would like to have an official explanation of why the word 'destruction' has been included in clause 9. There is another matter in the same clause to which we wish to refer. In clause 9(3) the Council is required to obtain reports from two independent experts on any work being considered for disposal. We pose the thought that the Council should be expected to adopt a responsible attitude to this matter, as in all other matters of management of the National Gallery and collection. We wonder what advice of consultants would be required in addition to the wisdom that the Council undoubtedly will develop in carrying out its own responsibilities; what would be the identification of the independent experts who are envisaged in this clause and what then would be the difficulties if the two independent experts had divergent views; and whether that particular provision places a requirement on the Council that may lead to some difficulties in its own responsibilities and administration. We would appreciate it if we could have some comment on those two matters, Mr Temporary Chairman.

talker.role: Leader of the Government in the Senate
talker.name: WRIEDT, Ken
Senator WRIEDT

talk.start.para: I understand that the . word 'destruction' applies where a sculpture- one could imagine a fairly large object- which had become non-repairable or possibly even dangerous because of damage done to it would need to be destroyed. That is the reason for including the word 'destruction' in the legislation. On the other matter raised by Senator Guilfoyle relating to the two independent experts, I inform senators that these would be people who are experts or specialists in the areas outside the area of the Council relating to the technical aspects of conservation and restoration. The Council would always have the final decision, based on the advice of experts. I think the legislation makes reference to the fact that the Council would need to turn to the advice of technical people. Presumably it would need to be a matter of judgment at the time as to who those persons would be. I should think it would be very difficult for the legislation to tie down specifically who the people would be. It would be a matter for the discretion of the Council.
I should like to refer to clause 1 1 sub-clause (6), which states:

speech.para: Before approving of the acquisition of a work of art in accordance with a request under paragraph (5) (c), the Minister shall obtain a valuation of the work of an from an independent expert.

We are somewhat surprised at the mandatory control over the Council by the Minister and we should like some comment as to why it is felt this is not a function that the Council should be expected to perform in the course of its normal responsibilities. Sub-clause (5)(c) of clause 11 states that if a property is a work of art and the Council wishes to acquire it for the national collection the Council may request the Minister to approve its acquisition for the national collection. We believe that the requirement of Ministerial approval is a mandatory control over the Council 's activities and we should be pleased to have a comment as to why this is required.

talk.start.para: Again I do not think it is a question of the legislation requiring the Minister to override the expert opinion of the Council.

speech.para: Naturally the people who would be appointed to the Council would be the ones best able to determine which works should be purchased. There is, of course, the financial question. It is readily understandable that in view of the limitations on the availability of funds the Minister would need to exercise some discretion as to the actual amounts which were expended. At present on any individual work of art there is a limit of $100,000. If a work involving some millions of dollars was thought to be a fit and proper acquisition for the Gallery, obviously the Minister would need to police the decision by the Council, as part of an overall consideration of government expenditure. That is the reason for the clause being worded the way that it is.

talk.start.para: I deal now with clause 13 which relates to the membership of the Council. I draw attention to the fact that there is no mention of the basis for appointment to the Council. We would have expected some mention of representation of practitioners. The Minister for Agriculture might indicate the qualifications of members of the Interim Council who were appointed in September 1974. Clause 13 (2) states:

speech.para: The members, other than the Director, shall be appointed by the Governor-General having regard to their knowledge and experience with respect to the visual arts or any other area of knowledge relevant to the affairs of the Gallery.

We would have expected some mention of representation by people with experience and skill and that they would find appointment as members of the Council. We would be pleased to have a comment about that.

talk.start.para: I would have thought that the answer lies in ella use 13(2), which states:

speech.para: The members, other than the Director, shall be appointed by the Governor-General having regard to their knowledge and experience with respect to the visual arts or any other area of knowledge relevant to the affairs of the Gallery.

It would seem to me that a fairly wide qualification as to prospective members is permitted to the Council. I know the appointment of persons to any statutory body is always a difficulty, particularly to one which is involved in the area of the arts. In view of the wording of that clause one would assume that commonsense alone would dictate the need to ensure that the persons who would be appointed to such a body would be knowledgeable and competent to contribute in a particular area. I do not find the clause too restrictive. It seems to me to cover the requirements of the legislation.

talk.start.para: I was referring to practitioners. I would have expected some specification about skill. If the Minister for Agriculture (Senator Wriedt) has no further comment on clause 13, 1 would like to move to clauses 1 5 and 16 and to comment with regard to deputies of members of the Council.

speech.para: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Devitt)- Are you addressing yourself to both clauses simultaneously?

talk.start.para: Yes, because they relate to one another. We are rather doubtful as to the efficiency and fairness of enabling a part time member of the Council to appoint, with the Minister's approval, a temporary deputy in the part time member's place. We think that this is an unusual requirement, and we would have taken as a general point of view that when a member is appointed to a council such as this the member should serve his term properly and fully or he should resign. Unless we could get a proper explanation with regard to this point we would consider this to be a provision with which we do not agree. Had we been in different circumstances I feel we would have been moving an amendment to this clause, because if we find that a part time member may appoint a deputy, we think that we are getting to the point in the formation of the Council where the required experience and the skill that we spoke about earlier may not be in the Council at the time it is undertaking its duties.

continue.para: Honourable senators will see that clause 17 (2) (b) provides that if a part-time member absents himself without leave from 3 consecutive meetings of the Council his appointment will be terminated in any case. With regard to the provisions of clause 17 (2) (b), the fact that a part time Council member may appoint a deputy seems to us to be a very wide area that is given to the membership of the Council. I simply say that if we were in different circumstances in this Committee debate we would have been seeking an amendment to this clause in the interests of having continuity of skill and experience in the membership of the Council. We would be pleased to have the response of the Minister to the need for the opportunity to be given for the appointment of a temporary deputy in the part time membership of the Council.

talk.start.para: I wish to make a brief comment in relation to Senator Guilfoyle 's comments with regard to clause 13 (2). I think her comments are consistent with observations which the Opposition made at the time the Arts Council legislation and the Australia Council legislation- with which I had a lot of sympathy- were debated. But I should have thought that in this area, as the Minister for Agriculture (Senator Wriedt) has pointed out, the very breadth of terminology which is contained in clause 13 (2) is the most desirable terminology that one could have in relation to a Council of this kind, particularly in view of the fact that the practitioners tend to be highly nationalised and not necessarily the most objective judges of their own particular discipline.
They are worse than lawyers.

As Senator Missen points out, they are worse than lawyers. If that be possible, I would agree with that observation. In relation to the appointment of deputies of part time members, I simply make the observation that, as I understand the relevant clauses, the part time members would be extremely limited in their capacity to appoint deputies because, after all, if the part time members fail to attend 3 consecutive meetings, that is, without leave, they are removed. Their capacity to appoint part time deputies must be limited to a maximum of 2 meetings.
Without leave. Without leave it can be much more diluted than with leave.

I understand that, but in my view it still establishes a much greater limitation and control over the activities of part time members than one might think from a first reading of the clause. I make that observation because, even though the clause states specifically without leave', I think it must be taken into consideration that the members are members of an entire Council. The limitation seems to me to be much more stringent than one would think at first sight.

I wish to hark back briefly to clause 13 (2) and the matters raised by Senator Guilfoyle and referred to by Senator Button. Looking back, in the arts in Australia we have been magnificently served by practitioners- artists in Australia who have assisted the nation through the years in the collection of works which are of inestimable value to our galleries, to our buildings, our embassies overseas and so on. I should like to stress again the high importance of clause 13(2), even though it appears to embrace the ability to have, among the 9 members, practitioners as such. I want to stress the desirability of credit being given' to the work through the years of Sir William Dargie, and Sir Russel Drysdale and to men such as those who can do a significant service to our nation in a council such as this. I pay tribute on this occasion to what they have done in the past-

Very briefly, I thank Senator Button for his very informed contribution at this stage, but I rise to comment on Senator Laucke 's remarks, which were similar to those made earlier by Senator Guilfoyle. I understand that the current Interim Council now has practitioners among its members- Messrs Williams, French, Dawson and Parr- in addition to other people having skills in the area of the visual arts. I would not claim to know exactly what Messrs Williams, French, Dawson or Parr do.
One is a sculptor.

I assume that they are artists, I understand that they are practitioners. They are already members of the Interim Council and I assume from that that the artistic community is in fact properly represented at the present time.

The Opposition was hoping that that section of the community would be continuously represented. I still would like some explanation with regard to the deputies and why it was felt necessary to have the appointment of deputies for part time members.

speech.para: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Devitt)-This relates to clause 15(1)?

talk.start.para: It is related also to clauses 16 and 17.

I have no doubt that the Minister will give a definitive view on this in a moment. I suppose one of the things that the legislation has in mind is the sort of thing Senator Guilfoyle mentioned when she was speaking about the gallery. One would hope for an exchange of ideas, for some movement of exhibitions and personnel and so on, and that many of the people involved on a National Gallery Board of this kind would be the sort of people who would be travelling quite frequently. The four people who have just been named by the Minister- Fred Williams, Janet Dawson, Lent on Parr and Leonard French- are all engaged in teaching or painting or sculpting and each one of them, I believe, would travel overseas at least once a year. I assume it is in that sort of situation that the provision for deputies for part time members would be envisaged as being useful. I am only hazarding a guess; the Minister may have some much more refined and clearer explanation than that.
Hear, hear!
If I might say so, in answer to Senator Poyser 's interjection, I am hazarding a guess upon which I would be prepared to put my money.

I understand that the position is that, with the Minister's concurrence, members do travel overseas or are absent on leave. Deputies can be appointed if the Minister agrees, but only on that condition, in which case the provisions of clause 13 (2) would apply. I cannot give Senator Guilfoyle any more information than that at the present time. If it is necessary, I will have to seek that information and supply it later in writing, if what I have said is not sufficient.

speech.para: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Senator Wriedt) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 17 April, on motion by Senator Wriedt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: The kind of Bill now before the Senate is not brought forward regularly. Every 1 8 months to 3 years we are presented with a request for an appropriation of money for the continuation of the war service land settlement scheme. Because a Bill of this kind is not a regular one and because there has been a large number of changes in the Senate since a Bill such as this was last before the Senate, I should like briefly to cover the history of war service land settlement and to point out some of the problems that the settlers are experiencing today.

speech.para: The purpose of the war service settlement scheme was to establish or re-establish eligible persons on the land. It is beyond my understanding how the authorities can claim that settlers have been re-established on the land when overvalued and under-sized properties caused their liabilities to be greater than their assets. It seems to me that the authorities have nationalised large areas of land in obtaining and taking over land for this scheme. It would appear to be fairly obvious that the main consideration has been to keep their little empire intact because, according to the history of war service land settlement, it would appear that what happened to the settler has been a minor consideration. Financial arrangements were different for each method of operation. The war service land settlement scheme envisaged that the Commonwealth would bear most of the costs of the agent States while the reverse applied to States which acted as principals. The whole scheme was under the control of" a Director of War Service Land Settlement who was responsible to the Minister for Post- War Reconstruction. In his second reading speech on 27 September 1945 the then Minister, Mr Dedman, referring to the scheme which had been implemented after the First World War, emphasised that a careful examination would have to be made of proposed land acquisition and of subsequent development to make sure that properties were of sufficient size and capable of providing a reasonable living for those who were to take up occupancy.

Proposals for land acquisition were submitted to the Commonwealth giving full details including the potential use of the land. After agreement had been reached between the Commonwealth and the States concerning acquisition, the States were to proceed with plans for subdivision. After approval had been given by the Commonwealth, the States concerned would then proceed with subdivision of and improvements to the land up to the point where the land could be brought into production. Later the principal States took over full financial responsibility for war service land settlement within their own States, and the Commonwealth agreed to bear an equal share in respect of any losses which were incurred.

In a second reading speech on a Bill to provide $17m for this scheme in 1956, the then Minister for Primary Industry (Mr McMahon) described the pattern of the scheme during the first 10 years of its operation. He mentioned that after a period of some years settlers could obtain freehold of their land, the actual period varying between 6 and 10 years depending on State arrangements as to when landholders could exercise their options. In New South Wales large estates were subdivided and some had irrigation facilities. A number of single unit properties were purchased under this scheme, probably in most of the States. In Victoria subdivision of large irrigation areas in the Murray Valley was undertaken. Proposals for the clearing of virgin scrub in the Otway and Wilson's Promontory areas were put in hand. The settlement scheme in Queensland was terminated after a large number of men had been settled on sugar or tobacco properties. Mr McMahon described heavy clearing projects which were being undertaken in the agent States. He mentioned that in Western Australia the Rocky Gully project would provide 170 fat lamb farms from 285 000 acres of virgin forest; 48 wheat and sheep holdings from 125 000 acres at Jerramungup; 40 farms at Mount Many Peaks in the Albany area and up to 100 farms were being developed with an area of 500 000 acres north of Bremer Bay.

Mr McMahonspoke of the 250 000 acres of scrub land in South Australia being developed on Kangaroo Island to form more than 1 70 fat lamb properties. On the Murray River, at Loxton, Cool tong and Loveday, 328 blocks were being developed for the production of horticultural crops under irrigation. He also described work in Tasmania covering 13 000 acres of densely timbered land in swamp country in the area known at that time as Montagu but which has since been renamed To gar i. That land is being drained and developed. He referred also to work on King Island where 90 farms had been occupied, and further work on Flinders Island where 1 38 farms were being prepared from virgin scrub for fat lamb and beef cattle production.

A moment ago I mentioned To gar i. The Minister for Agriculture (Senator Wriedt) will remember that I asked him a question about To gar i and the drainage there and I thank him for the answer I received today. I think it is important that we get into perspective the situation that the people find themselves in at To gar i at this time. Various authorities in Tasmania have made some funds available for partial snagging of the river there. Rather than help alleviate the problem that work has tended to increase it. One part of the Montagu River runs through a narrow rocky gorge. When the river rises quickly it cannot get past this narrow point and the water is forced back over the properties. This has brought about the problem that the people there have. It could well be that Tasmania may look at the matter and see whether it is possible, with the help of financial aid from the Commonwealth Government, to do something about widening the river, perhaps by blasting this rocky gorge, to increase the flow of water in that area.

talk.start.para: Would a dam meet the situation?

No, I do not think so. If the water were dammed it would be forced back all the time. It is just an unfortunate geographical feature. The water runs through a rocky cutting and this cutting causes an impediment in flood times. Flooding is the natural corollary.

continue.para: It was becoming apparent by 1 959 that further development of the scheme would fall off in future years. By that time over 8000 ex-servicemen had settled on the land, but there were still many outstanding applications from qualified people- men who had the requisite training or experience in agriculture. However, it was expected that projects in hand would enable those interested to be settled. It was appreciated that many men who had applied were settled in other vocations and were no longer genuinely interested in war service land settlement. Some of the settlers under the scheme had got into financial difficulties and it was appreciated that ways and means would have to be devised to see them over the difficult period which they were going through. It was apparent by the mid 1960s that there were real problems in some of the areas selected for development. In the words of Mr Adermann, then Minister for Primary Industry:

It is recognised that problems have arisen, it is mainly extraordinary circumstances in many war service land settlement areas, such as those at King Island, Rocky Gully, Kangaroo Island and Loxton, and have required additional development work. This has delayed the completion of schemes that could have otherwise been completed perhaps by 1959 or 1960. These extraordinary circumstances have arisen, the Government is sympathetic and is prepared to meet the needs of settlers and see that they get a just recompense for their efforts.

There were many problems of location and of insufficient size of properties on King Island and elsewhere. Significant numbers of settlers simply gave up either because of a lack of experience or low morale due to isolation and the difficulties of making a profit. In the Loxton irrigation area in South Australia unexpected drainage problems were encountered which caused production of citrus fruits to be far less than anticipated. As Mr Adermann said in 1967:

There have been many testing problems. One I recall very well was that of Loxton when the expert technical advice given some years before that extensive drainage would not be necessary was proven wrong.

We note from the second reading speech that a portion of the moneys made available under this Bill is for additional drainage works in Loxton. I cannot understand why there has been such a delay in this work being done. It has been delayed to this point. It is nice to see that at last something is being done about it. Mr Adermann went on to say:
We did not hesitate to undertake extensive and costly redevelopment to ensure that the farms were capable of the planned level of production.
On the other hand, there is still a lot of criticism of properties at places like King Island. One report indicated that no fewer than 116 settlers out of 1 54 had left the Island.

It is also interesting to note in passing that a very large number of people who settled on King Island were not Tasmanians although King Island is a sovereign part of Tasmania. A very large number of people, many of whom I know quite well, came from Victoria and New South Wales because land was available on King Island for this sort of project which was not necessarily available in their own States. It is apparent that there were some major problems which had to be overcome over the long period in which the scheme had been functioning. Those problems have been highlighted in debates in both the House of Representatives and previously in the Senate. However, looked at from an overall point of view the scheme has served a very useful purpose in land development and the resettlement of a great number of ex-servicemen. It seems apparent that funds should continue to be made available for the purpose of overcoming problems and enabling those settlers who have now committed themselves irrevocably to their properties to continue in the business of farming.

It is interesting to note at this point, when we look back over what has happened in some of the debates prior to this, that Dr Patterson moved an amendment in the other House on one occasion. He said:
I now move the following amendment, which is in the same terms as the one I moved last year:

That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to inserting the following words in place thereof: whilst not opposing the provisions of the Bill, the House is of opinion that a Select Committee of the House should be appointed to inquire into all aspects of war service land settlement in Australia in order to formulate guidelines for any future land settlement scheme with particular reference to the level of rentals demanded from settlers, the method of valuations and the option of purchase price of properties. '

If honourable members refer to pages 1604 and 1605 of the Hansard record dated 19 September 1972 they will find that the then Opposition opposed the motion that the Bill be read a third time. I wonder why. No explanation was given. 1 think it is pertinent that all people responsible for war service land settlement in some respect or other have to bear some of the responsibility for the fact that the scheme has never worked quite as well as was envisaged, notwithstanding the history of what happened after the First World War. I think this side of the Parliament is as responsible as the other side. But when we look back over what Dr Patterson said in his amendment and subsequent to it we realise that this is perhaps one of the unfortunate instances in which politics has been played, not necessarily to the real benefit of the settlers concerned.

The Authority has undoubtedly taken advantage of a general looseness in the principal Act. For instance section 2 (4) of this Act states that holdings shall be of sufficient size to enable settlers to operate efficiently and to earn a reasonable labour income. But who determines what is sufficient size and what is a reasonable labour income? It is the Authority. There is no provision in the Act for a farm size appeals board, so the Authority may divide an estate into 40-cow farms and then claim that the settlers have been allocated 70-cow farms. It is understood that the Authority had determined that $45 a week was sufficient labour income for settlers that it had under financial management. It may be true that these settlers accepted financial management but it is equally true that they accepted because they were under threat of eviction if they refused.

At this point I mention that a subtle form of blackmail was used to induce settlers to accept offers of holdings. It is considered that the Authority waited until the settlers had invested their savings in their holdings, had made considerable improvements to the holdings and were in a position where, because of severe stock losses and heavy plant depreciation due to inadequate development in the first place, they would have faced bankruptcy had they refused to accept and they would have been evicted. The settlers were advised that if they failed to accept the offer within 21 days the Authority would consider offering the holding to another eligible person. I think it is correct to say that at a later date partial compensation was paid for stock losses and plant depreciation but this was not mentioned in the offer of holding. There is no known case of a settler who refused his offer of holding any such compensation.

The prime cause of settler failure has been the lack of farm size but this could have been avoided if the Act had provided for the right of appeal to an independent statutory body which could hear not only appeals on farm size but also appeals on arrears caused by the lack of farm size. It is noted that the Authority has on scores of occasions put pressure on settlers who have had arrears of payments until those settlers walked off their holdings. After those settlers' leases were terminated the Authority was quite happy to write off those arrears. The select committee of the Legislative Council of Tasmania which inquired into the administration of war service land settlement in Tasmania found that in that State as at 31 December 1970 the Commonwealth had written off $696,878 of settlers' arrears. Supposedly the funds were appropriated for war service land settlement to establish eligible persons on the land. But now perhaps it could be said that these funds were misappropriated. They were and are being used virtually to nationalise land.

Much capital has been made of a decision to give some settlers the right of appeal against the option purchase prices to a body known as the Option Purchase Prices Appeals Tribunal. On examination this Tribunal is found to be a non statutory body. It appears doubtful whether either the chairman of the Tribunal or the settlers concerned ever knew whether the Minister accepted the Tribunal's recommendations. So the appeal is still as before- from Caesar to Caesar. On 19 March 1974 Senator Lillico asked the following question of the Attorney-General; at that time it was Senator Murphy who is now Mr Justice Murphy:
Would a tribunal be considered to be truly independent if one of its members had been involved in the determination of the matter under dispute?
The reply was:

The question calls for an expression of opinion. I must say, however, that it is a well-established rule of law that the principles of natural justice require that a person adjudicating in a dispute between parties should not himself have an interest in the subject matter of the dispute, or to have otherwise been involved personally in the matter under dispute.

When the Minister for Agriculture replies I would like him to comment on the reasons for the appointment to the Tribunal of the First Assistant Secretary (Grants Administration), Australian Department of Agriculture which incorporates the War Service Land Settlement Division. Also I would like the reason for the appointment of this same person or any other person connected with the administration of war service land settlement to the appeal board established under section 68 of the Tasmanian War Service Land Settlement Act. Will the Minister also advise what steps he intends to take to correct this anomaly? Will the Minister also indicate whether he will introduce amending legislation to provide a right of appeal against farm size to a statutory body? I think it is extremely important that this matter should be looked at.

I know that the schemes have been in operation for many years and that a lot of people have been established on properties for a long time. But we must recognise that a very large number of those people are now well into their fifties- some are in their early sixties- and they are no longer able to cope with all the physical effort involved in farming and also with the worry that is caused by an ever-decreasing income and an ever-increasing cost factor. Unfortunately due to the way in which the Act is written these people are not able to have access to farm reconstruction plans and other assistance which is made available through various Commonwealth agencies. Because of the bad record of some settlers, not necessarily due entirely to their own efforts, it is not always possible for these people to get assistance under the War Service Land Settlement Acts, the result being that very many of them are finding it extremely difficult to continue.

Very recently the costs involved in farming have gone up by 35 per cent and unfortunately incomes have fallen by up to 40 per cent in some cases. We all know of the occasions- I think they are legion- when mention has been made in both Houses of Parliament of the increased costs involved in farming, such as the increased cost of fertilisers due to the removal of the bounty and the increased price of superphosphate rock, the increased cost of transport and the increased telephone charges. All these matters affect the war service land settler just as they affect everyone else. In fact they affect him worse because, unless he has been able to establish resources over a period of time whereby he can buy or obtain access to extra land, he is not like the ordinary farmer and he does not have the ability to be able to overcome the tremendous difficulties in which such people find themselves at present.

It is to be hoped, now that this matter is before the Senate, that the Minister will look at this problem that has been with us, particularly in Tasmania, for many years. I am sure the Minister is aware of it. I do not think the Labor Party in Government is altogether to blame. I think some blame must fall on the previous Government. But that does not alter the fact that now is the time when decisions must be made and responsibility must be accepted by the Minister and by the Government. It is to be hoped that these people will be assisted in such a way that their main worry- the inability to maintain the income from their properties to meet commitments to the Government- will be alleviated in the not too distant future. It is to be hoped that assistance will go to these people, who, firstly, have served their country and, secondly, have worked extremely hard to earn a living and to maintain their families on these properties, so that they will be able to spend the twilight of their lives in some sort of security- at least security of mind.

It is known that many settlers in the Bass Strait islands and on the Tasmanian mainland have had pressure put on them to terminate their tenancies. Will the Minister advise whether he is quite happy for settlers in his own State to be put on the road simply because the Authority miscalculated, because the Act does not provide an appeal against farm size and because no provision is made for additional land to be made available to these people. I realise that there is a physical difficulty in making additional land available, particularly in a settlement area in which the farms are set out side by side. In instances where settlers have had to leave their properties by reason of their being no longer physically or financially able to continue, I think it may well be possible for governments- I say governments' advisedly- to cut their losses, to divide up properties, particularly where there is one on either side of an empty block, and to make available some additional land for other settlers. We must not forget that when the scheme was established in the early 1950s a 45-cow property was probably able to produce a reasonable standard of living. The same could not be said today for a property twice its size. I do not think anybody can be blamed for that but we must recognise that there is a problem and, if possible, try to establish these people in a position where they can reasonably expect to make a living and meet their commitments.
Section 5 (2) of the relevant Act does not bear very close examination. It reads:

When the planned works involved in any holding forming part of the project have been substantially completed, a valuation of the holding shall be made in consultation by officers appointed by the Commonwealth and the State for that purpose.

The only right a settler has is to reject the offer of a holding. At this point a settler's success or failure is determined and it has been at this point that the scheme in general has failed. Any miscalculation here can mean only settler failure. It is fair to say that if there had not been any miscalculation at this point there would be few, if any, cases of settler failure. It is also fair to say that if settler failure is due to miscalculation by these officers then the funds appropriated for war service land settlement have not been used in the manner intended by the Parliament when the appropriations were approved. Had the holdings been at the standard indicated in the rental and option to purchase price valuations there is little doubt that this scheme would have worked in the way the Parliament intended. Unfortunately, when Parliament makes a judgment, as it will in a few moments; it cannot possibly foresee, particularly in a country like Australia where so much of our produce is sold on the international market, what the market position or what the cost position will be in 10 years from today, as has been the case in the past with regard to land settlement.

The Opposition supports this Bill. We realise that if this scheme is to be kept in any way viable it is occasionally necessary for money to be appropriated for the purpose of making loans to settlers, either as carry-on loans or as loans to replace machinery or even stock. The Opposition hopes that the Minister for Agriculture will keep in mind some of the points I have made. They refer to problems that settlers have faced for as long as we have had soldier settlement.

talk.start.para: in reply- This question of war service land settlement is one which has had as long a history of debate in this Parliament as has any scheme commenced by any government. As I have said in the past, when I was appointed to this portfolio 2V4 years ago and was required to acquaint myself with the background to this scheme, I could come to only one conclusion. It was that our predecessors, the Liberal-Country Party Government, over the years had been generous to war service land settlers. Basically the policies which were pursued by the previous Government have been continued by this Government. There were many decisions taken by my predecessor which I believe could be described only as fair and generous.

speech.para: Over the years a great deal of money has been made available from Federal sources to finance soldier settlers on very favourable conditions with favourable interest rates and favourable terms of repayment. The truth of the matter is that the great majority of war service land settlers have been successful and have not in the main suffered any great problems, apart from the normal downturns and the problems which affect the whole of the farming community anyway. There have been cases where war service land settlers have not been successful. Many have not been successful because of their own fault. It is as simple as that. They have not applied themselves as have their comrades who also went on to the land under exactly the same conditions. It could not be said that any government since the war has been anything but very sympathetic to the whole of the war service land settlement movement. I know that there have been agitators perhaps that is not the word to use, but I would call them pressure groups within the associations who have -

talk.start.para: Malcontents.

There have been malcontents who have not been so successful as other settlers, and for some reason this is said to be the responsibility of the governments over the years. I reject that. I reject it in respect of Liberal governments as I do in respect of Labor governments. It is true that in isolated areas there have been problems such as those that have been mentioned by Senator Bessell. These were matters about which neither the State governments nor the Federal Government could have done much. All in all, I emphasise that the whole program over the years, despite some shortcomings, has been basically a very generous one.

continue.para: My predecessor studied the Fenton report on Tasmania, as I did. I came to the same conclusions as he did, with one exception, that is, I agreed to the appointment of a tribunal to hear appeals on option prices. I dare say that was another step forward, but in the main I believe that the actions that were taken before the present Government came to office were fair and reasonable in the circumstances.

It is a fact that the majority of settlers are solvent. There are some who do have arrears problems, but most of them have met their commitments under the scheme to the respective governments. I think it should be borne in mind that so much of what is done is done through the State instrumentalities. I do not think it is valid to be critical of the officers who have to inspect properties. They are commissioned to make a judgment as to whether they believe a settler is in fact doing an efficient job or a reasonably efficient job on his property. There is no ban on the purchase of adjoining land in order to expand the property that a settler has. Once again I can only say that from my experience every co-operation has been afforded to those settlers who have found themselves in difficulties. I would not suggest for a moment that certain improvements could not be effected. I certainly do not deny that some settlers are in trouble, but I reject the argument that this has been caused by the ungenerous attitude of governments over the years towards settlers. It is necessary that this legislation be carried as part of the continuing scheme.
Senator Bessellreferred to the appointment of an assistant secretary to the appeals tribunal. I think he was referring to the appeals tribunal in Tasmania.

talk.start.para: Yes.

I think it would be understood that the Federal Government, again irrespective of its political colour, needs to have representation to ensure that the moneys which come from a Federal source are properly monitored by the relevant Federal department. This has been the general practice over the years with the disbursement of most Federal moneys. I believe it is proper that that practice should continue.

continue.para: Senator Bessellraised one or two other points which I believe were valid but on which I am not able to give him specific answers now. If he is agreeable, I will obtain comment on those matters and write to him supplying him with more detailed information rather than giving him an answer now without having the proper facts before me. Let me conclude by indicating the Government's pleasure that we are at least getting this legislation through today with the support of the Opposition. We all know that many promises have been made in the past about these matters, but generally my overall impression is that the war service land settlement scheme has done a tremendous amount over the years on very favourable terms and conditions for those who availed themselves of it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 21 April, on motion by Senator James McClelland:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: The Trade Practices Bill 1975 is a Bill to amend the substantial piece of legislation that was adopted by the Parliament last year- the Trade Practices Act. The Bill contains 3 separate amendments to the existing legislation. The Opposition supports that legislation and, in their present form, it finds these amendments to be quite satisfactory and necessary in the operation of the legislation. The Act has now been in operation in its entirety for some three or four months. The particular problems dealt with by these amendments have arisen since then. I will outline briefly the amendments and their effect.

speech.para: The first of the amendments contained in this short Bill is to be found in clause 3 of the Bill. It has resulted from some doubt that has arisen as to the effect of Part IV- in particular section 51- of the Trade Practices Act. That section deals with the various exceptions in the Part. It provides for the exceptions to the contraventions contained in the Act. It sets out a number of exceptions and allowances of contracts based in s( 'Tie cases on the fact that they are approved or authorised under existing Acts of this Parliament or of the States or ordinances of a Territory. In that and various other ways it excepts certain conduct from contravention of the Act. The doubt that has arisen is as to whether those exceptions apply to section 45 of the Act. That is the section which makes contracts in restraint of trade or commerce unenforceable and which forbids such contracts. Some doubt has arisen as te whether one can still find a contract unenforceable under section 45 of the Act when it is allow able under section 51. As the Government has said, it has always been the intention that the legislation should be so applied. All that the amendment in this respect does is to make it perfectly clear that section 5 1 of the Act does apply to section 45 ( 1 ). That being the intention, the proposition has the support of the Opposition.

The second of the three sets of amendments is to be found in clauses 4 and 5 of the Bill. They relate to the two different provisions of the principal Act which provide that regulations may be made to provide for, in the first case, product safety standards and, in the second case, product information standards. I will refer to them together because exactly the same amendment covers both section 62 and 63 of the principal Act. The position which has arisen is that regulations may apply to goods which are intended for sale overseas where requirements set here may not apply. One may take the example of a provision which might be in our legislation, perhaps relating to safety belts, but which is not the law in the country to which the car or other goods are being exported. As I understand it, the position which the Government and the Opposition take, is that manufacturers of goods which are intended for export should not be required to carry out various arrangements or provide certain facilities which are not required and perhaps not useable or desired in the country to which the goods are to go. That being the intention, the provision which is made in this Bill is that regulations may exclude- not that they necessarily will exclude- nom their operation goods of a kind set out in the regulations that are intended to be used outside Australia.

The Opposition in the House of Representatives proposed a further amendment, which was accepted by the Government, which required that a statement indicating that the goods were intended to be used outside Australia should be affixed to the goods. The purpose of this amendment was to bring to the attention of the users of the goods, if the goods were finally used in Australia, that the requirements had not been met because the goods were intended originally for export. As I said, the amendment was accepted by the Government and it is now in the Bill as it stands. As I understand the situation, the 2 clauses relating to goods intended for export will not have the effect of allowing inferior quality goods. But in view of the fact that overseas competition is difficult enough and that our goods should not be at a competitive disadvantage as against goods of other countries, it was essential that these amendments be made to the Bill.

The third proposal contained in the Bill concerns a problem that is probably better known, namely, the unsolicited forwarding of credit cards to people in Australia. This was a matter that caused a certain amount of furore for a period last year when bank cards were sent to hundreds and thousands of people. In some cases this action caused some anxiety and some annoyance. There seems to be some doubt as to whether very much harm came from this action. Apparently very few objections were made, according to the New South Wales Ministry of Consumer Affairs. On the other hand, it has been said that up to 80 or 100 cases of fraud lent misuse of those bank cards have taken place. Whatever may be the situation, there is no doubt that to many people the delivery of unsolicited bank cards caused a considerable annoyance. In addition, I understand that another scheme, the gold key credit card scheme in Queensland, involved the delivery of cards and that somewhat the same objections were raised. People who receive these credit cards were upset and annoyed. They did not know what to do with them. In some cases they felt that the cards might fall into the wrong hands. In addition there was complaint that the cards constituted a breach of privacy so far as the persons who received them were concerned. One might even feel that a certain amount of domestic disharmony may have been caused by the sudden arrival of credit cards, particularly where the amount of credit allocated to the wife was greater than that of the husband.

talk.start.para: That did not happen to you?

I hope not, senator. I am not prepared to disclose that because to do so would be a breach of privacy. But I would think that generally the arrival of such cards caused considerable upset to some people. There is a provision in the existing Act which relates to unsolicited goods but it is clear that this section does not cover the situation beyond any doubt so far as the sending of these cards is concerned.

continue.para: The Bill provides that in future a corporation shall not send a credit card to a person except, firstly, in pursuance of a request in writing by that person or, secondly, in the case of the renewal or replacement of or substitution for such a credit card or one that had been used for that purpose. In future corporations must obtain prior permission before such cards can be sent out. Failure to comply with this provision can attract a substantial penalty under section 79 of the principal Act. It seems to the Opposition that that likewise is a desirable course to be taken. I understand that the banks have agreed to the form of this legislation and recognise the necessity for it. The Opposition supports this amendment also.

No doubt other amendments to this very important legislation will be required from time to time, and these three are perhaps but minor ones in the scheme of things. There does appear to be some obscurity in the language of the Act which people are noting on close perusal. There seems to be some confusion in relation to consumer legislation and the extent to which there is overlapping between the Commonwealth and the State legislation. No doubt other more major amendments will be required from time to time, but these 3 amendments appear to be clearly desirable, and the Opposition gives its support.

talk.start.para: in reply- The Government is grateful to the Opposition for the helpful attitude it has taken to the Trade Practices Bill, both here and in the other place. As a matter of fact, as Senator Missen has mentioned, one of the amendments to this Bill was suggested by the Opposition when the Bill was being debated in the other place. I think it is generally conceded that this important piece of legislation, being a novel enactment which I think everyone has agreed is a great improvement on the body of law in this country, is naturally a measure which lends itself to amendment from time to time. Because of its novelty, we are proceeding in some spheres by trial and error and it is inevitable, as Senator Missen said, that there will be further amendments in the future as practice shows gaps or even flaws in the legislation.

speech.para: I think that the amendments and the attitude which the Opposition has taken to these amendments are in the general spirit in which this legislation was born. I know that Senator Murphy, as he then was, who pioneered this legislation was always open to suggestion for improvements. I can remember myself being lobbied by a group of businessmen who had seen a draft of the original Bill, who gave a lot of care and thought to the draft and who came along with a body of suggested amendments which in due course I took along to Senator Murphy and he and his advisers considered them seriously. Many of those amendments were ultimately embodied in the Bill which was presented to the Parliament. It is in that spirit that the Government sees the need for a constant scrutiny of the way in which this Act is working. It is for that reason that this Bill was introduced. As there is no contest in the matter, I am content to thank the Opposition for its co-operation.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 23 April on motion by Senator Bishop:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: The Opposition does not oppose this Bill and what I have to say will not take very long. It is a Bill which provides that procedures for reference and appeal to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission should apply with respect to disputes which arise under the Flight Crew Officers Tribunal. The Flight Crew Officers Tribunal was established in 1967. It is the body which deals with disputes existing or arising concerning pilots, navigators and flight engineers. These people come under the jurisdiction of the Flight Crew Officers Tribunal and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has no concern with them at the present time. The purpose of the Bill is to ensure that there is a means by which through appeal and reference these matters can be taken to the Commission. In short form, therefore, the Bill is essentially concerned with bringing these employees into the same position, broadly speaking, as other employees within the Commission's jurisdiction.

speech.para: The Government obviously believes that this step which it has taken is desirable and should be taken. I think the Government ought to heed the past experience of the dispute settling procedures relating to flight crew and allied personnel. There was a time in the 1950s when these employees were subject to the jurisdiction of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. My recollection is that the Air Pilots Association was a registered organisation under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The Air Pilots Association was either deregistered or voluntarily withdrew from the surveillance of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and for many years operated outside that Act. It was an achievement of some significance, I think in 1967, that enabled the Government, after consultation with the relevant persons, to establish the Flight Crew Officers Tribunal. That has been the body to which disputes which have occurred in the intervening years have been referred and it is by that Tribunal that the necessary arbitrated decisions have been able to be made. I understand that what has now happened is that the Government without consultation such a striking departure from those canons and conduct which when in Opposition it suggested the Liberal and National Country Parties should follow- has now decided to bring the flight crew officers under the jurisdiction of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We trust that this will operate to the benefit of the community and to those who are affected by any decisions which have to be made.

But the decision does enable one to point to some of the very subtle double standards which this Government engages in. I know that we have had before us in this Senate on a number of occasions a Bill which has not received the support of the Opposition. It is a Bill which seeks to establish a new concept of the public interest in the certification of agreements which are made by negotiation. The Government, of course, in 1972 made great play in its pre-election propaganda of the need to emphasise negotiation and conciliation and to play down any emphasis of arbitration. We heard much talk of meaningful negotiations and of the desirability of negotiated agreements being accepted. Of course the unreasonableness of this approach has been seen frequently in recent times when, as a result of negotiated agreements, immense salary claims have been made and conceded by the employers without regard to the consequences to the public, in particular to the flow-on consequences and to the relativities by which other workers are guided and the consequent desire on their part to maintain the traditional relativities which have applied. This has been a not insignificant feature in the bout of wage claims and excessive wage increases which has now received the condemnation of the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam) and I think of both the former and present Ministers for Labor and Immigration. This is one of the consequences of this plea for negotiated agreements to be recognised and to be accepted.

A provision in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act provides that such negotiated agreements are to be certified and made awards only if it is in the public interests that they are so treated as awards. The Government has not welcomed that provision and has sought to have it amended. That has been the subject matter of the Conciliation and Arbitration Bill which has come before this chamber from time to time and has not been passed by it. The reason it has not been passed is that the concept which the Bill has sought to introduce is a concept that the agreement shall be regarded as automatically applying unless someone can establish that there is grave detriment to the public interest. The imposition of that onus is an imposition which the Opposition has felt to be unreasonable. We believe that the whole purpose of establishing the conciliation and arbitration machinery contained in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act is to emphasise that conciliation is necessary in the public interest. If, in the public interest, conciliation does not achieve results there should be arbitration.

Going back to the original Conciliation an Arbitration Act which was established by Deakin it is apparent that the public interest was always the rationale and the motivation for legislation of this character. It has continued to be the motivation, and surely in this day and age it can be only the public interest which justifies conciliation and arbitration legislation. If we do not have that public interest concept warring factions of unions and employers can lead to endless dis put at on between themselves to the detriment of the public. It ought to be remembered that conciliation and arbitration legislation is legislation calculated to protect the community from the dislocation which such conflict, unregulated, can bring.

I have said that because this Bill flies right in the face of all that the Government has been attempting to do in its earlier legislation. In its earlier legislation it sought to remove from the Bill the requirement that things should be certified, should be referred or should be approved in the public interest. It seeks to put in place of that requirement this concept, which is left for someone undefined to raise, that things shall not be certified if a grave detriment to the public interest can be shown. But this Bill, of course, requires that the Commission shall do certain things; it shall entertain references and it shall entertain appeals if in the public interest it is desirable to do so. I invite the new Minister for Labor and Immigration (Senator James McClelland) to make a noteworthy striking contribution in, I think, the first debate in which he will engage in his new capacity and explain why it is that in the erstwhile Bill the concept of the public interest is removed and in this Bill the concept of the public interest is sought to be established as the criterion.

The second matter to which I refer in passing is another double standard in which the Government is engaged. It relates to whether or not the processes of conciliation by ministerial direction should be departed from in favour of arbitration. I seem to recall that it was not so long ago that it was accepted- certainly there are still some members of the Australian Labor Party who seek to develop this idea- that arbitration ought to be resorted to, if at all, only as a very last resort and that conciliation is the procedure which should be adopted. Consistently also it has been recognised that independent statutory bodies should not be interfered with by Government in order to achieve particular results- particularly results as to what should be the level of salaries and wages which are to be paid by particular employers. But we have become accustomed in recent times to the Minister for Transport (Mr Charles Jones) frequently complaining about the excessive wage claims and the excessive demands of various personnel within the jurisdiction of the Flight Crew Officers Tribunal. Whilst Mr Jones can only beat the air with regard to the Employees of Ansett Transport Industries he feels that he can take a different stand with regard to the employees under the control of the Australian National Airlines Commission- that is, Trans-Australiann Airlines.

I recall putting a question on notice some time ago after one of these outbursts by Mr Jones to ascertain whether the Minister did take action under the Australian National Airlines Act to direct the Commission as to the course it should follow. After some time I received a reply. I refer any honourable senator who is interested to the full question and answer which appears in the Senate Hansard of 4 March of this year. One question I asked was:
Does the Commission accept instructions from the Minister for Transport with respect to the salaries to be paid to its employees?
The answer I received- it contains a lot of words -was as follows:

The conditions applicable to the appointment of officers of the Commission are prescribed in section 17 of the Act. Subject to the provisions of awards and agreements, the Commission has power to determine the terms and conditions of employment of its staff. The rate of salary payable to the General Manager is determined by the Remuneration and Allowances Act 1973. The rates payable to other officers are determined by the Com mss ion subject to the approval of the Minister for Transport where the rate of salary exceeds $13,700 per annum.
I simply say that that is a fairly clear indication that in the higher levels of salary the Minister has a power which he may exercise. The next question I asked was:
Has the Commission accepted instructions from the Minister in respect of the recent claim by air pilots for a salary increase; if so, what were these instructions?
The significant reply was as follows:
The Commission was advised by me -

That is by the.Minister for Transport that the claims for salary increases by the Federation of Air Pilots should be determined by arbitration before the Flight Crew Officers Tribunal. Following this arbitration which resulted in a lower rate of increase than that agreed by Ansett Transport Industries and the Federation of Air Pilots, the Commission was informed that it should exercise its own managerial judgment and decide what changes in salaries and conditions it should agree with the Federation of Air Pilots.

There is a striking example of this Government arguing and directing that arbitration should take place in preference to conciliation, and, when arbitration resulted in the absurd situation that a lesser amount was arrived at by arbitration than had been agreed to by the Federation of Air Pilots and the other airline company, the Minister then says: 'Well, let there be an agreement reached'. It shows the absurdity of the Government's action, as well as its double standards.

talk.start.para: Could the arbitrator's mathematics not have been at fault, Senator?

It is quite possible, if the honourable senator wants to find that sort of extenuation, to justify what I think is otherwise an absolutely inexplicable piece of work on the part of the Minister. But I raise these matters, firstly, because this is an opportunity when they can be raised, and, secondly, because they highlight the inconsistencies for which this Government is becoming renowned. The Opposition offers no objection to the basic principle which is inherent in the legislation now before the Senate. It trusts the legislation will work in the public interest but it acknowledges that the way the Government has gone about such matters in its recent history in dealing with airline matters does not leave very much hope that it has learned by experience.

Despite the invitation from Senator Greenwood, I do not propose to embark on a long dissertation on the relationship of the public interest to arbitration legislation but I cannot forbear from saying a little in reply to the allegation that this is a government with double standards. We have heard- at least as long as I have been in this place I have heard- a constantly reiterated theme that this Government is soft on the unions; that it will not stand up to the unions; and that it has no wages policy. But in the last few days I think we have had a curious example of the double standards of the Opposition.

speech.para: If honourable senators opposite are really indignant about unilateral action by groups in the community to raise their living standards at the expense of the rest of the community and if they are outraged by defiance of decisions of arbitrators, one would have expected from them yesterday and today a long, moralistic dissertation on the recent conduct of the doctors throughout Australia. They have continued to rant against the metal workers and to point to the immorality of the people in that level of the wage structure thinking they are entitled to a bit more. But I have listened in vain for the slightest strictures on the already fairly well rewarded section of the community that belongs to the Australian Medical Association, which has thumbed its nose at an arbitrator appointed by themselves and which just baldly has told the community that it will insist on having everything to which it thinks it is entitled. I think this is as blatant an example of double standards as we have had in the matter of an appropriate rate of remuneration for various sections of the community.

Everything that the honourable senator who has just sat down said was irrelevant to the purpose of this Bill. This Bill merely aims to bring airline pilots into the same position as other sections of the community in respect of appeals from decisions of the tribunal which hears its applications in the first instance. I understand that this is a purpose which is concurred in by the Opposition. But I should like to remind Senator Greenwood also before I sit down of another apposite little piece of history in relation to this particular section of the community. I think it is particularly fitting to remind the honourable senator of this because of the situation the country finds itself in at the present time. I refer to the position that arose at the time of the last airline strike, about which the honourable senator expressed a few indignant remarks in respect of Mr Charles Jones.

What happened in the last airline strike was that the Government airline, Trans-Australiann Airlines, was prepared to resist what undoubtedly were insupportable demands by the pilots but that the ground was cut from beneath its feet by the private airline operator, Ansett Airlines of Australia, which caved in and gave the pilots what they wanted, leaving TAA no alternative but to follow suit. That was an example of the private employer sabotaging the arbitration system.

I would like to put on record a fear which I have in relation to the present actions which the Government is taking to ensure that a rational wages policy is followed by the work force in the present crisis of inflation. I hope my fear does not come true. I fear very much that the efforts which the Government is making to hold the line to reasonable wage increases at present will be sabotaged by individual employers. I fear that as an economic upturn arrives it will not be the unions which will sabotage the indexation decisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission but that individual greedy employers will succumb to pressure and we will find the ground cut from beneath the feet of arbitration again, in the same way as Sir Reginald Ansett cut the ground from beneath the feet of the Flight Crew Officers Industrial Tribunal at the time of the pilots' strike. Senator Greenwood talked about double standards, about the public interest and about an all-out effort to do something about inflation. I would remind him that he could well use his eloquence and his indignation in directions other than against the trade unions. He could suggest to some of the employers whom he knows that they should continue to respect arbitration. Next time he is unfortunate enough to have to go to his doctor I trust he will be as indignant to the doctor as he customarily is in this place to the metal workers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 13 May on motion by Senator Wriedt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: The Dried Fruits Export Charges Bill 1975 and the Dried Fruits Levy Bill 1975 are related measures. I wonder whether the Minister for Agriculture (Senator Wriedt) desires to have these Bills debated cognately.
I am agreeable to that course.

These Bills are of a machinery nature and can be dealt with expeditiously. The Opposition will not be opposing them. Both Bills relate to conversion from the imperial system of measurement to the metric system of measurement. Since 1970 there has been a progressive transition from the imperial system to the metric system of measurement of quantities. The dried vine fruit industry converted to metric measurement at the beginning of the current season on 1 March this year. The Australian Dried Fruits Control Board has recommended that legislative approval be given to the conversion.

continue.para: The purpose of the Dried Fruits Export Charges Bill is to obtain parliamentary approval for conversion to metric measurement of the maximum permissible rate of charge on exports of dried fruits as provided in the Dried Fruits Export Charges Act 1 924-1 970. There are 2 variations provided for in this Bill. The first provides for the metric unit, the kilogram, which is 2.2406 lb to be substituted for the imperial unit the pound. The second variation is that the maximum rate of charge which may be applied is varied from three-tenths of a cent per lb to seven tenths of a cent per kilogram. This is the nearest rational metric equivalent to the previous rate but results in an increase of 5.8 per cent in the maximum rate of charge. The Minister for Agriculture indicated in his second reading speech that the present rate of charge is 50 per cent only of the permissible maximum rate as prescribed in a regulation made under the Act. The moneys provided by the charge constitute the biggest part of the finances of the Australian Dried Fruits Control Board which is responsible for controlling the export, the sale and the distribution after export of Australian dried currants, sultanas and raisins.

The second Bill, the Dried Fruits Levy Bill, provides for 2 amendments. The first is that the metric unit, the tonne, is substituted for the imperial unit, the ton. The tonne, as honourable senators will know, is 2204 lb and the ton is 2240 lb. The maximum rate of levy which may be applied is varied from $ 1 per ton to $ 1 per tonne in the case of dried vine fruits, and from $5 per ton to $5 per tonne in respect to dried tree fruit. The effect of these variations, because of the difference in the number of pounds as between a tonne and a ton is an increase of 1.6 per cent in the maximum rates of levy. But again, as in the Dried Fruits Export Charges Bill, the rate is about 50 per cent of the maximum prescribed under regulation. The funds raised by the levy are applied to the financing of the Dried Fruits Research Committee which sponsors scientific, technical and economic research in connection with the production, processing and packaging of dried fruits- all worthy requirements.

As I have said, the Opposition does not oppose these measures; but I wish to take the opportunity of making reference to a matter which has close relevance to the dried fruits industry, particularly in South Australia, and which I think is related directly to the Dried Fruits Export Charges Bill because it provides for charges to that industry . I refer to the high level of salinity in the River Murray waters from time to time in South Australia, which is in fact becoming quite persistent and which is reaching levels disturbing to the fruit industries of South Australia dependent upon River Murray water for irrigation. I make the plea to the Minister and to the Government that a very close watch be kept in conjunction with the River Murray Commission and other authorities that this very pernicious increase in salinity be investigated and such action be taken from time to time as will alleviate this very serious problem.

We at the end of the line in the River Murray in South Australia suffer the effects of huge irrigation settlements above us. As the water is pushed out from the river to the surrounding lands and percolates back through saline strata we find this build-up of salty water coming down to the far end where we are, causing these aggravated problems both within our own areas of drainage back into the water of the Murray as with the pollution occurring higher up. I refer to this matter because it is in direct relationship to the well being of the industry which is being converted to metric measurement. The well being of this industry is so closely aligned to the availability of reasonably sweet water that I make this plea this afternoon as we discuss these Bills. The Opposition does not oppose the measures that are now before us.

talk.start.para: I am pleased, of course, that the Opposition is not opposing the legislation as Senator Laucke has indicated. One may express some disappointment, I think, that the Government was not a little more generous because when the floods occurred originally there was an immediate response by both the Federal and State Governments, the flooding having caused some loss of life and considerable damage to Seymour and buildings in the area. talk.start.para: in reply- I thank the Opposition for supporting the Bill. It is not a matter of assisting flood victims. Assistance is given on the same pro rata basis in respect of other flood mitigation work. Agreement has been reached between the Australian Government and the Victorian Government. This legislation appropriates the money that is required. I thank the Opposition for a speedy passage of this legislation.
