talk.start.para: Mr President, I ask whether the Special Minister of State (Senator Douglas McClelland) is prepared to have a cognate second reading debate on orders of the day Nos 13, 14, 15, 16 and 17 and 5 separate divisions on the Bills?

talker.role: Manager of Government Business in the Senate
talker.name: MCCLELLAND, Douglas
Senator Douglas McClelland

talk.start.para: I agree.

interjection.para: The PRESIDENT- There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.
Government supporters- Put them all in.

talk.start.para: I am tempted to accede to the wishes of the Government senators but I think we might have different stances on different Bills. I do not think we can follow that course. I speak on the 5 Bills which provide for the proposed redistributions. I put to the Senate that the Government's action in presenting these Bills to the Senate exposes the Government in its true colours. By its own actions the Government has admitted that it is not interested in genuine electoral reform; it is interested, however, in creating a gerrymander. It is determined by whatever means possible to do everything it can to perpetuate itself in office, even while it is tearing itself apart internally. If that requires rigging the boundaries, if that requires overlooking the laws of the land, then this Government will do so. Integrity and honesty have flown out the window. Principles have been replaced with opportunism. This Government will take any steps it considers necessary to achieve its objectives and its chief objective is to stay in power by so rigging the system that it cannot be removed. It is not concerned with being a good Government. It is not concerned with winning the support of the people through achievements, but it is concerned with manipulating the rules of the game to its own advantage. It wants to play with a stacked deck.

continue.para: The boundaries which these Bills seek to impose upon the electorate have already been rejected once by the Senate. They were rejected because they were unfair. The arguments have already been canvassed and I will not take up the Senate's time by going through them again in detail. I shall say only this: The proposed new boundaries would protect the Government from any reasonable swing against it. Worse, if the 1974 results were repeated, the Government would end up with a majority in the House of Representatives of eleven instead of the present majority of five. In fact that would be less when we win Bass in Tasmania on 28 June. So by stacking the deck the Government would end up with an increase of six in its floor majority. Therefore I can understand why the Government wants these proposed boundaries. They are not bad boundaries at all for the Government. But I say quite flatly that it is a fiddle. No matter what the Government may say this fact remains. The Government has embraced these boundaries because they are the best it can get. They provide the Government with an unfair advantage.

If the Government gets away with this attempt to fiddle with the electoral laws it will become impossible to remove the Government no matter how much damage it does to the economy, no matter how many people it throws out of work, no matter how many people suffer from its inflationary policies. I put it to the Senate that if the Government were honest, if it were fair, if it were not opportunist, it could have easily overcome the Senate's distrust of the boundaries embodied in this legislation. The electoral law itself spells out the methods by which a government can deal with a distribution which is rejected by one House or the other. Perhaps we are being a little too optimistic in expecting the Government to honour the electoral laws.

This Government talks a lot about convention. What it means is that the conventions it wants should be observed. But the conventions that in any way attempt to check its abuse of power are always overlooked. The Government wants one law for the people and another for itself. As I have said, the electoral law itself provides simple and proper machinery to deal with this problem.

Section 24 of the Act provides quite simply for the Government to refer the distributions back to the Commissioners if either House rejects them. The Commissioners can then redraw the boundaries and come up with another proposal, which the Parliament may once again consider. That course is proper and correct. It was included in the legislation to overcome the present situation.

Yet the Government, once again, has chosen to by-pass the law. I ask: Why is it by-passing the law? I answer by saying: Because it fears what might happen. I put to the Senate that the cynicism of the Government has now been exposed. While the Government talks about these boundaries being fair, the real position is that the Government knows these boundaries are unfair. They would help the Government resist the will of the people. They would allow it to take even more unpopular measures and remain in office despite the desire of the majority of voters to throw them out. That is the real reason why the Government promotes these Bills. Once again this Government is trying to disguise its deceit.

Once again it tries to rush through the Parliament legislation which it hopes will escape scrutiny. In the other place the Government allowed only 4 hours debate on the Bills, claiming urgency. I ask: What urgency, Mr President? There is no election for the House of Representatives due until May 1977, which is almost 2 years away. What the Government is trying to do is sneak these Bills through the Parliament now and hope the electorate will forget about this fraud by the time the day of reckoning arrives. I note that the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam), in speaking on these Bills in another place, tried to bluff the Opposition into letting them pass. He said:

In the event of continued Senate obstruction to any of the 5 Bills, we shall allow the people of Australia yet another opportunity to endorse, as they did last May, the principle of equality of representation in the Australian Parliament.
If the Senate again rejects this principle, that rejection will again be an issue on which the people will be able to pass judgment.

I say only this about the argument the Prime Minister tried to put up: If he talks about equality of voting, he talks rubbish. The Constitution itself ignores equality of voting. The Prime Minister himself ignores this principle. Only last year the people rejected his attempt to insert in the Constitution a clause which would have required electorates to be based on total numbers, not on numbers of voters. I ask: What sort of equality is that? It totally ignores the Prime Minister's own avowed dedication to the principle of one-vote one-value. What he tried to insert in the Constitution means one vote with varying values. It would have been another way of manipulating the electorate in favour of the Labor Party. The people saw through that ploy and rejected it.

The plain fact is that there cannot be total equality of voting. The redistribution proposals now contained in these Bills do not even pretend to be equal. The quota in Queensland is 64 842; in Victoria it is 63 507; in New South Wales it is 62 765; in Western Australia it is 62 071; but in Tasmania the quota is 49 198, in the Australian Capital Territory it is about 53 500, and in the Northern Territory it is about 39 386. So much for this principle which the Prime Minister claims to endorse, but conveniently overlooks. I say without reservation that once again he is talking hogwash.

Apart from paying ex-service to these grand principles, the Prime Minister has also issued a threat. He tried to say that he would make these boundaries an election issue. To that we reply: Good. There is nothing we would welcome more. We would enjoy the chance to campaign on this gerrymander and on this deceitful attempt by the Government to keep itself in power forever so that it can wreak more havoc on the community. We know what the voters would say. Once again we see the Prime Minister shooting off his mouth, trying to bluster and bully people into giving him his way. I say this now quite deliberately: If the Prime Minister wants an election, we will welcome it. We will do nothing to prevent it. We would enjoy it.

I say to the Prime Minister and his supporters: The Government already has the grounds for a double dissolution. We do not apologise for that. He can go to the polls any time. But that is a decision for him and we intend to leave that decision to him. Does he want to face the people now, after the fiascos and fur ores in his own Party room? Will Dr Cairns and Dr Cass be supporting him at the polls? Will his rural rump be on his side? Will this dividend mishmash, this collection of vested interests, these dinosaurs, the brontosaurus of the Cabinet and the brachiosaurus of the Caucus be prepared to put their big black cars and their office suites at risk? I fear they Will not. They fear the people. They know that their hold on office is slipping away from them. But they will deliberately try to keep that hold for as long as they can. But the Prime Minister can ignore them, Mr President. It is he who decides when to have an election.

If the Prime Minister feels so strongly about his bid to rig the system, he can jump into his white elephant and drive out to Yarralumla and ask for a poll. We will hold open the door of his car for him. Then he can go to the people and ask them if they want Labor to govern forever, because that is what will happen if Labor wins another election and is able to put these Bills on to the statute book. Give Labor absolute control of both Houses of Parliament and we will never be able to vote them out, because the Prime Minister does not want democracy. He wants complete unbridled power. He has already tried to abuse what power he has been given. I ask: Would the voters be prepared to give him more? I answer: They would not. He will not bully the Opposition by threatening us with an election, even though he might be able sometimes to bully his own back bench, and force his own Deputy to back down. I say quite openly: We will fight him any time he chooses. If he wants to fight on this gerrymander, then let him fight now. Let him put his job on the Une, if he dares.

For too long the Prime Minister had bluffed and bullied his way- in the Parliament, in the Cabinet, in the Caucus. Caucus may be afraid of him, Cabinet may be afraid of him, but we are not. We know that he is a man who has deserted his one time friends. Do honourable senators remember Harradine, Crean and Barnard? If the Prime Minister was sincere, if he is the man of courage and principle that his image makers make him out to be, let him show that courage now. Let him go to the polls now on boundaries that are fair and equitable, on boundaries that are not rigged to guarantee him control of the Parliament. We are prepared to call his bluff. Is he man enough to go through with it?

talk.start.para: One wishes at times that Senator Withers would revise his speech. He seems to use the same copy but adds a few words each time a redistribution proposal comes into the House. However, one thing was clearer in his speech tonight and that is that Senator Withers had very seriously charged senior public servants across Australia. He said tonight that the redistribution proposal we have before us is a fiddle, a gerrymander, a fraud and it is deceitful. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the parent legislation, passed by this Parliament, which provided the basis for this redistribution. It provides for none of these things to take place in any redistribution. The parent legislation is entirely fair and no one in this House can say otherwise. It set out the basis for a redistribution with a tolerance of 10 per cent between electorates instead of 20 per cent. Nothing in that legislation makes it a fiddle, a gerrymander, a deceit or a fraud. So if the parent legislation is entirely free of those faults and crimes it must be, by Senator Wither's definition, the people who drew the boundaries who are responsible for these things. There is no other construction that one can put on the development and evolvement of this redistribution.

speech.para: Senator Withersby his remarks here tonight has charged very serious crimes against the public servants, people of the community in each State. The Chief Electoral Officer in each State is, by Senator Wither's definition, responsible for producing a deceit and a fraud. This allegation is extremely serious and is a slur of the greatest magnitude on officers of the Public Service for whom I and most Australians have the highest regard. What is Senator Withers going to do about his charge? Will he continue to skulk in here, redistribution after redistribution, presentation after presentation, using insults instead of logic, forgetting the public in interpreting his own Party attitudes and so shaming many of his back benchers that they will not come into the House to listen to him? I suggest that Senator Withers confront these people who created this fraud, that he goes out into the public and charges the public servants with having done so. No one else could have done it.

The parent legislation is clean, easily interpreted legislation which is fair to every reader of any political persuasion. I believe that it is up to Senator Withers to produce real reasons instead of insults to public servants for his continued opposition to what every political writer in the country has said is the fairest redistribution Australia has ever seen. I for one want to be absolutely dissociated from the most unjust, unfair and disgraceful charges that Senator Withers made tonight against senior public servants.

talk.start.para: What do the country people in South Australia think about it?

As Senator Jessop knows, the country people in South Australia are heartily in favour of fair electoral systems. At the last electoral test in that State they threw Senator Withers' party out, it being defeated by the other major political party by 46 per cent of the vote to 29 per cent. That is what they did to Senator Jessop 's Party.
You are a Judas. The country people in South Australia say you are a Judas.
Senator Jessop says that I am a Judas -
I did not say that.

Senator Jessop mouths other people's words, like Senator Withers, in this House. He disgracefully mouths insulting words. Of course, he can produce no evidence to back the use of those words. Senator Jessop knows the results that will ensue in South Australia. As the last senator on the ticket for the Liberal Party, he has a very limited life in this House, thank goodness. I suggest that Senator Jessop do something rather noble and take an attitude on this legislation according to the last test vote in South Australia taken, as I have said before, in one of the more conservative country areas. The people heartily endorsed the fair electoral proposals which were propounded throughout the lengthy campaign preceding a by-election. However I do not want to develop this long argued issue. Senator Jessop knows that he attended a declaration of the poll relating to the Senate at which one of his running mates said that he did not believe in the principle of one vote one value. He publicly said that to representatives of the Press who were assembled on that occasion. Senator Jessop is branded as a party man who believes in different values for voting.
Do not wag your finger at me, Senator.
All I can say is that Senator Jessop should explain to the Senate why his colleague, Mr Nessmer said to the public as late as last year that the Liberals do not believe in voting equality.
Why is that?

I do not know why. Why would they not believe that people should be equal under the law? I do not know, except that they have a history of being dominated by the Legislative Council in South Australia, a situation they will never get out of. Senator Withers talked exactly like a South Australian Legislative Councillor. The records of Hansard for the last 30 years show the model for his speech year after dismal year. The result, of course, was the depression of the Liberal vote in South Australia on such a permanent basis that there had to be a revolution on the Liberal side to achieve any success.

continue.para: I end by saying that it is up to Senator Withers to step outside the stereotyped speech he makes in which he hurls insults at others, and of course diminishes his own Party in so doing, and to lay the charges directly where he means them to be- at the feet of the public servants who drew electoral boundaries which are the basis of the fairest of all pieces of legislation. There can be no other construction. I sit down knowing that I sit on a side where the Leader of the Opposition lays charges at the feet of public servants who Crew these boundaries, and I am ashamed of his statement.

talk.start.para: This debate had become a hardy perennial since August of last year when the subject of reform of the Commonwealth electoral laws was dealt with by a Joint Sitting of both Houses of Parliament. The legislation now before the Senate results from that Joint Sitting. The Joint Sitting dealt with electoral legislation, one of the reasons for a double dissolution of the Parliament, and which was one of the election issues put to the people in May 1974. The Joint Sitting decided that the Distribution Commissioners for tie various States should be permitted a variation in the number of electors within a division of 10 per cent above or below the quota instead cf the previously prevailing variation of 20 per cent.

speech.para: Regrettably Senator Withers' remarks this evening are not a defence of his attitude, his Party's attitude or the attitude of the National Country Party of Australia to the 5 Electoral Bills hi respect of Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania now before the House. He used the debate to launch an unwarranted and uncalled for diatribe of criticism, if not abuse, against the Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam). We heard Senator Withers in his typical fashion talk about dinosaurs and brachiosaurs, and at o.ie stage I think he had white elephants opening doors. Frankly, all the remarks by Senator Withers concerning the Prime Minister were pointless and irrelevant to the legislation. As Senator HaU has said, Senator Withers, by his simple use of the term 'gerrymander' and alleging that the legislation now before the House was to protect gerrymanders that had been given up by Distribution Commissioners, that it was legislation of deceit and that it was legislation of fraud, was accusing in one breath and finding guilty in another the independent Distribution Commissioners who have been charged apparently with acting with political bias.

I do not think that that is fair on the part of the Opposition because in respect of each of the Spates the Distribution Commissioners drew up boundaries for approval by both Houses of the Australian Parliament as a result of a law enacted by both Houses at a Joint Sitting. They acted in accordance with that law and drew the boundaries in accordance with that law. The simple fact is that it is the law- npt the bound" aries but the boundaries based on the law- that does not suit the Country Party and. in some instances, I suppose, the Liberal Party, and therefore the combined Opposition in this chamber has decided to reject the legislation, as it rejected the redistribution proposals a week or so before last week. As my colleague Senator Willesee, who is the representative in this chamber of the Minister for Services and Property, said when the Government introduced the legislation a couple of weeks ago:

The Government has decided to introduce S separate Bills to implement the Distribution Commissioners' proposed electoral divisions for South Australia, Tasmania, Queensland, Victoria and New South Wales.
Those are the 5 States to which I have referred. He went on to say:

This action has been taken because of the uncompromising attitude adopted by the Opposition Parties in this chamber towards the redistribution proposals for each of the 5 States concerned. In rejecting all -

Not one but all- the redistribution proposals, both Opposition Parties have been motivated by their objection to the basic redistribution ground rules as set out in section 19 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, . . .
Of course, those ground rules must be observed by the Distribution Commissioners when they give consideration to the drawing up of boundaries. Senator Willesee went on to say:
Accordingly, it is quite clear that there would be no point in the Minister - *

That is, the Minister for Services and Property- directing the Distribution Commissioners to propose a fresh distribution in the States concerned, as allowed under section 24 (2) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

No matter how often the Minister referred the matter back to the respective Distribution Commissioners in each of the States the Opposition Parties would reject the proposals, irrespective of the boundaries that were drawn up, whilst they collectively were opposed to the ground rules on which the boundaries were based. The Government does not overlook the possibility, as Senator Willesee said when introducing the legislation, that the Opposition may even choose to reject the Bills themselves. Nevertheless we believe that the redistributions have become a matter of urgent necessity because of the inequality in representation on the boundaries that now exist. We believe that the legislation is of urgent necessity in. order to provide equality of representation for every elector.

I think it was Senator Hall who said that the proposed boundaries embodied in the legislation presently before the Parliament have been described as being the fairest set of redistribution proposals that has ever been presented to the Australian Parliament. Mr Malcolm Mackerras, the noted electoral analyst, and well known commentator on elections generally, has gone on record as saying:

In overall political terms, the 1975 redistribution is the fairest set of proposed boundaries ever to be presented to any Australian Parliament in my lifetime. The Commissioners have bent over backwards to avoid any suggestion of gerrymandering. They have set out to draw boundaries so patently fair that rejection by the Senate would reflect discredit on the Senate not on the Commissioners.

Lest there by any doubt as to the Opposition's motives in relation to this matter I point out that shortly after the Joint Sitting of both Houses in August 1974 laid down the ground rules for the Distribution Commissioners to follow in their drawing up of the boundaries- within about 6 weeks of the Joint Sitting of both Houses, namely, on 30 September 1974- Mr Anthony, the Leader of the National Country Party of Australia, set out in an article in the Melbourne Age' that his Party's objections to the redistribution were on the grounds that they were premature and unnecessary. The right honourable gentleman was reported in the article which appeared in the Melbourne 'Age' of 30 September as having said:

When the new boundaries are presented to Parliament, every Country Party member and senator will vote against their implementation. We are confident that our Liberal colleagues share our views, and that the proposed boundaries will be defeated in the Senate.

So well before the Commissioners had drawn the boundaries and long before the boundaries had been presented to this Parliament, the Leader of the National Country Party was saying that irrespective of what boundaries were drawn, because the size of the electorate would be based on a one-tenth variation instead of the previous one-fifth variation the National Country Party and its ally the Liberal Party would reject the legislation in the Senate.

On past performances, I think we all know the fate of the legislation we are now considering. Nonetheless, we believe a principle of equality is involved and that we should carry out the wishes of the elected representatives of this Parliament. Therefore I suggest that the second reading of the legislation should be agreed to by the Senate.

We are pleased to see that there is provision in the States Grants (Universities) Bill for the preliminary funding for the Deakin University in Victoria and we welcome the progress that is being made to achieve further tertiary level opportunities for education in that State.

continue.para: It is opportune at this time to note that there has been an announcement from the Government of the amalgamation of the tertiary commissions, that is, the amalgamation of the Australian Universities Commission and the Commission on Advanced Education. We will be looking forward to the developments that are undertaken with regard to the merging of the two Commissions and the effect that this will have on the plans for tertiary education in this country in the future. It was of interest to us to see the announcement and it was of interest to read that it had been taken without consultation with the Australian Universities Commission. I take it that deep thought had been given before the amalgamation was announced. As I understand it, it will not affect the funding for the next triennium, for which we are expecting to receive reports in the very near future.

I want to take this opportunity to ask a question with regard to the funding for tertiary education and how this is handled with the tertiary institutions. I would be interested to have a response from the Special Minister of State (Senator Douglas McClelland) with regard to what system is operative, when we take for granted that universities and colleges must make some forecast of student intake and courses, which they expect to be undertaken in the forthcoming year or in the triennium. I am wondering what the position will be when admissions are finalised, what the relationship will be between the forecast figures and those which are actually achieved in the courses and the particular studies, what action is to be taken by the tertiary institution to show the relationship between what has been forecast and what has been achieved, and what action is to be taken if minimum numbers for courses as have been forecast are not achieved. I think that in the interests of dealing with the Bills, which are providing for a great deal of additional funds for tertiary education, some response from the Minister with regard to the arrangements that are being made in these circumstances would be welcomed by the Opposition.

The figures in the 2 Bills represent quite a deal of finance. With regard to the universities we see that $104m is to be applied as additional expenditure. It is an undertaking by Government to fund the increases that have occurred, but it brings to mind the inflation which is evident in the economy that such massive funds are required in addition to those that have already been dealt with through the normal funds in the States Grants (Universities) Bills and the States Grants (Advanced Education) Bills. With these brief remarks, Mr Deputy President, the Opposition does not oppose these 2 Bills with which we are dealing. I should be interested to hear the response from the Minister with regard to the funding arrangements.

talk.start.para: The Government is appreciative of the speedy passage being given to these 2 education Bills that are now the subject of debate before the Senate- the States Grants (Advanced Education) Bill 1975 and the States Grants (Universities) Bill 1975. 1 respond briefly to the first point made by Senator Guilfoyle when she referred to the lack of consultation with the Universities Commission and the Commission on Advanced Education as a result of the Government's decision to weld the two into a single statutory body. The Prime Minister (Mr Whitlam) issued a Press statement on the matter on 30 May- about a week ago- which, for the benefit of the record, I shall read. It stated:

speech.para: The Prime Minister, the Honourable E. G. Whitlam, stated today that after consultation with the Minister for Education, the Honourable Kim E. Beazley, he has decided to amalgamate the Universities Commission and the Commission on Advanced Education into a single statutory advisory body to the Australian Government on universities and colleges.
I interpolate here to indicate that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Education (Mr Beazley) had consultation on the matter. The Press statement continued:

The Prime Minister said that notwithstanding the close working relationship which exists between the 2 Commissions the balanced development of the provision of university and advanced education throughout Australia would benefit from the creation of a single body.

The Secretary of the Department of Education, Mr K. N. Jones, the Chairman of the Universities Commission, Professor P. H. Karmel, and the Chairman of the Commission on Advanced Education, MrT. B. Swanson, have been asked to recommend how the amalgamation may best be put into effect. The panel, with Mr Jones as convener, will consult with interested parties and will make its recommendations in time for legislative action to be taken during the Budget Session of the Parliament later this year.

Therefore, both the Chairman of the Universities Commission and the Chairman of the Commission on Advanced Education will play a prominent part in making recommendations as to how best to give effect to the decision that has been arrived at by the Government as a result of discussions between the Prime Minister and the Minister for Education to weld the 2 bodies into an independent statutory authority.

talk.start.para: I was making the point that no consultation apparently had been undertaken before the announcement was made.

It was a decision by the Government and decisions are taken by government. It obviously has been taken as as result of ministerial changes that recently have been implemented. It is a decision taken by government and, that decision having been taken by government- let us face it, government is responsible for making governmental decisions- it will best be carried out as a result of consultation with Professor Karmel and Mr Swanson. On the matter of the figures to which Senator Guilfoyle alluded, I am advised by the advising officers sitting alongside me, who come from the Department of Education, that student numbers are predicted triennial by universities and the Commission on Advanced Education. Generally the predictions have been within 2 per cent to 3 per cent of actual numbers and, according to the advice given to me by the departmental offices, there have been only one or two exceptions. Actual numbers are set out in the Commission's sixth report, which I am advised will be issued shortly. The honourable senator will realise that I am only the Minister representing the Minister for Education. I will certainly endeavour to obtain from the Department of Education for the honourable senator any additional information that might be available in the Department concerning figures. As I have said, the Government appreciates the speedy passage that the Opposition is giving to these 2 important pieces of education legislation.

continue.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: This Bill will result in an agreement between the Federal Government and the Government of South Australia with respect to a proposal that the Australian Government take over the rural railway system, certain workshops and other matters concerned with that railway system in South Australia. The Postmaster-General (Senator Bishop) will recall that at the time the Australian National Railways Bill was debated in this chamber I said to him that it was regrettable that the Senate had not been given an opportunity to discuss the suggested terms of agreement for such railway takeovers because I felt that such an agreement must form the basis of future takeovers by the Australian Government should they be requested by a particular State.

speech.para: Already we have seen the reaction of the Tasmanian Government with respect to the proposal of taking over railways in that State. I understand that the Legislative Council in Tasmania expressed some reservations about it. I believe that the Bill before the Senate is currently being debated in the State Assembly in South Australia, I have spoken with members of the Opposition in that State and they have already demonstrated some reservations about this Bill. They have every reason to be concerned about it. Firstly, the State Government has no mandate to ask the Federal Government to take over the rural rail system in that State. On that ground alone I think that the State Parliament and the Legislative Council in particular would be justified in rejecting this Bill outright. I had a word with the Postmaster-General the other day and suggested that it was possible that amendments will arise as a result of the debate in the State Parliament on this Bill and that it might be prudent in the interests of time in this pressing end of session period that he defer the BUI until the August session. I am certain that the chamber will be debating this matter again at that time.

I believe that reservations could be held by the South Australian Government quite properly over the proposal to take over one part of the railway system in isolation. The Minister will recall that after the debate on the Australian National Railways Bill in this place the trade union attitude in South Australia was one of hostility to the proposal. It appeared to me, according to Press statements that I have read, that the trade union movement was certainly not happy about the taking over of the rural railway lines in South Australia in isolation from the urban system. Its comment at that time was that the Aus.tralian Government ought to take over the whole system or none of it at all. I think this attitude could well be the one that would be adopted by the State Parliament if the proposal in that direction goes through the Legislative Council.

Other matters that I have immediately in my mind question the attitude of the State Opposition to providing the railway lines in South Australia in those rural areas with an unfair advantage over private land transport operators, particularly in country areas. The Minister will be aware of the fact that in South Australia, as I have no doubt in other States, the road transport operators are required to pay road tax into the State coffers. Does the Australian Government intend to pay into the State Government Treasury in South Australia from railway revenue a sum equivalent to the road tax demanded of private land transport operators in that State? This in my view seems to be a logical question that would be raised in the minds of members of the State Opposition in South Australia. There are many other matters that ought to be questioned. For example clause 10 of the Bill states:
On and after the declared date, the Commission may-
(a) administer, maintain and operate in South Australia the railways and services acquired under the agreement; and

(b) construct and extend railways in South Australia in accordance with the Agreement and administer, maintain and operate railways so constructed or extended and services (including passenger and freight road services) incidental or supplementary to, or associated with, those railways.

That is another area of concern that I have in mind, and I am sure that my colleagues in the State Parliament would share my concern on this particular matter. It seems to me that the Australian Government would be in a position to take over or run road passenger and freight services in South Australia to supplement the services of the railways. I believe that there is a danger here to private road contractors who have been providing a good service to South Australians over a long period of time. This Bill seems to me to add up to the usual incompetent bull at agate system of this Government. I believe that in this Bill the Government is placing the cart before the horse. It seems to me to be a quite reasonable suggestion to put to the Minister that the State governments ought to have been consulted with respect to this Agreement before it was discussed in this chamber.

I point out these things to the Minister because it seems to me that we are going to be faced with another debate on this issue in this chamber. I was talking this afternoon to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the House of Assembly in South Australia, the Honourable John Combe and he told me that the Opposition in that House had considered this Agreement and was going to vote against it completely. I do not know what will be the attitude of the Upper House because it will consider its legislation in its own way and will review it in a responsible manner, as it has done with legislation in the past. I believe that there are some members in that chamber who will share the view of the Assembly Opposition and may choose to reject the legislation completely. If they do not do that, then it is inevitable that they will bring amendments before the chamber, and the Senate will be faced with another debate in August.

I do not think there is anything more I need say about this measure. I believe that I will have another opportunity to speak on it when it is re-presented to the Senate. I do suggest to the Minister that he would have been well advised to delay the discussion of this Bill until the August sittings, when the Senate would have been in a position to determine the wishes of the State Parliament on this matter.

talk.start.para: In reply- May I thank the Opposition for stating that it will not oppose the Bill. Senator Jessop was concerned that the South Australian legislature now might amend the South Australian Bill and he talked about the reaction in Tasmania. I have made inquiries about the position in Tasmania, where the Legislative Council inserted some amendments which were later accepted -
We are not dealing with the Tasmanian Bill yet.
I am replying to Senator Jessop.
Order! I will allow some latitude in this matter. Senator Jessop intruded this issue into the debate and the Minister is entitled to respond in the same vein.

I refer to Tasmania only because Senator Jessop raised it. He said that he was concerned about the reaction in Tasmania. As far as the Australian Government and the South Australian Government are concerned- I have discussed with the South Australian Government the amendments which have been moved in Tasmania- neither Government is concerned about them because all that they do in fact is ensure that the Minister in that State and/or the Parliament will be aware of what might happen in relation to the closing down of railway lines or in relation to freights and fares. Perhaps I should read what has been inserted. Clause 9 of the Tasmanian Bill reads as follows:

continue.para: It is hereby declared by the Parliament that freight rates applying to the railways in the State are of concern to the State and the State shall request the Australian Minister or his delegate to consult with the State on all proposals to fix or vary those rates and, in any such consultation, shall maintain the view that those rates should not be fixed at a higher level than those applying to railways of the Commonwealth outside the State.
Clause 10 of the same Bill reads:

Where, by resolution, either House of Parliament declares that the cessation of any railway service is undesirable the State shall, unless that resolution be rescinded, dispute the cessation of that service by the Australian Commission.
Consequently where the closing down of a line is involved the matter would be taken to arbitration and the Parliament and the State Government would know about it.

In my opinion the position in South Australia is quite different. The South Australian Government and the Australian Government have reached a very amicable agreement. I think the terms of the agreement are very favourable to the South Australian Government. Paragraph 8(1) of the Schedule to the Bill reads: 8(1) The Commission will ensure that, in general, fares, freight rates and other charges in respect of the non metropolitan railways and services shall be maintained, on and after the commencement date, at levels not less favourable to users than those levels generally applying on the railways of States other than South Australia and where, in general, fares, freight rates and other charges at the commencement date have established a relative advantage to the users, that advantage shall not be diminished.

If honourable senators care to read the other principles set out in that Schedule they will find that it is a very favourable agreement. I think the agreement favours South Australia. The agreement was reached with a State in which the railway systems are very well developed and are based, as everybody knows, on basic productive capacity particularly at the Islington workshop which has a long history dating back to the days of rehabilitation when I worked there in 1927 and when Mr Webb, the American, brought

American methods of production into the railway system. That South Australian railway system with about 10 000 kilometres of track is a very advanced system, and the agreement is related to such a system. Provision is made for guarantees which should apply. They are the benefits to the State.

Senator Jessoptalked about the early reactions of the unions to the proposed takeover. The unions met the Minister for Transport, Mr Jones, on 2 occasions and in addition the State Minister for Transport, Mr Virgo, has talked to the unions. I am told that at present the unions are in favour of the agreement. They think the proposal is an improvement. As honourable senators know, the State employees will in future be members of the Australian National Railways. The whole of the agreement has to be looked at on the basis of existing losses, which are tremendous. For example, the loss for non-metropolitan railways in South Australia for the forthcoming year is estimated to be as high as $23m. Under the agreement South Australia will receive an amount of $10m for the conveyance of assets, mineral rights, etc., to the national Government. As far as I am aware the South Australian Government and the union movement are very happy with the arrangements. There will of course be an interim period during which the transfer has to be executed. There has to be some general co-ordination in the transference of such things as classifications, safe working rules, and train control procedures to adjust to Commonwealth standards. I have had conversations recently with the Government and with the unions as Senator Jessop had mentioned and I am satisfied that what has been done in respect of South Australia has been favourably received.

In relation to the question of road transport, I would like to remind Senator Jessop of something of which he is well aware. Any raU system in any part of the country always has had to pay for its own road works and earth works. It is not so with road transport. The various States impose various road charges in an attempt to recover from the road users, including the operators of the very heavy vehicles which carry freight which aU of us often consider ought to be on the railways, the cost of maintenance of the highways. I think it is fair to state that in no way do those charges cover the cost of highways. State railway systems have to pay for their own road works and often they have road services competing against them, often running alongside the railways. One frequent criticism is that there is a lack of co-ordination and in these days this situation really is quite illogical.

As to the other matters relating to road competition which might concern the honourable senator, he will recall that when the first memorandum of agreement came into the Senate it was pointed out that we had accepted an agreement which was opposed by the Opposition in the other place, which made it clear that the road services which would be developed, operated and used by the rail system would be those which are incidental to the system. We all know that the railway road services are run in conjunction with various train movements. They have to have a road system. Road motor sections operate satisfactorily in many States. Of course they are restricted under the State Acts and they will be restricted under the Federal Act because we have accepted, as all honourable senators know, an arrangement which was proposed as a criticism.

I think those are the main things to which I want to refer. If honourable senators are doubtful about the benefits of the agreement to South Australia they should look at the detailed Schedule at the back of the Bill. It is a most exhaustive statement and it developed from conferences with the South Australian authorities. I think the details are more particular and specific in the case of the agreement with South Australia because the rail system in that State is much larger. The agreement guarantees, for example, the strengthening of the line from Adelaide to Murray Bridge and also refers to matters relating to the outer harbour connection to the future container berths. There are other matters relating to the South Australian system. The agreement is more particular because the South Australian system is much larger than the Tasmanian system. The rail mileage in Tasmania is about 2000 as compared with 10 000 miles in South Australia. I thank the Senate for its comments.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: The Bill.

talk.start.para: I understand and agree completely with the principle of the Australian Government taking over interstate railway systems. I do not think a great amount of argument could be presented against that proposition. I believe it is an area where the Australian Government could effect some economies. However, I can see that questions would arise in the minds of South Australian members of Parliament, particularly those in the Opposition who exert some responsibility in regard to this matter, about administrative difficulties presented by the Australian Government taking over the rural railway lines alone, divorced completely from the urban railway system. I should like the Minister to consider that aspect and tell me how he will ensure that there is to be a smooth functioning between those 2 systems in South Australia.

speech.para: The Minister referred to matters of detail contained in certain schedules in the latter part of the Bill. Here I believe is a case in point where these matters of detail must demand comment from and approval of the State Parliament. I must remind the Minister that there has been no mandate for this proposal. It seems to me that the Australian Government always throws up to us on this side of the chamber that it has a mandate to do this and to do that. But surely the State Parliament must have some mandate from the people, enunciated in the election speech of the Premier of South Australia, to request the Aus.tralian Government to take over this section of the railways. In my view that highlights the concern that could arise and has arisen in the minds of Opposition members of the State Parliament with respect to this measure.

I must say that I was pleased to hear the Minister say that the road transport systems which are affected by this Bill will be incidental to the existing railway systems. I should like the Minister's assurance that the Government has no thought of taking over other private road transport systems in South Australia. These matters are of concern to me and to my colleagues in South Australia. Another aspect I should like to mention is that as I understand it the South Aus.tralian railways is obliged to pay some payroll tax to the State Treasury. I realise that this is probably a book entry and somewhat of an accounting fiddle, but it is nevertheless significant in the minds of my State colleagues. I wish to know what the Australian Government intends doing in that respect because I understand that the Commonwealth is not obliged to pay payroll tax in any case.

talk.start.para: The first thing I wish to say is that what the State Government might do is a matter for the State Government or the State Parliament. The State Government has made the agreement with the Commonwealth Government. It has been presented to me as a most favourable agreement to the South Aus.tralian Government. The Bill authorising the agreement has to go before the South Australian Parliament. It may be that the South Australian legislature might seek some new assurances or might seek to amend the Bill. But I should think it is generally known that the railways are a great liability to the States and that the States are finding it almost impossible now to cope with the general debts of the railway systems. The railways are carrying out the function of developing the States and providing general commuter services at great costs and the States are finding it hard to recover those costs by increasing revenues. That applies to all the States.

speech.para: Many innovations have been started in the States to try to recover the position. We know that in New South Wales the railways incur hundreds of millions of dollars of deficit each year. In the other Sates there are great deficits. In Victoria Mr Bill Gibbs is trying to introduce new methods of vehicle use and certain new tariff changes to encourage people to use the railways. But generally speaking, as everybody knows it is like all public transport. People still tend to use their own vehicles to get to and from work. The States have to provide public transport. The Aus.tralian Government said that we would encourage, and in fact invest large sums of money in, public transport. In addition we told the States that if they wished we would take over their railway systems. That is what we have done.

In the schedules of the agreement with the States honourable senators will see that in respect of the 3 most important matters the States can object and they can go to arbitration if they wish, if the arrangements are wrong. In respect of fares and freights they can say that the provisions do not suit them. As I have said, under the provisions of principle 8 honourable senators will see that the conditions are to be no less favourable than those existing in the other Commonwealth or State railway services. In addition, if there is a benefit to user that benefit has to be obtained even when the National Railway runs the line. There is access to arbitration in the case of disputes when the national government might decide to close down lines. There is an obligation that generally there should be at least an equivalent service.

talk.start.para: What happens to the Peterborough workshops, for example?

I only say that I am talking for the Australian Government. I tell the honourable senator that I presume that some of the matters he has raised will no doubt be raised in the South Australian Parliament. In conversations with the Minister, Mr Virgo, I have been told that as far as the South Australian Government is concerned the agreement is very beneficial. Maybe there will be some afterthoughts as to what to do. In relation to freight and fares there is a guarantee. In relation to the closing down of lines there is a guarantee.
A guarantee with the approval of the State Government.

Yes. There has to be a procedure of improvements. If the State Government is not satisfied with those trends to improve the service it can take the matter to arbitration. The honourable senator will see from the Schedule that the principles are quite specific. The Australian Government has to invest large sums of money in this system. I suppose the last answer is that this is finally a matter for the State Parliament, as it is with our Parliament, to say whether there might be some follow up.

continue.para: As I have mentioned in relation to the first point, in Tasmania there has been a follow up which is not worrying the Australian Government. I understand that it is not worrying the Tasmanian Government. So I think, aU things considered, everybody realises that these things cannot be done overnight. Anybody who knows the railway system knows full well that it will take some time for the State system to be merged into a national system. We know that generally speaking most States, once they are satisfied that there is not a general takeover by the Australian Government, are happy for their systems to be merged with the national railway enterprise. Of course, that is the sort of thing about which most railway engineers have been thinking for many years. They want an Australian railway system and not different railway systems in the various States.

talk.start.para: In regard to any possible line closures, there will not be any without the concurrence of the State Government?

Yes. Senator Laucke has raised the position of closure of lines. As the honourable senator will see, clause 9 ( 1 ) of the Schedule states: 9(1) The Australian Minister will obtain the prior agreement of the State Minister to-

continue.para: (a) any proposal for the closure of a railway Une of the non-metropolitan railways; or -
(b) the reduction in the level of effectively demanded services on the non-metropolitan railways, and failing agreement on any of these matters the dispute shall be determined by arbitration.

talk.start.para: I was interested to hear Senator Jessop say that there may be opposition in South Australia to the Railways (South Australia) Bill. I have read reports that one or two Legislative Councillors have said that they do not approve of this transfer. Senator

speech.para: Jessop may know more about this matter than I do. Certainly this indicates that the BUI may not obtain an automatic passage through the South Australian Parliament. I mention a matter in the Schedule. It relates to clause 8, rates and charges. We have a very important line in South Australia and that is the Broken Hill line. That line has been the main conveyance of ores from the fabulously rich Broken HU1 to Port Pirie for treatment and shipment overseas. The upgrading of that line and its standardisation were of great importance during the Gorton Government and other Liberal governments. I think the link was formalised during the Gorton Administration. At all times the freight rate that is charged by the South Australian Railways for the conveyance of that ore is a vital factor in the success of the Broken Hill mines and the smelters which are dependent on that ore. Any sudden and substantial rise in that rate would cause chaos to that extremely large industry. Therefore I look with some interest at clause 8 of the Schedule, which states:
( 1 ) The Commission will ensure that, in general, -

I stress the words 'in general '- fares, freight rates and other charges in respect of the non-metropolitan railways and services shall be maintained, on and after the commencement date, at levels not less favourable to users than those levels generally applying on the railways of States other than South Australia and where, in general, fares, freight rates and other charges at the commencement date have established a relative advantage to the users, that advantage shall not be diminished.

It seems to me the words that govern this matter are 'in general'. I am talking about the particular. There is a very special rate for the companies which transport ore on this vital link, which is now a high grade link having been standardised under the previous arrangements in the 1960s. As I read that clause, the rates to be charged will be those not less favourable to users in other States. That is the only particular application. Otherwise we are dealing with general rates which would not safeguard the rate that is charged for transport from the Broken Hill mines. This is vital to the economy of South Australia and to Broken Hill.

I have not any comparisons because it would be most difficult to obtain them, but I am sure that the Department of Transport can obtain them. I am sure that members of the South Aus.tralian Parliament Will ask this very fair question: What Will be the possible alterations to the ore charge from Broken Hill? I know that the Postmaster-General (Senator Bishop) will understand what I am saying because he is a South Australian. I am sure that the companies would want to know what they will be up for. I see the reference to 'in general' as being very important wording which may disadvantage these companies if they have to pay a rate such as that which is being charged interstate in respect of Mt Isa. This is something on which the South Australian Parliament will want to be assured. While I am sure that the Postmaster-General cannot give us all that detail tonight, if the Minister for Transport (Mr Charles Jones) is to get this legislation through the South Australian Parliament he will have to produce the figures, he will have to be convincing about the matter and he will have to assure the South Australian Parliament that the industry will not be disadvantaged in that respect.

I wish to refer to sub-clause 8 (3) of the Schedule. I thought that South Australia was getting rid of responsibility for these railways, not for physical reasons, because the State is best able to build, maintain and run railways, but for financial reasons. If South Australia is divesting itself of the responsibility for the country railway system for financial reasons it seems that the State would have a continuing obligation under subclause 8(3), which states:
The State will reimburse the Commission the reasonable cost to the Commission as agreed between the parties, of the passenger concessions continued pursuant to sub-clause (2 ).
Sub-clause (2) states:
Passenger concessions that exist in respect of the non metropolitan railways at the date of this agreement shall continue after the declared date so far as they lawfully may do so.

As I see the matter, the existing concessions, which are of an immense nature per ticket purchased, must continue and the Commonwealth will not pay for them. I find this rather peculiar. I thought that the State was getting rid of responsibility for these railways against its will, in a sense. We in South Australia had no reason suddenly to say: 'Here, take something we do not like'. Despite a few troubles we are rather proud of our system there'. I thought it was for a financial reason that we were getting rid of the railway system. No doubt the overall debt is immense and there will be great advantages financially to South Australia, but there is on the tail of this agreement an unending and growing burden to pay the difference between the actual cost and the cost charged for the conveyance of country passengers. The last figure given in this respect, and I stand to be corrected, was a subsidy of $13 or $14 per ticket purchased on average by a country passenger in South Australia. As I see it, the Schedule is loaded against the State and the State has to continue paying this subsidy. Perhaps there is some other factor but that is as I read the clause and I would like the Minister to explain it to the Committee.

talk.start.para: I am glad that Senator Hall raised the question of freight rates in relation to clause 8. He is right in pointing out that the economic welfare and viability of Broken Hill Associated Smelters Pty Ltd at Port Pirie are dependent very largely, if not entirely, on the advantageous rates that are being obtained on that railway line at present. I question the Minister on whether concessions for pensioner passengers on the railway line will continue.
That is what Senator Hall has been talking about.
I beg your pardon. I understand that the previous Liberal-Country Party Government granted a 50 per cent concession on Commonwealth Railways. I support what Senator Hall said in that regard.
I start with the point on which Senator Hall finished in relation to clause 8 (2) of the Schedule which states:

speech.para: Passenger concessions that exist in respect of non metropolitan railways at the date of this agreement shall continue after the declared date so far as they lawfully may do so.

These are the concessions which are given to pensioners, to returned soldiers who attend Anzac Day celebrations and the special travel concessions given to members of Parliament. They are the only concessions involved in that prescription. Turning to the other point raised in connection with users, the important part of clause 8 ( 1 ) of the Schedule is in the concluding lines where it says: in general, fares, freight rates and other charges at the commencement date have established a relative advantage to the users, that advantage shall not be diminished.
That provision is intended to cover Broken Hill traffic and traffic on other lines.

talk.start.para: It says 'in general '.

I was not there with Mr Virgo and Mr Jones to consummate the agreement. There are many lines in South Australia on which relatively concessional freight rates are allowed to users in the non-metropolitan area, and this includes the Broken Hill line. It is good traffic, intensive traffic. Of course, the Australian Government would not want to impede that railway traffic. The intention of this provision, 1 am advised and I can see it clearly, is that where there has been a user advantage that advantage shall continue, but in such a document as this one could not specify such matters. I can think of a dozen concessional freight agreements in South Australia in regard to various users. They cannot all be specified. If the South Australian Parliament decides that those details ought to be written into a memorandum, it has the right to do it.
You say you can think of a dozen. Give us an illustration.

There is a lot. I am not here to give illustrations. This is a matter for the South Australian Parliament. I am not against the South Australian Parliament or its Minister, but in this Parliament it is of no use asking me what wil happen in the South Australian Parliament because I cannot tell you. All I can say is that from my point of view and as far as I am aware from the point of view of the unions in the railway service and the State Minister for Transport, Mr Virgo, what has been effected is an agreement which is beneficial to South Australia. When the Senate debates the Rau ways (Tasmania) BUI later tonight, I have no doubt that some senator Will say: 'Look at what South Australia has got. Why have we not got it?'
Hear, hear!
Senator Marriott's interjection proves my point. What I am putting to the Senate is that I do not think it is logical to say that in an agreement such as this -
You have a guilty mind.

I am just having a good guess. When railways contract to run a service or to lift a special cargo, whether it be steel, superphosphate or iron ore, they offer various concessional rates on runs where the traffic is good. The intention of the Bill, as can be seen, is to guarantee that the user gets any advantage. That was set out in the memorandum presented to the Senate.

continue.para: It was suggested that colleagues of Senator Steele Hall and Senator Jessop in the South Aus.tralian Parliament may prevent passage of complementary legislation by the South Aus.tralian Parliament. I will be very much surprised if they do more than carry a resolution. For the reasons I have stated, we can fairly say that the Agreement set out in the Schedule to the BUI is a very good agreement.

talk.start.para: I seek further elucidation from the Postmaster-General (Senator Bishop) about how the Bill wil affect those who have made commercial investments on the expectancy of a railway line being provided for many years ahead. I refer to decentralised industries in South Australia. As the

speech.para: Minister rightly says, clause 8 (1) of the Agreement set out in the Schedule to the Bill states that where fares, freight rates and other charges at the commencement date have established a relative advantage to the users that advantage shall not be diminished. I would like the Minister to explain his attitude to a situation which could arise from the closure of a line. If an industry has invested moneys in a spur Une and the orientation of buildings to receive raw materials and push out the finished product, what will be the situation in respect of that capital investment in the event of Une closure as distinct from changes in freight rates?

talk.start.para: It seems to me that the position under the Agreement whereby the Australian National Railways Commission will take over railways in South Australia will be better than it is at the present time. At the present time a number of railway lines are being closed down in all States. I remember that when former Senator Lillico was a member of the Tasmanian State Parliament a number of Tasmanian railway lines were closed. Senator Lillico went on the hustings with the secretary of the railways union in that State to circumvent the closing down of lines. Not all his efforts were successful. Little can be done if a State government decides to close down a line. Members of Parliament can agitate in their electorates and make representations in the Parliament. That goes on every day. The Agreement in the BUI we are discussing sets out clearly a new prescription which, as far as I am aware, is not to be found in any State legislation dealing with railways. It states:

speech.para: The Australian Minister will obtain the prior agreement of the State Minister to-
(a) any proposal for the closure of a railway line of the non-metropolitan railways; or
(b) the reduction in the level of effectively demanded services on the non-metropolitan railways, and failing agreement on any of these matters the dispute shall be determined by arbitration.

There is an acknowledgement in that- the acknowledgement was made before the Bill was introduced- that the South Australian Government had to have a guarantee that once the transfer of its railways to the Australian Government had been effected the national Government could not close down lines, or could not close them down easily, anyway. Before that could be done the State Minister must agree to the closure. It was agreed that if the State .Minister did not agree to the closure then the matter had to go to arbitration and be argued. The matters about which Senator Laucke talked would be matters for arbitration.

talk.start.para: I am not so worried about the closing down of railway lines because from time to time there will have to be a closure of lines. In some ways I hope that the Australian Government, because it is further removed from the local scene, will be able to look at matters more objectively and overcome some of the difficulties with which the State administrations are faced when they are hard pushed electorally and are unable to make sensible decisions about closures because of local feeling. As the Postmaster-General (Senator Bishop) probably would be aware, very important illustrations are available of how difficult it is to close lines; yet how right it often is to do so. I remember what happened in 1969 when the South Australian Government closed down a substantial number of services. Petitions containing the signatures of up to 2000 people were received. Those people were crying out in a very sentimental fashion about the closing down of lines; yet when one looked at the usage one found that only seven to nine people were using those very expensive trains each day. Of course, when the trains were taken off the run and were replaced by faster, more convenient and flexible bus services at a cheaper cost than that at which the railways could provide a service it was found that the public would not like the return of the rail systems. So I think that as long as there is an arbitrator perhaps there will be a more effective economic approach to closures than when parochial problems confront State governments.

speech.para: I am still worried about the particular point I have raised. I cannot do any more than express my worries and sit down because we will not get anywhere with them tonight. I am not criticising the Minister for that. What I am really saying is that the future administrators of this legislation will not place any reliance on the goodwill expressed tonight by the Postmaster-General. I am sure that the Postmaster-General has expressed goodwill because he is a loyal South Aus.tralian. I do not doubt that at all. In raising the issue I am not being critical of him; I am simply saying that in clause 8 of the Schedule I see possible danger to the specific advantages now held. I just want to have that put down. I ask the Postmaster-General to read it in a quieter moment. As I have said, he can do that after the Bill has been passed because that does not affect its passage now. If the Postmaster-General reads clause 8 he will find that sub-clause ( 1 ) is really divided into 2 parts. It states that the Commission will ensure that, in general, fares, freight rates and other charges in respect of the non metropolitan railways and services shall be maintained and then it goes on to talk about it being on a not less favourable basis than the other States. Then, still using the words 'in general', it says that where the fares, freight rates and other charges at the commencement date have established a relative advantage to the users that advantage shall not be diminished.

What does 'in general' mean? The clause does not say 'in particular'. If I were drafting that to mean what the Postmaster-General would like it to mean and what I would like it to mean I would say 'in particular' and not 'in general' because I am sure that in the future some person, if he wanted to vary the rates against the present users, could say: 'It mentions "in general" and you, on the Broken Hill line, are not "in general"- you are "in particular". You have a particular contract for a particular product from a particular part of New South Wales. You are not "in general".' I am just saying that if someone wants to play around in the future he would have an 'in' there. I do not expect the Postmaster-General to reply to my comments because it is not something that we can alter tonight, but I imagine that it could cause trouble for the South Australian Parliament.
Bill agreed to.
BDI reported without amendment; report adopted.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: The Opposition does not oppose this Bill which will give force and effect to an agreement entered into between the Commonwealth of Australia- I am pleased to note that the agreement specifies 'the Commonwealth of Australia' which is the proper legal title, and not 'Australia' as this Government is so keen on calling itself- and the State of Tasmania. As we are all aware the Commonwealth Government, by virtue of section 5 1 (xxxiii) of the Constitution has the power of acquisition, with the consent of a State, of any railways of the State on terms arranged between the Commonwealth and the State.

speech.para: On 23 May 1975 the Commonwealth of Australia and the State of Tasmania entered into an agreement whereby the railways of Tasmania would be transferred to the Commonwealth of Australia. Bills of the type that we are now considering always present some difficulty, especially when they come into the Senate, in that they are designed to give confirmation to an agreement entered into between 2 governments. Therefore parliaments tend to be somewhat reluctant to interfere with agreements entered into by two separate governments, especially between governments of the Commonwealth and the States. It is even more difficult, of course, when both Houses of the Parliament of the State of Tasmania have passed, as I assume, a Bill for an Act to give force and effect to this agreement. Therefore it is with some reservations and recommendations therein that the Opposition does not oppose the Bill.

Of course, the other side of the coin is that the Senate has a duty to see that the rights of the States are not submerged totally in this matter. But, as I say, this is a difficult area. If, of course, the Parliament of Tasmania had not confirmed the legislation Tasmanian senators may have been far more critical of the legislation as it concerns their State. Whether or not their State got as good a deal as it might have done is another problem. This is a matter for which the Government of Tasmania will eventually be accountable to its electors. If the criticism of the Hon. Max Bingham, Q.C, the Leader of the Opposition in the Parliament of Tasmania, is valid the State Government will pay the penalty for that at the next election. But tonight we are faced with the situation of the Senate being asked, as the fourth House of the 2 Parliaments, to give its approval to an agreement entered into between the Commonwealth of Australia and the State of Tasmania. That is the reason why the Opposition will support the Bill.

One could deliver an interesting philosophical discourse on whether the powers which the constitutional fathers had in mind in 1 900 are still as valid in 1 975. All I can hope is that as a result of the legislation which will be passed this night, the people of Tasmania will in fact be better off than they are at present. That is something which will be decided in the future. I just hope for myself personally and I think for all my colleagues that the great hopes that the Government has, that this Bill will in fact be for the betterment of the people of Tasmania, will come to pass. But if those hopes do not come to fruition I think it will then be a matter for the electorate of Tasmania to use its judgment in relation to the people it elects at both the State level and the Federal level. With those comments I again indicate that we will support the Bill.

talk.start.para: I was pleased to hear the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Withers) indicate to the chamber that the Opposition will not be opposing the Railways (Tasmania) Bill 1975 because, as he rightly pointed out, to do so would be to fly in the face of an agreement proposed to be entered into between the Government of Tasmania and the Commonwealth, as he puts it. I think it would be desirable if, for the sake of the record, I were to indicate as briefly as I possibly could the principal purposes of this legislation. On my summary of the Bill there are in fact what could be regarded as 1 1 main points. The first relates to the agreement which is embodied in the Schedule to the Bill. The agreement provides for an interim period commencing on 1 July when the Australian Government accepts financial responsibility for the Tasmanian Railways and has the assets of the railways vested in it. The second point is that the interim period will terminate with the transfer of the railway staff to the Aus.tralian National Railways Commission, and during that period the Tasmanian Transport Commission will administer the railways on behalf of the Australian National Railways but subject to the direction and control of the Australian National Railways.

speech.para: The third point is that the agreement provides for the Australian National Railways to operate ancillary services in Tasmania and to extend its railways where necessary. On that point, I would just indicate to the Senate that in recent years one quite important extension to the railway system has already been made to provide principally for the needs of the wood chip industry in that State. The purpose of the extension was to provide a rail track from Launceston to the Bell Bay area on the Tamar River to enable the transportation of substantial quantities of chipping timber to that region. More recently, a proposal is under consideration for an extension to a section of the railway system in the vicinity of Devonport to service the requirements of the Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd complex at Wesley Vale. I commend these propositions as indicating that the railway system generally still has a very useful and worthwhile purpose to serve in the Aus.tralian community. The fourth point is that provision is also made for a continuation of concessions presently available on the railways if the State so requests, provided that the State meets the same proportion of its costs as was provided before the transfer.

Fifthly, in the case of a dispute arising between the Australian and Tasmanian governments on payments for concessions and cessation of services on the railway, provision has been made for settlement by arbitration. The sixth point to be made is that because of the importance of sea trade to Tasmania- sea trade is of extreme importance to the State of Tasmania, Mr President, as you, being a Tasmanian senator, would know- and because of the integration of the systems of rail transportation and sea transportation to bring them into the mainland systems as we know them, the Government's declared intention is to have greater coordination which would be absolutely essential in this situation, between the Australian National Railways and the Australian National Line. Provision has been made for Tasmanian nominees to join both the Australian Shipping Commission and the Australian National Railways Commission. So we can see the association of those 2 systems of transport is so important that it has been considered by the 2 governments in consultation that there ought to be a combination of the relationship of those 2 systems. Both of these appointments will be subject to the approval of the Minister for Transport and are provided for in clause 9 of the Agreement.

I come to the seventh point. At present the Tasmanian Transport Commission operates a precision tool annexe at Launceston. Although its buildings are situated on railway land, the annexe is not part of the railway operations. It services the operations of the railways, but the annexe is not essentially part of the functioning of the railway system. Consequently, it has been decided that the annexe will remain with the Tasmanian Government. Clause 19 provides for this and for the eventual removal of the annexe from railway land, possibly within a period of 10 years. There is to be no great urgency about this. I make the point in passing that this is a very fine complex. It is capable of turning out some high quality machinery work and work of that nature. As a matter of fact, in recent years substantial progress has been made with the development of the diesel locomotive system. I was very pleased a few years ago to see the capacity of the railway workshops at Launceston, alongside the tool annexe, to manufacture many of the parts in the diesel system implemented into the Tasmanian railway system generally. It was a fine piece of work and it is a very great tribute to the workmen there and to the capacity of the organisational setup to be able to undertake and faithfully execute that work.

The eighth point relates to the provision in clause 14 for the payment to Tasmania of $5m in consideration of land, minerals and other assets when both the Australian and Tasmanian parliaments ratify the necessary legislation to approve the Agreement.
