Clause 15, which deals with the ninth point, provides for the taking over by the Australian Government of a specific portion of the railway debt. The tenth point, which is embodied within clause 16, refers to the interim period during which any loss in connection with the railways will be borne by the Australian Railways Commission and any profits will be paid to the Commission, and that is a reasonable enough proposition. Finally, clause 17 is intended to ensure continuity of superannuation to any transferred employees. As I see it, that crystallises the main purpose of the Bill. The clause is designed to give effect to this Agreement reached between the 2 governments to enable a system to be taken over and integrated into the national railway system to the benefit, it is believed, of Tasmania, the railway system itself and, I would hope, to the benefit of those people who work in the service of the railway system currently under the control of Tasmania

There is presently proceeding an inquiry by Mr J. F. Jimmy into Transport Charges to and from Tasmania as they relate to the transport costs of Tasmania. I will not go into great detail. I think that honourable senators are aware of the purposes of this inquiry, that is, to endeavour to provide to Tasmania, as the Australian Government has undertaken, a system of transportation the cost of which does not exceed the per ton mile cost of freight rates in the other States of the Commonwealth. So here again we see the relationship between the Tasmanian raU system and that of the mainland States. Of course, I would expect this relativity to wipe out the disability of freight costs when the sea-raU services are used. As I think everybody would concede, the rau ways have played a tremendous part in the development of this country. They are a public transport system which I suppose we all accept is one of those systems which does not pay. It has been a good old whipping post for a great many people over the years when those people have set out to criticise the budgets of those States controlling and running a railway system when the annual accounts of the States have revealed the condition of the finances of those railway systems.

I think that never in an argument of that kind is any credibility given to the tremendous role which has been played by the railway systems in the development of this country. In fact I would go so far as to say that had there not been a rau way system over the years in my State of Tasmania, serving the outlying areas back into the bush and back into the developing farmlands, the progress that has been made in those regions would not have been so great as it has been. Those areas still would have been using the road systems which would have had to bear the additional load imposed upon them because of the absence of an alternative system. The road systems would have been in a much worse condition than we see some of them at present. I think it is necessary and tremendously important to maintain the railway systems so that the load, the rate of usage and consequent destruction of the road systems of the various States can be limited, at least to that degree.

I see in this proposition an opportunity to upgrade the raU tracks and also upgrade and modernise the rolling stock in the Tasmanian railway system. Most people hail Tasmania as a place with tremendous tourist potential. For a number of years, especially since it has been my privilege to visit other countries, to see the sorts of things that are going on and to view the tourist attractions, I have thought that there is a tremendous potential in Tasmania if we could only use it. This involves substantial financial commitments for the development of a quite magnificent railway system. That is perhaps something for the future. I mention it now as something which could be achieved were all the other problems associated with the financing and the development of these systems able to be overcome. Right throughout the country and in fact throughout the world there is the problem of what is to be done with motor transport, particularly in the urban areas. This is worrying every city in this country. I think if we were not to endeavour to keep railway systems alive and progressing with the times we would tend to aggravate and add to the problems. This is perplexing all the urban authorities at present.

I saw during a world tour a couple of years ago the potential for the development of a railway system. I am talking about the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics which has highly developed railway systems in the urban areas which, in fact, are paying propositions. I know that the circumstances in the USSR and here are vastly different. I wish to point out the possibility that railway systems do not have to be losing propositions all the time if they are properly utilised and developed. As time goes on, particularly in the urban areas where the problem of traffic is becoming increasingly difficult, we may have to turn more and more to the use of railway systems for the carriage of commuters to their various duties in the principal areas of population.

I have mentioned already the role of the railways in opening up the country. I am quite certain when we talk about the merits of the operations of private and public enterprise that private enterprise would not take on many of the undertakings that have been carried out by the railway systems of this country. The railway systems are not paying propositions, as I think I mentioned earlier, and therefore they are not attractive to private enterprise. So, credit for much of the progress of this country can be laid at the door of the railway systems. I am reminded also in my thoughts about this general proposition that the railways on many occasions have further jeopardised their chances of showing any sort of reasonable balance sheet by coming to the aid of various sections of the community. For instance, a few years ago the Tasmanian Government adopted the principle of payment of a certain amount of subsidy on the transport of, I think, agricultural lime to service the farming communities. That could not have been undertaken by private enterprise. But the railways reached out into those country regions and it was possible for the railways to provide that service to the country areas and so, to a degree at least, keep the price of that very necessary commodity especially necessary in the high rainfall areas- at a level that could be met by the farming community.

We are coming closer together all the time, with the frequency and the speed of carriage of goods across the continent these days. I do not think that any State can be isolated from the principal transport system- the railway system. Whether the proposal before us turns out to be financially good or financially not so good for Tasmania, I think that the general question of the integration and the relationship of transport systems is such that we cannot stay out any longer. I hope that the Jimmy report will come down shortly. If it is not possible to have the full report of the Jimmy inquiry, it might be possible to obtain an interim report which will give some indication of the fact that there will be a continuation of the present arrangement of assistance for the freight rate on goods exported from Tasmania. Pretty well all of those goods go by ship, and the ships are to a very substantial degree serviced by the railway system of Tasmania. I think that the ability to arrive at that point will be enhanced by the proposal embodied in this Bill, namely, by the integration of the rail and sea Way systems. As Senator Withers indicated, one could perhaps speak at some length on many of these points. I do not want to protract the debate. I am very pleased indeed to note that the Opposition is accepting this proposition and will not oppose it. I commend the proposal as something worthwhile, particularly in the interests of my State of Tasmania and in the interests of the transportation of goods in this continent generally.

talk.start.para: This Bill comes to us out of a crisis which inevitably was to face the Government of Tasmania. Mr Reece, the former Premier, fell upon the misfortune of trying to manoeuvre the finances of Tasmania, and the country will remember that when he tried to extricate himself from the political debacle that the tobacco tax represented to him, he withdrew his State from the authority of the Grants Commission and then he decided to go it alone in consideration of an increased reimbusement. Of course, we on our side of politics said: 'He is not reckoning with the future as to the railway crisis. The losses in it alone will need underwriting by the Commonwealth'. The Commonwealth has now taken advantage of that crisis and has said: 'You are completely within my monetary control. Make a bargain with us. Sell us your railways'. That is what has been done.

speech.para: Tasmania abandons all control. There are a few phrases in the agreement that are tokens of giving Tasmania some authority over the continued operation of the railways, but they are completely ineffective and operate merely as tokens. In 1970-71 the loss on the Tasmanian railways was $3.9m, and in the last year the commercial loss on the railways was $ 1 5m according to my latest information. So honourable senators see the predicament that is now facing Mr Neilson, the present Premier pro tern of Tasmania. The financial losses of the railways are such that he will be submerged unless he gets rid of them. He has yielded to the theme of Mr Whitlam that the best thing for all Labor State politicians to do is to scuttle themselves. That was the proposition that Mr Whitlam put to them some 10 years ago. With regard to the railways, Mr Neilson says: '1 am getting $5m. I am getting free of debts to the extent of $63m. Here, take the railways. I wish 1 had never seen the slurry ducks'. This is the sort of bargain that we have and Tasmania is ceasing to have any control over its railways and the associated services.

As Senator Devitt mentioned, in frankness no doubt, the services on the Sea road are to be associated with and dovetailed into the Tasmanian railways. That involves yielding to the policy that has been inveterately pumped out by the experts in Canberra that Tasmania has too many ports. We have 4 grand ports developed at great cost and capable of efficient and economic management. The Commonwealth operates the Interstate Commission and the Australian Shipping Commission, which trades as the Australian National Line. After the report into which Senator Devitt claims to have some insight but which has not yet been made public, I suppose there will be an attempt to make 1 port serve in place of 3 northern ports to the great disadvantage of the transport system of Tasmania.

So it is an evil day for Tasmania that we Liberal Tasmanian senators find ourselves in the crunch between an agreement by a Federal Labor Government, with a Tasmanian Labor Government and the Tasmanian Parliament. That is to say, the majority of Labor men in the House of Assembly, their action endorsed by the Legislative Council, with 2 reservations, have passed the Act approving of the Bill. So we find ourselves in the crunch where the Senate could not be prevailed upon to disrupt the arrangements that have been made by force of this agreement and which are to commence to operate on 1 July. But it is almost as much a mystery as the external loan raising of Dr Cairns when one looks at this agreement and sees how poorly it, a contemporaneous agreement between the Commonwealth and Tasmania made at the same time as the South Australian agreement, provides for the protection of Tasmania and of any effective right on the part of her representatives to determine what lines shall be kept open and at what fares and freights the trains shall run.

Whereas in the South Australian agreement there is a specific provision that when their rau ways come under Commonwealth control they wil be upgraded and improved to the standard of the other mainland States, there is no specific, undertaking with regard to Tasmanian railways in that respect. Then there is the vital question of freights. In the South Australian agreement there is the provision which Senator Bishop read out during the debate on the previous BUI, which states that freight rates Will be maintained at a level that generally applies in other Commonwealth railways. There is no provision such as that in the Tasmanian agreement. In fact, it simply contains this provision:

When so requested by the Senate, the Australian Minister or his delegate will consult with the State on matters regarding the operation of the existing and new railways within the State which the State considers to be of concern to the State.
The next clause, clause 7, states:

Subject to the provisions of this clause, the Australian Commission will, if so requested by the State, continue to grant the concessional rates and concessional charges granted by the Tasmanian Commission in respect of the railways at the date of this agreement.
Then the nub comes. It would surprise all of us. Clause 8 states:
The State will, both during and after the interim period -

That is to say, for all the future- maintain its proportion of any costs existing at the date of this agreement as a contribution to such concessional rates and charges as it contributed to before the date of this agreement.

What is involved in the indefinite obligation of the State to continue to make contributions equal to those concessional rates? When one thinks not merely of passenger concessions but also of industry concessions which operate in that State, one finds that the Tasmanian obligation is very significant. Anybody who thinks that Tasmania will escape completely from its past losses, I am afraid, Will find that clause construed against Tasmania to its surprise and detriment in future.

There is the important item of how the railways Will be maintained. I pointed out that there is no undertaking by the Commonwealth to upgrade or even maintain any specific part of the railway system of Tasmania or the system in general. All we have as a protection for the cessation of any raU service is that the matter shall be determined by arbitration. I ask: What sort of system of government is envisaged if, when there is a dispute between the Commonwealth and Tasmania as to the railway lines that shall be maintained, it is to be determined by an arbitrator? It is carefully provided in the last clause of the Agreement:
The arbitrator shall not perform his functions as an arbitrator under any law relating to arbitration, but shall act as an independent expert or adjudicator.

Any dispute as to the closure of particular lines in the State- that is to say, whether any service shall be withdrawn from any district of Tasmania mil be left to the decision not of the Tasmanian Government, not of the Tasmanian Par.liament but of an arbitrator who is appointed. Under this Agreement, his decision operates. I say that the Tasmanian Government, in accepting an agreement such as this, has abdicated its responsibility, handed over the railway system for a pittance of $5m and has left the State people unprotected.

More than that, all associated surface transport services come under the direction of the Commonwealth. They include associated road services- those services which can be associated with the railways- and probably Senator Devitt 's apprehension is correct and there in an intention to include within that term sea-going services. They wil be under the control of the Commonwealth for the purpose of coordinating them with the Commonwealth 's idea of directing the railway services through one port, if it adheres to policy pronouncements over the last few years, and so prevent Tasmanian outer ports from being serviced independently.

So the other little thing which the Tasmanian Premier no doubt thought he had some protection from- Senator Devitt has referred to it and I mention it just in passing- is that there is to be one of several Commissioners appointed by Tasmania for a period of 5 years. That shows how limited and feeble is the foresight of the Tasmanian Government at the present time. Five years seems a long time for the appointment, no doubt, measuring it against the time of the next election. Contrasted with that, the Premier of the other Labor State, Mr Dunstan, agreed to a 10-year period for his Commissioner. Each case is a feeble indication of the right of the State to be on a commission that operates what were formerly State railways that pass under Commonwealth control but which essentially served the people of the State. There is more than usual sense in integrating the system so as to get the uniform gauge in all the mainland States. It is one of the abysmal circumstances of the development of this country that we have inherited that those who pioneered the railways pioneered them on different gauges for the different States.

But that consideration of impelling mainland States to come into one uniform system does not operate at all in Tasmania. My theme is that it is a most misguided agreement whereby the control of the Tasmanian system passes from the Tasmanian people's representatives into the Canberra control where, of necessity, Tasmanian affairs occupy a very small focus. In that respect the Agreement is very shortsighted. There are those in this chamber who say: 'But think of the $15m loss they made last year'. From 1932 to 1970 the Grants Commission used to adjust Tasmania's finances so as to offset any deficit from the railways. This Agreement is due to that smart aleck trick- which it really was whereby as a result of a political imbroglio the former Premier got himself into over the tobacco tax, from which he could not extract himself except by coming to Canberra and persuading Mr Whitlam that if he were to come out of the ambit of the Grants Commission Mr Whitlam would adjust the former grant by $10m or $12m- I forget which it was, it may have been $15m- a year. That proved to be a most disastrous course for Tasmania. It is not irrevocable. Tasmania could go back under the Grants Commission, and if it did and got equitable treatment the financial loss that it sustains from its railways ought to be made up by the Grants Commission under the terms of its jurisdiction. So to me this represents a very material surrender of the control by the Tasmanian Parliament and the Tasmanian Government of a vital utility that has been developed for the service of the Tasmanian people.

I join with Senator Devitt in referring to the pioneering element of the railways, to the necessity to continue them at the present time for certain freights and to the prospect of their improvement if the motor car world suffers a reverse, as it may because of many circumstances. I see the surrender of the Tasmanian railway system as an abandonment of the control of a most significant utility, and any financial adversity arising from its operation could be adjusted by the Grants Commission if the present State Labor Government had sufficient fortitude, to adopt a volte-face and say: 'We made a blunder in going out of the Grants Commission in 1971. We want to come back to it in a manner that will permit our losses to be adjusted on a proper basis'.

talk.start.para: Are you not proud not to be a mendicant State?

Senator McAuliffe parroted the old expression 'mendicant State'. The possibility of State grants was recognised in section 96 of the Constitution for the true purpose of granting financial assistance to the States in cases where it was proper, and that section has been much overlooked since then for other purposes. Mr Joseph Lyons erected the Grants Commission in 1 932 and for a period of about 5 years enjoyed the unique position of being the only State to apply to the Grants Commission. Queensland went off, Queensland came back; South Australia went off, South Australia came back. It is quite obvious that if the current rate of inflation goes on there has got to be a more equable distribution of Federal finance to support State functions, of which the railway in Tasmania, an island State, is peculiarly one.

continue.para: I think that this Agreement represents a really retrograde step on the part of the Tasmanian Government. I should say that one of the things that has persuaded me that it is not a practicable proposition either to reject or to amend the Bill is that this Agreement has been through the Tasmanian Parliament and the Legislative Council there has adopted 2 amendments to the Tasmanian Act. In the first amendment it has declared that freight rates applying to the Tasmanian railways are of concern to the State and the State shall require the Australian Minister to consult with the State on all proposals to fix or vary those rates, and in any such consultations shall maintain the view that those rates shall not be fixed at a higher level than those applying to the railways of the Commonwealth outside the State. I must say that great credit is to be given to the Upper House for having secured that amendment, but it will be ineffective. The other amendment that the Legislative Council secured was that where by resolution of either House of the State Parliament it is declared that the cessation of any railway service is undesirable, the State shall, unless that resolution be rescinded, dispute the cessation of that service by the Australian National Railways Commission. That means that either House can direct the Government in regard to that matter to dispute the cessation of the service, and thereupon it becomes a matter to be referred to the Arbitrator. That again is a very weak support, but I do give credit to the Legislative Council ibr securing those 2 amendments. With those reservations, Mr President, let the Bill pass.

talk.start.para: in reply- I think there is no need for me to respond to Senator Withers who led for the Opposition and to Senator Devitt who followed him in the debate because they generally accepted that the Bill should be passed as it has been passed in the other place. Perhaps 1 should make one or two comments on what Senator Wright said. First, I refer to his challenge that the Tasmanian Government had in some way failed to carry out its responsibilities in relation to its railways. I would like to read the deficits and the forecast deficits for railway systems in the States including the Liberal States. On 30 May the Minister for Transport in New South Wales, Mr Fife, as reported in the 'Australian Financial Review', stated that the overall 1973-74 deficit was about $150m, the expected deficit for 1974-75 was $200m and for 1975-76 it was $250m. In Victoria the 1974 annual report on the railways showed a deficit of $86.9m. For the Queensland railways the deficit was $36m. For Western Australia the deficit was $ 16.6m. For the South Australian railways the figure was $34.6m and of course the Tasmanian railways deficit was $ 1 5m, as has been stated.

speech.para: The other factor to be considered- I go straight to the point that Senator Wright raised in the first place- is that after all the State of Tasmania has what could be called a run down railway system whereas the South Australian railway system, as most people know, is modern and well-established and the tracks are generally good. In Tasmania the position is the reverse; because of the terrain and narrow gauge the railways are generally run down. I do not think anyone would expect to reach the same agreement in respect of a State with a run down railway system as in respect of a State with a modern railway system. In South Australia the rehabilitation of the system by Webb in 1927 made it possible to fabricate modern rolling stock in two or three hours. Senator Wright said that it is not so important to take over a system like the Tasmanian railways, but I think it is because the general concept of manufacturing railway component parts has to be considered. It is easier to manufacture components- bogies, vehicles, automatic couplers, wheels, carriages and all the rest as if they are standardised; that alone results in great savings.

In respect of the commissioners, the purpose of the Government in making the term of appointment 5 years was to do 2 things. Firstly, it wanted to tie the Tasmanian railways more closely into the national link, so it offered the Tasmanian Government a proposal to have 2 commissioners for 5 years, one on the Australian National Line and one on the Australian National Railway Commission. That would give better coordination than what obtains in South Australia where a commissioner is appointed for a period of 10 years. No doubt during that time the arrangements will be re-negotiated.

talk.start.para: Senator Wright was being foxy then.

He might have been. Senator Wright referred to the concessions set out in the Schedule to the BUI. I can only repeat what seems to me to be pretty clear. Coupling the Schedule, which incorporates the agreement, with what has been decided by the Government the conclusions are pretty satisfactory. The Schedule reads in paragraph 6:

continue.para: When so requested by the State, the Australian Minister or his delegate will consult with the State on matters regarding the operation of the existing and new railways within the State . . .
Paragraph 7(1) reads:
Subject to the provisions of this clause, the Australian Commission will, if so requested by the State, continue to grant the concessional rates and concessional charges ...

I point out that the position in regard to the charges is not as it was put by Senator Wright I am told that at present the Tasmanian Government carries the responsibility for the greater part of the concessions, not this Government. Under this proposal the Australian National Railways will take over the liability for the greater part of those concessions. The other smaller parts of the concessions will be picked up by the Tasmanian Government. Of course, as Senator Wright has mentioned, arbitration can be resorted to so far as closures are concerned. All in all I think that the matters raised have been satisfactorily explained. I thank the Senate for its co-operation in agreeing to the passage of the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative. BUI read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: The Bill.

talk.start.para: I regret that I sent my copy of the Bill away. Could I have another copy.
What is going on? What skulduggery is afoot?
Senator Georges is not in his usual humour. He would be kinder to me if he acted in accordance with his usual character. I wish to refer to clause 10 of the Bill which states:

continue.para: On and after the declared date, the Australian Commission may-
(a) administer, maintain and operate in Tasmania the railways and services acquired under the Agreement; and

( b) construct and extend railways in Tasmania in accordance with the Agreement and administer, maintain and operate railways so constructed or extended and services (including passenger and freight road services) incidental or supplementary to, or associated with, those railways.

I ask the Postmaster-General (Senator Bishop) to tell me where in the Bill is there an obligation, if any, firstly to upgrade the railways and, secondly, to keep them in their present state of maintenance and repair. Thirdly, I ask him to explain to the Committee the meaning of the expression in parenthesis, 'including passenger and freight road services' which are 'incidental or supplementary to, or associated with, those railways.' 'Supplementary to' may extend to road services for some 30 or 40 miles. There are some road services carrying timber- may be for part of the time in competition with the Bell Bay railway for 50 miles. Is the Australian National Railways Commission to take over control of those road services as 'supplementary to, or associated with, those railways.'? Are those road services any longer to be administered by the State licensing authority, or is the Commonwealth to have control of them irrespective of the State licensing authority?

talk.start.para: I will answer firstly the question about the road services. We have included in the Bill the prescription suggested by the shadow Minister for Transport in the other place. It was put into the Australian National Railways Act which was passed recently by the Senate. It is in section 3 1 (B). At the time that was considered acceptable to the honourable senator's Party.
Would you remind me what it was.

I will refer to the Aus.tralian National Railways Act. When the Australian National Railways Bill was being debated Mr Nixon raised the very point that Senator Wright mentioned and the Minister for Transport agreed to insert into the Bill a prescription which was acceptable and which was reported to this place for the reasons I have given. It states: 3 1b ( I ) Without limiting the powers of the Commission to transport passengers and goods on the railways, the Commission may (as incidental or supplementary to, or in association with, the transport or passengers or goods on the railways) transport passengers and goods for reward by land, otherwise than on the railways . . .

continue.para: This provision was intended to guarantee that there would not be any new incursions of the railways into the area of trade that was generally undertaken by road services. All I can say is that the provision was considered at that time to be satisfactory.

As to the other point raised by Senator Wright on clause 10, 1 think that if he reads the clause he will see that it contains the words 'administer, maintain and operate'. Obviously a railway is not maintained if maintenance is not done. Unless there are maintenance crews, section builders, fettlers, gangers and welders it is not maintained. Clause 10 (b) mentions 'construct and extend railways'. Maybe that is not sufficient to suit what Senator Wright thinks the Tasmanian Government might want. But so far the Tasmanian Government has raised no objection except to make a number of suggestions which were put up in the Legislative Council and which seemed to strengthen the role of the State Government. Clause 10, as I read it anyway, means that we shall continue to maintain, continue to operate and continue to construct and extend railways in Tasmania. After all, the national Government will take responsibility for them. I think it is in its own interests to see that the railways are properly maintained. As I have said, the Government wants to see a new coordinated approach. The State Government has a commissioner on the Railways Commission and on the National Line for the first time.

talk.start.para: I am grateful to the Postmaster-General (Senator Bishop) for his explanation of the clause. Perhaps he will permit one incidental question to be repeated. Will those road services that are administered by the Commonwealth supplementary to the railways be subject to the Tasmanian road licensing system? If they are not, there may be a dislocation of them. I also rise to ask the Minister to address his attention to clause 14 of the Bill. It is the width of this clause that attracts my attention. I ask the Minister whether he will be good enough to tell me whether it is directed to any specific laws or area of other law. It states:

speech.para: The Agreement has effect notwithstanding anything in any other Act and nothing in any other Act prevents the carrying out or performance of any provisions of that Agreement.

In my limited experience of reading statute law now some 50 years- I do not recall any section so absolute or wide in its operation. I suspect comprehensive prohibitions such as that. I ask the Minister whether his knowledge of the situation would yield to me information as to whether it is directed to any specific area of law or any other specific law.

talk.start.para: I am advised that the provision does not in fact apply to any specific law but it is a general prescription which has been recommended by the Attorney-General (Mr Enderby) as one which is fairly uniform. I cannot identify where it is provided elsewhere but I am told that that is the reason. It is certainly not directed at any particular law. In relation to road services, I am told that it is proposed that only those road services which are presently run by the Tasmanian Government Railways will be in fact operated by the National Railways.
Yes, but subject to the Tasmanian licensing system or not?
Senator BISHOP- I am told that it is not subject to that system.

continue.para: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Senator Bishop) read a third time.

subdebateinfo.title: Conciliation and Arbitration Act: Legal Aid- Parliamentary Staff- Parliament House- Joint House Department

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Douglas McClelland) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: I desire to raise on the adjournment a matter which I would have liked to raise in the course of some debate I have been unable to do so. It relates to the manner in which the Attorney-General (Mr Enderby) has exercised the discretion accorded to him to dispense legal aid in a matter arising under the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Act. I raise this matter because members of the Australian Labor Party who are concerned in the application for legal aid which has not been granted have been unable to obtain redress from the representations which their own Labor members have made to the Attorney-General. I am sure that these people would have preferred the matter to be raised and decided without publicity and for any difficulties to be confined within the ranks of the Australian Labor Party. But that apparently is not the case.

speech.para: A circular was distributed to the 1 975 biennial Federal Conference of the Australian Labor Party by the State Secretary of the Queensland branch of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees' Association. In that circular reference was made to the fact that a Mr Barry Thomas Egan was removed from office as national secretary-treasurer of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees' Association by resolution of the delegates attending the 1 974 national council meeting of the Association on Friday, 1 8 October 1974. The resolution removing Mr Egan from office, which was carried without dissent, was carried after Mr Egan had requested a period of 8 weeks in which to explain a discrepancy in excess of $120,000 in accounts filed by Mr Egan in respect of the New South Wales Branch of that Association during the period he was secretary of the branch. Of the 24 delegates who voted for Mr Egan's removal from office not less than 17 were members of the Australian Labor Party. That was the statement that was circulated. As to the truth or otherwise of the allegations, I have no knowledge and I am not concerned. Suffice to say that Mr Egan was sufficiently concerned to take action in the Aus.tralian Industrial Court with a view to seeking redress against those members of the Association who had voted him from office.

As a result of the action which he has instituted protracted court proceedings have occurred. As I understand it, court proceedings which initially commenced in November 1974 are still continuing after at least 2 1 days of actual sitting time. The legal costs which have been incurred in this court case are extremely high and the 25 officers of the Association who have been individually sued would be liable for costs which, I am told, are likely to exceed approximately $60,000. Spread amongst some 25 people it might be thought that that sum would be within the means of a number of them, but I would have thought that to the individuals who are concerned in this matter the responsibility for those costs is enormous. I remind the new Minister for Labor and Immigration (Senator James McClelland) either in that capacity or in his capacity as Minister representing the Attorney-General (Mr Enderby), that in 1973 the provision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act with respect to costs was altered. Now in proceedings of this character no award of costs may be made against an unsuccessful party in proceedings before the Industrial Court. So it is quite clear that the persons who have been sued in those proceedings, irrespective of the result of the proceedings, have a liability for those costs. They have had a liability for those costs from the very day on which they were joined as parties to the proceedings.

I mention that because I think it is a highly significant fact in the difficulties which they are experiencing and which they have not been able to have resolved even by the merest assurance that their costs would be met by the Attorney-General. As I have indicated the proceedings started on 1 November 1974. Mr Egan applied for financial assistance, as he is entitled to do, under section 141 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act I am informed that Mr Enderby as Attorney-General approved his application for financial assistance in March or April 1975. Mr Egan's then wage, with allowances, was some $320 weekly. I mention that only because it is a sum vastly in excess of the amounts which are being earned and received by the persons whom he is suing.

I understand that individual applications for assistance- not a block application- were made by the people who were being sued over a period from December until the last of the 25 people applied in February 1975. 1 understand that the applications were accompanied by statutory declarations. I quote one paragraph of the general form of statutory declaration which I understand has been lodged:

I am informed by my solicitor and believe that the said proceedings are expected to occupy at least six days of hearing and will commence in the Australian Industrial Court in Sydney on or about 25 February 1974. 1 say that my take-home pay does not exceed-
Then there is set out whatever is the appropriate amount with regard to each individual case.

talk.start.para: How much was it?
It varies with each of them, I understand. I do not know because those details have not been supplied to me. I do not think they are necessary for the purpose of the case I am making.
How about the documents? How do we know they are authentic?
I do not know. It is simply a document which the honourable senator can certainly look at if he wants to do so. I do not mind. It is a facsimile, a background document. The letter continues:

continue.para: I say that my take-home pay does not exceed $ . . . per week and I have no assets other than those of a domestic nature sufficient to enable me to meet the costs and expenses of defending the said proceedings without hardship to myself.

The request was for the Attorney-General to approve payment of reasonable legal costs and expenses pursuant to section 14 In of the Act. The solicitor for the respondents wrote to the Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department on 25 February, referring to his earlier letters of 12, 16, 17 and 19 December 1974 and 21 and 22 January 1975, and asked that the Attorney-General's direction be sought as soon as departmental convenience permitted. Subsequent follow-up letters were forwarded but to this day there has been no indication by the Attorney-General as to whether those expenses would be met.

I imagine that Senator James McClelland will not be in a position to answer these questions tonight, although if he is able to give some indication I am sure it will be appreciated. My purpose in airing this matter is to indicate that an injustice is being caused and that it ought to be rectified. There appears to me to be no reason why it should not be rectified unless the apprehension that is held by these respondents is a justified apprehension; that is, that the Attorney-General has been prevailed upon by Mr Egan and his associate, Mr Paul Russell Whelan who, I understand, is an associate of Mr Enderby, to ensure that whilst Mr Egan has his financial expenses guaranteed to him, the fact that the respondents have no guarantee whatever that their costs will be paid will place them in an invidious position and they will not continue in the proceedings and thereby allow Mr Egan to succeed in his application. Whether that be right or wrong I am unable to say, but it is an apprehension which is felt by the respondents.

When one takes into account the number of applicants- and I understand that the Postmaster-General (Senator Bishop) is one of the persons who made application to the Attorney-General on behalf of these people and that the Executive of the Australian Council of Trade Unions has been concerned to make representations on behalf of these people- unless some action is taken the purposes of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act provision which enable legal aid to be paid will not be satisfied. The provision in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act has a heightened impact because of the fact that no costs can now be awarded in this type of proceeding against the other party, and everybody who is engaged in that litigation knows from the moment that litigation commences there will be liability for costs that they will have to bear, and in this case it is a significant liability.

I therefore pose these questions: Has the Attorney-General had for his consideration since February 1975 applications for financial assistance from some 25 members of Australia's third largest trade union in respect of a legal proceeding taken against those officers by one Barry Thomas Egan in the Industrial Court? Was the Attorney-General requested by any person to expedite approval for financial assistance to Barry Thomas Egan and to delay or deny approval for financial assistance to those against whom Mr Egan was bringing proceedings in order to force those persons to abandon their opposition to the orders sought by Mr Egan? In consequence of that request did the Attorney-General in or about April 1975 approve payment of financial assistance to Mr Egan?

Further, in or about that month, did the Attorney-General request his departmental officers to withdraw a recommendation that financial assistance be extended for the 25 respondents who opposed the order sought by Mr Egan and substitute for that recommendation an advice which conveyed that the Attorney-General could with propriety delay his decision on the respondents' application until Mr Egan's action against time had run its course? If this is so, will the Attorney-General identify the person who requested him to adopt this course and table all the adv i sings from his departmental officers in connection with this matter between January and June 1 975.

I finally ask: Is the Attorney-General aware that the amendments made to this legislation in 1972 under which the Attorney-General was given the power and the authority to determine applications for financial assistance were made so that the Parliament could satisfy itself that the exercise of this important discretion would be characterised by justice and efficiency rather than by the possible partisanship and the possible inefficiency which could exist if officers over whom the Parliament had no authority were handling this matter?

In view of the circumstances I simply say that where a Minister has the responsibility in these areas a House of the Parliament is an appropriate place where his handling of this discretion could be raised. I trust that I have raised this matter in a manner which highlights the problems of principle which are involved in the way in which this discretion is exercised. I indicate that this is not a case in which the broad Party political issues are canvassed but the matter is being aired to ensure that there is proper administration of our legal aid scheme. This is a case where I think an injustice has been carried on for far too long. I would be grateful is the Minister representing the Attorney-General could see as quickly as possible that justice is done.

talk.start.para: I suppose we can give Senator Greenwood credit for acting tonight in a spirit of high principle, but I think we can be excused for feeling some scepticism that that was his real motivation. He did not make any direct accusations against the Attorney-General (Mr Enderby), but there were some snide innuendoes in what he' said. For instance, he said that an application for legal aid had been made by Mr Egan, and by Mr Whalan who he understood was an associate of Mr Enderby. I would like a more precise definition of that statement from Senator Greenwood. The Attorney-General of Australia does not have an associate in the sense that a judge has an associate. What does Senator Greenwood mean b suggesting that Mr Whalan is an associate of Mr Enderby? Is this meant to indicate that he is in a position to bring some undue influence on Mr Enderby?

speech.para: As I understand the gravamen of Senator Greenwood's speech, it was that the Attorney-General had exercised his discretion to grant legal aid in a 'manner which favoured certain litigants in an individual litigation and which wrongfully brought pressure on the opponents of his favoured side in this industrial litigation by keeping them in doubt as to whether they would be up for extensive costs in the proceedings that are on foot. He does not have any proof of that. But, even though he does not have any proof and even though he has put the whole matter as a sort of tentative questions and as a seeking of enlightenment as to whether the suspected injustice is in fact the case, he has not hesitated to assert positively that an injustice is being done. I suggest that this is legal sharp practice at its worst.

Senator Greenwooddoes not have any facts upon which to base the innuendo that he has cast into the ring here tonight. All he knows is that legal aid has been granted to one side in litigation and that apparently it has not yet been granted to the other side. I am not aware- I could not be expected to be aware- of the precise facts of this situation. But my recollection of the legislation providing for legal aid in the industrial law of this country is that the respondents that is, the parties who are dragged into the ring, who did not start the proceedings- in litigation may make application for payment of their costs. My experience when I was practising in this arena was that they were very rarely refused.

To make a charge that the Attorney-General of Australia is using his power to exercise a discretion for the granting of costs in favour of one side in the litigation and is withholding the granting of costs to the other side in order to favour one side and to intimidate the other side is, I should have thought, a charge of such seriousness that the man making the charge would have had precise information on which to make it. But nothing emerged from what Senator Greenwood said to indicate that he has any such proof. That did not stop him from bandying around words like 'injustice'. I would suggest- I confess that I do not know the facts of this matter that to bandy the matter around in this way is the height of irresponsibility.

I hasten to add that I do not even know the merits of the litigation between Mr Egan and his opponents. I have not taken sides, politically or industrially, in the matter. But I think that we have to admit that for the state to pay the costs in litigation between rival factions in unions is a reasonable social cost and that if we are to preserve democracy in the unions- where after all large interests inevitably come into conflict- it must be accepted that the costs that individual unionists or even officials of unions incur in the deciding of these matters in the courts are appropriate for the state to bear. This is especially the case because of the particularly tangled state of industrial law in this country. I do not want to be embarking once more upon a journey into the thickets of the Moore v. Doyle case, but the fact of the matter is that, with the best will in the world, union members in this country can find themselves involved in litigation caused primarily by the dichotomy between State and Federal industrial law and, in defence of what they consider to be highly cherished rights, they may have to embark upon the most tangled, lengthy litigation the cost of which they should not be asked to bear.

talk.start.para: That is what we want you to remove by withdrawing the Superior Court Bill.

That is a side issue in the matter that we are discussing tonight. Where the battles are fought out, whether in a superior court or an industrial court, is not really germane to the issue I am discussing. If we want to have unions and union leaderships in this country that genuinely reflect the wishes of their members, which I suggest is a highly important social matter, I think that it is appropriate that, with the right safeguards, the state- I do not mean, say, New South Wales; I mean the 'state' in its generic sense; the government, if you like; the people- should bear the cost of the litigation which decides in the ultimate analysis who are the legitimate leaders of these vast and powerful organisations. To suggest that the Attorney-General, who has an unblemished record so far as any person in this Parliament knows- I have never heard anyone suggest otherwise- should use this highly important power to favour one faction against another is, I suggest, a grave and very unworthy charge in the absence of positive evidence. In any event I will take great pains to find out what are the facts of this matter and I will seek an appropriate occasion to set them out.

continue.para: I merely close on the note of regretting that Senator Greenwood has seen fit to make these snide innuendoes without any backing up, any support for these charges against a man who in my view- and I think in the view of most honourable senators opposite, no matter how they may disagree with his politics- has acted in an exemplary way in the carrying out of his duties.

talk.start.para: Mr President, I rise on a point of personal misrepresentation. I only say that whether the questions which I have asked are sustained or not, the material which I put before the Senate was material supplied to me formally on behalf of the 24 persons who have not yet received an answer. If they cannot have their point of view placed in this Senate without the person who presents it being subjected to type of unfair accusations which have been made, it is a very poor day.
I rise to a point of order. What is the misrepresentation to which Senator Greenwood is replying? Where was he misrepresented?

interjection.para: The PRESIDENT- Senator Greenwood, you claimed to have been misrepresented. Have you put your case?

talk.start.para: Yes.

I wish to speak on the same matter, because my name has been mentioned. Perhaps I should state for the information of Senator James McClelland and others what the position was. About a fortnight ago I was approached by Mr Goldsworthy, the General Secretary of the Shop Assistants Union. Mr Goldsworthy, who is a South Australian, advised me that he and the Australian Council of Trade Unions had made representations to Mr Enderby about the matter. He asked whether I would speak to Mr Enderby about it. I did so within a couple of days. Mr Enderby stated that he had not determined the matter and that it would be considered at a later date. I related that answer to Mr Goldsworthy. I was told that Mr Goldsworthy would take a deputation to the Minister. I am not aware of what has developed since then. But the matter was put to Mr Enderby who said that the matter was under consideration and that it had not been determined. I understood then that either Mr Goldsworthy or the ACTU would follow up the matter.
I rise tonight to speak on matters of a domestic nature. I do so mindful of the statement that you, Mr President, made during the adjournment debate last Wednesday. You said:

speech.para: I hope that there will never be another occasion when these matters have to be raised in the adjournment debate in the Senate.

Unfortunately, Mr President, because of developments over the past few days it is necessary for these matters to be raised again. I refer, firstly, to an advertisement which appeared in the 'Canberra Times' on Saturday 7 June. One can only assume that the advertisement was placed as a result of what was said during the adjournment debate last Wednesday. The advertisement is very brief and I would like to read it to the Senate. It appears under the Australian coat of arms and it simply states:
AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENT JOINT HOUSE DEPARTMENT
ATTENDANT GRADE 1
(Position more suited to females)
SALARY: $6,358-6,663 per annum. Superannuation available after qualifying period.
DUTIES: Assist members of the Public, particularly females, visiting Parliament House. Staff and Information Centre, and Bookshop. Weekend work involved.
QUALIFICATIONS: Neat pleasant appearance essential and an aptitude for or expedience in dealing with the public desirable.

One can only assume that the word 'expedience' was supposed to be the word 'experience', unless, of course, the Joint House Department does find it necessary to get rid of visitors virtually as they come through the front door by disposing of them out the back door.

I have never claimed to be an academic. I am a pretty simple sort of a person, but I would really like someone to clarify for me what that advertisement is all about. I cannot understand that a responsible department of the Parliament of

Australia not only could but would insert such drivel in a daily newspaper. I would like to know, for instance, to whom I am supposed to apply; how I am supposed to apply, whether by writing, by telephone, or perhaps it is thought that we still use carrier pigeons. I would also like to make sure, if I were an applicant, that I knew by what date my application was due in. I would like to have some indication as to when an appointment would be made. In addition as an applicant I would like to know- as a senator I would certainly Uke to know- just what the term 'superannuation available after qualifying period' actually means. I ask this question mainly because, as I pointed out last Wednesday, we have only one female attendant, who is still employed in a temporary capacity even though she was appointed in 1973.

I would Uke to read from a letter dated 9 June 1975, which was yesterday, received by that attendant. I do so in an endeavour to have the situation clarified. The information I am about to give to the Senate did not come from the attendant herself. I am given to understand that already a form of intimidation is being used against her. So, in order to provide her with some form of protection, I intend not only to read the letter but also to name the person concerned. The letter is addressed to Mrs M. Rodda, Joint House Department, Parliament House, Canberra. As I said, the letter is dated 9 June. It reads:
I refer to your enquiry of 9 June, 1975, concerning your position of Attendant, Grade 1, on the staff of this Department.

You may be assured that the rights and entitlements you have in your present position are being kept in mind and will not be prejudiced when the new appointment to the vacancy recently advertised, is made. It is, in fact, to protect your position that the new appointment will be made in a temporary capacity only, at least in the first instance.
Mr President,would someone please explain to me how superannuation benefits could possibly be available if the appointment is being made 'in a temporary capacity only "? The letter goes on:

However, just as we are protecting your interests against new appointees, you will appreciate that it is also necessary to protect the interests of other Attendants, Grade 1, with longer service than yourself. It is for this reason that your appointment has been delayed so that the necessary formalities can be completed that will allow these Attendants to be appointed with not less seniority status than yourself. It is regretted that this action has taken longer than expected, but I am hopeful that finality in it will be reached within the next few weeks.

The letter is signed 'R. W. Hillyer, Secretary'. I pointed out that the attendant has been employed by the Joint House Department since some time in the middle of 1973 and all she is getting at the moment is a regretful notice from the Secretary of the Department saying 'that this action has taken longer than expected'. I understood that most Public Service awards provided for appointment to the permanent staff after 6 months' service, and I am rather curious as to why that has not already been done.

I would like now to quote from a letter referred to by Senator McLaren in the adjournment debate this week. It is a letter also written by Mr Hillyer and is dated 6 May, which is already one month away. I read from the Hansard record:

The staff ceiling limit that was imposed was later eased and accordingly some months ago one of the two women remaining, who was previously on part-time only, was advised that she would be appointed permanently to the vacant full-time position. However, she was also informed that, so as not to place her in a more favourable seniority position than the other Attendants who had given longer service, her appointment would not take place until administrative action could be taken that would allow these other Attendants to also be made permanent officers. This action is now in hand and it is anticipated that the permanent appointment of this female Attendant will soon be possible which will then also make it possible for an appointment to be made to the position she will vacate.

I read into that advertisement that a number of attendant staff around this Parliament House are also on virtually temporary employment. It does not matter that they may have been employed here for some years.

I return to the advertisement, or perhaps I could call it the non-advertisement, which was placed in the 'Canberra Times'. The final paragraph deals with superannuation benefits being available. I am extremely curious about this reference. At the time I spoke on this matter last week I did not have any figures available. I have done a little homework since then and I have found that approximately 26 000 people visit Parliament House in each 12 monthly period. This is 26 000 people who actually take part in the guided tour. This figure does not take into consideration the number who come in when the Houses are sitting. It is quite possible that if those people were taken into consideration and registered as entering the building, the number of visitors could be trebled even. I understand that on public holidays and during holiday periods there are frequently 2000 to 3000 visitors a day to this building. Yet we still have only 2 female members of the attendant staff, although an appointment was approved by the Joint House Committee some weeks ago.

I think that concern should be expressed also that during weekends there are only 5 members of the staff available at Parliament House. Three of these people act as guides, one is in attendance at the front door and the other one is a female attendant who, by then, is doing her mind bending little bit in the cage downstairs. It is supposed to be a book selling department. If honourable senators have not been inside it, I suggest that if they really want to blow their brains they spend a couple of hours tied up there. Those 5 people have to be responsible not only for the security the tours, the inquiries and the book sales conducted in the House on those days but also they have to appear to be charming and look as if they really are enjoying their lives.

I do not think I am being presumptuous in suggesting that the Joint House Department should perhaps make available to itself fairly soon the services of a person with a little knowledge of copywriting of advertisements and perhaps it should be instructed- not requested but instructed to place another advertisement in the 'Canberra Times' as soon as possible, complete with all the details, pointing out that this will be a temporary appointment only. If the Joint House Department were really serious in not trying to get anyone to apply for the position advertised, the advertisement placed in the newspaper was a darned good start. I am also presumptuous enough to suggest that Mrs Rodda should look forward to becoming a permanent member of the staff and to receive as early as possible the superannuation benefits mentioned in the advertisement.

Mr President,I, like yourself, am anxious that this adjournment debate should be utilised in the way it was intended and not in the main for airing matters of domesticity. But a number of problems relating to this debate have been brought to my attention. It is rather amazing how people are made aware that perhaps you intend doing something for them. I wish to quote from the Hansard record of the Senate Estimates Committee A which met on Monday, 22 October 1973. The evidence on pages 335 and 336 deals with the situation with regard to additional attendant staff having been employed and there is some discussion between Senator James McClelland who was chairman of the Committee, the then President of the Senate Sir Magnus Cormack, and Senators Wright and Georges, together with the Clerk of the Senate, Mr Odgers, and the Usher of the Black Rod, Mr Smith. As reported on page 335, Senator Georges raised this question:
But do I understand that an attendant has to work a considerable time before he goes on to an overtime rating?
Mr Smithreplied:
The Public Service (Parliamentary Officers) Regulations lay down hours of duty based on a conceptual 36 and three quarter hour week, which is the normal Public Service working week.

Mr President,I understand that there are still a number of attendants on the staff who find it necessary to work a 40-hour week before they actually go on to any overtime. Mr Smith says- I remind the Senate that this was on 22 October 1973- in reply to Senator George's further question:
Is that for everyone?

Well, for everyone on the Senate staff. It does not necessarily apply to all other departments because other departments have different kinds of positions. I understand that the Joint House Department has different hours for people working in its refreshment rooms and other areas. But it is based on a conceptual 36% hour week which involves- I may be wrong here, because these hours have changed recently- working 3214 hours in recess and 42 hours in session. From time to time, we have taken out a study on this matter to see whether the conceptual 36% hour week has been exceeded or whether it has been in the attendants' favour. We have never yet found it to be not in the attendants' favour.

I have a great deal of correspondence on this and I do not intend reading it all but there are extracts which I would like to have written into the record. I put to you, Mr President, that if there are still discrepancies we have been falling down on this job since 22 October 1973 when an Estimates Committee was assured that the situation did not exist. For instance back on 15 February 1973-1 have read all this correspondence but I do not intend reading it to the Senate- a similar question was raised by the Branch Secretary of the Federated Miscellaneous Workers' Union. He made representations to the Speaker of the House of Representatives who was then Mr W. J. Aston, and to the President of the Senate who was then Senator Sir Magnus Cormack. It is from this last letter that I quote. It is dated 15 February 1973:

The representations you have made have been the subject of examination by the officers of the parliamentary departments concerned and of discussion with officers of the Public Service Board. However, there remain certain details that still need to be settled and I have asked those concerned to expedite their consideration of these so that a reply to you can be furnished as soon as possible.

I do not know whether in actual fact Mr Wood ever received a reply. I am not even sure that Senator Sir Magnus Cormack got any further with the matter, but I know that you, Mr President, on 8 May 1973 in your capacity as Government Whip in the Senate received a letter from Mr Hillyer, the Secretary of the Joint House Department, which said:
HOURS OF DUTY:

As previously advised the Federated Miscellaneous Workers' Union submission on this matter is still under consideration and I am not in a position at this point of time to indicate either agreement to the proposal or rejection of it.
However, I am conscious of the need to secure an early decision and you may be assured every endeavour will be made to provide one as soon as possible.

I should like some indication, even if the matter is still in the 'too difficult ' basket, or in the pipeline somewhere, Mr Hillyer having expressed the concern that he is conscious of the need to secure an early decision, that someone somewhere is in actual fact going to make a decision on this. While we are speaking of the male attendants let us look at the same letter by Mr Hillyer, dated 6 May, which relates to the shirt and footwear allowances for the Senate staff attendants. It states:
The scale of issue of these items that currently applies in the Department is as follows:
Shirts- Three per annum at a cost not exceeding $5 each.
Footwear- One pair of shoes per annum to the value of $8.75 or, if preferred, one pair each two years at a cost of 17.50.
Two questions come to my mind. Firstly, from where did the figure of $5 per shirt come? Secondly, who contrived the figure of $8.75 a year for a pair of shoes?

talk.start.para: That was Noah.

Yes, it probably was. But even in 1973 where would attendants have been able to buy the articles at those prices? We are talking about the tools of trade of the male attendants at Parliament House. We are talking about those tools of trade in exactly the same way as the tools of trade of a plumber, a bricklayer or a carpenter are referred to in union disputes and union awards. There must have been some basis for somebody coming down with those rather brilliant figures. I should like to clarify the situation to find out from where the figures came. The attendants should perhaps be a little thankful that the Taxation Department has a more realistic attitude to the prices paid for clothing which is being used as uniform. I think one would find that attendants are allowed a little more leeway in their taxation returns.

continue.para: I would Uke to make a couple more points. One of the most controversial areas in the running of the House, as far as I am concerned, is the situation which exists in the dining rooms where we are subjected to a rather repetitious menu which changes very little and which does not depend at all on climatic conditions or the days of sitting. But at least with our facilities we are able to order and receive a number of items of food at rather peculiar hours- but then we work rather peculiar hours. Unfortunately the situation is not the same in the staff dining room. I understand that it is not even possible to purchase a slice of toast there after about 9.30 in the morning. I understand that the premises are rather touchingly referred to as 'Hepatitis Hall'.

I notice that on 25 May 1973 in the report of the proceedings of Estimates Committee A there was a rather humorous interchange between Senators Wheeldon, Gair, Georges and McLaren on this very item. So perhaps we should be looking for a more comprehensive study of the running of the dining rooms while we are having this airing and general complaint about the administration of the Joint House Department. I have noticed in my arrivals and departures at and from Parliament House a number of parking signs clearly marked 'Members Only'. One could assume from that that a number of members drive to Parliament each day and require close proximity parking. But the real situation is not as simple as that. In actual fact the parking is not even for the personal staff of members or for some of the most important people in this House- the Hansard reporters. I had a quick look around today and I discovered that most of the parking facilities marked for members only were being used by members of the Joint House Department, the clerks of the Senate and numerous other people, but with a couple of members thrown in for good luck.

talk.start.para: Did you see my car there?
No, as a matter of fact, I did not, Senator McLaren. It would appear that there is some difficulty even for members in obtaining a parking sticker if they want to avail themselves of the facilities.
They absolutely refuse to do anything about it.

I think it is about time members themselves did something about it. I understand that the difficulty in obtaining car parking stickers is exceeded only by the difficulty in drawing hens' teeth. The staff of members, Hansard writers, the typists, the librarians and, one presumes, the switchboard operators, the dining room attendants, the bar staff and others have to park their cars up at the back of the House. If one looks at it in the dark at night or in the early hours of the morning one realises that it might as well be at the back of Bourke. It is in a dark area with great potential, for instance, for rapists. I understand that on Friday night of last week Canberra residents were warned that a rapist had escaped.

continue.para: The people on whom we rely to do so much work- and the female staff particularly- in our involvement here in Parliament House are required to walk into a reasonably secluded, dimly lit area to collect their cars at night. A number of them have already found that their tyres have been let down. They have left this House in the late hours of the night or the early hours of the morning and have found themselves in some difficulty in trying to get home. I am not affected because I do not have a car in Canberra, but a lot of other people are affected. We should not wait until there is a rape or an attempted rape, until there is an attack or an attempted attack, before some action is taken. I am a great believer in prevention being better than the cure. So let us start doing some preventing.

I understand that last year a study was carried out of the close proximity car parking facilities for the people who work in the House, and it was determined by that study that no further facilities were necessary for them. Of course, the fact that the study was undertaken in broad daylight would not have thrown a great deal of light on the matter. Perhaps we should have someone out there having a look at the situation in the dark of night when these people are required to leave. There is a pressing need for a better lit parking area for those people who have to work because of our involvement and their involvement here.

Having mentioned pressing needs, I should like to draw the attention of the Senate to a situation which would probably be quite amusing except that it is so ridiculous. Honourable senators are probably aware that in the main part of the building outside the chamber there is a ladies toilet at the back of the Senate attendants box, just up the stairs inside the front entrance. It is quite clearly marked 'Ladies Convenience' I think and it is presumed that this convenience is there for the use of ladies who come to visit Parliament House- the very ladies who are mentioned in the advertisement. Some 2 weeks ago I understand they started -

talk.start.para: Members of the Opposition do not seem to be interested in this. There is none in the chamber.

Well, they are not terribly interested in the running of the House anyway. But for about 2 weeks now I have been conscious of an almost constant stream of people being directed downstairs and I have discovered that these toilets are having the ceilings replaced. While the House is sitting, if you do not mind, with a rather lengthy recess coming up, they are having the ceilings replaced in the ladies' toilets which are required for the use of the general public. The difficulty arises, I believe, in that yesterday the downstairs facilities were being painted and are still being painted and therefore are closed to the public.
One member of the Opposition just looked into the chamber but he took fright and left.

I am pleased. At least he is expressing some concern. I presume the Joint House Department ordered firstly the replacement of the ceilings in the original toilets and now it has ordered that the toilets downstairs, normally for the use of lady visitors to the House, are to be painted. To the best of my knowledge, the only other facilities downstairs are those that require people to go through a door which has a sign outside which clearly states 'Members only allowed through these doors'. Quite frankly, Mr President, I dread to think of the number of women who must stand there almost with their legs crossed and quivering wondering whether they dare go through those doors. I believe that it should have been possible for all of these things to have been arranged during the recess and I am concerned that obviously the Joint House Department did not take that into consideration. Of course, if it had been done then, it would not really have inconvenienced anyone a great deal.

continue.para: I must admit, I find it a little disconcerting to have to traverse something like 4 corridors to get from this chamber to a ladies' toilet. Yet immediately behind your entrance, where you are sitting now, Mr President, there are 2 toilet facilities; one is marked 'Senators'- and I am a senator- and the other is marked 'Officials' and one can only presume in this illustrious House that they are both intended for males. I question the right of any male official to have a toilet in such close proximity to this chamber as against the right of female members of this House. I cannot understand that someone at some time has not thought of simply making one a male toilet and the other a female toilet but now that I have put the idea into their heads perhaps someone will give the matter some consideration. This toilet could be used by the female members of the staffs of the members of Parliament. It could even be used by female members of Parliament.

talk.start.para: What about joint toilets?
Mr President, I travelled in Asia and I found that they do utilise joint facilities.
They have them on aeroplanes.
Yes- and no one objects to them there. I certainly do not object to them there. I think the people who might be outside waiting for me to come out might object more than I would.

continue.para: In conclusion I simply want to refer to a reply to a question on notice which was asked by Senator McLaren. I am aware that the hour is late and that members want to get to their respective abodes in preparation for a reasonably long day tomorrow. I question the reply that has been provided to question No. 549 in that it contains no reference to any of the employees in the bars or the dining rooms. Yet I am quite sure that a number of those employees would be considered to be administrative staff. The reply lists the names of 13 people on salaries ranging from $6,000-odd to $20,000. The reply is supposed to relate to the administrative staff of the Joint House Department. I respectfully suggest that perhaps this question should be returned to the Joint House Department, through the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Wriedt), for clarification and that the Senate should decide now that there be a comprehensive study into the running of the House at present by the Joint House Department. That would appear to me to be the only way to avoid having to speak continually during adjournment debates about matters on which senators require clarification.

talk.start.para: It is my desire to raise also a matter related to the Joint House Department. At the time I put my name down on the list to speak tonight I was not aware that Senator Coleman intended to refer to the answer given to me today. I intend to refer to it. It relates to question No. 529 which I placed on the notice paper on 14 May. It sought information as to the numerical strength of the administrative staff of the Joint House Department, the duties performed by each person and the salaries paid. The answer reveals a strength of thirteen. Names, in order of seniority, are supplied. In respect of the Chief Executive Officer it is not stated whether the position is permanent or temporary, yet every other officer is designated as a temporary employee or a permanent employee. The duties of all the staff, except the Secretary who is in receipt of a salary of $20,000 per annum, have been outlined. I am particularly interested to know why these particulars were omitted from the answer. I would be grateful if they could be supplied at an early date. The total salary paid to all 13 staff at a minimum rate is in excess of $124,000 per annum. If the maximum rate is applied the amount is in excess of $132,000.
Do those figures include overtime?

I am coming to that. These figures are arrived at without any allowance for overtime. Therefore it will be seen that an astronomical cost is involved in the administration of the Joint House Department. One wonders why that should be so. Paragraph (6) of the answer given to me today explains why. I will quote that paragraph. It states:

continue.para: Up to the year 1954 the functions of Secretary to the Joint House Department were carried out by a senior officer of either the Senate or the House of Representatives in addition to the duties of his substantive office. In 1954 with the retirement of Mr R. H. C. Loof, then Clerk Assistant of the Senate and Secretary, Joint House Department, the President of the Senate and Speaker of the House of Representatives decided that the growth in the functions of both positions made it essential to separate them and so the office of Secretary to the Joint House Department was created and filled in a full time capacity. The numerical strength of the administrative section of the Department at that time was eight.
That was in 1954. Of course we are now told that the size of the staff has grown to thirteen.

The number of staff referred to previously and costs involved have to be considerably added to because there are other people who are employed in connection with the running of the services of the Parliament- the catering and bar services, etc.- who have to do a great deal of administrative and clerical work, who are charged with certain responsibilities, and who are on a lower rate of salary than some of the administrative staff whose only duty, it would appear, according to the duty statements provided, is in double checking the work of the people in the category I have just mentioned. I refer to the people who work in the bar, the cellar and other associated jobs.

I understand that it has not been the practice in the past for committees such as the Joint Statutory Committee on Public Accounts to inquire into departments of the Parliament due to the fact that the committees have been reluctant to do so. However, in view of the enormous cost of administering the Joint House Department, as has been revealed here today, it would appear that the time is now appropriate for the Public Accounts Committee to make a searching inquiry into the affairs of the Department in order to ascertain if its continued existence in its present form is necessary.
